abstract: THE FIFTY-SIXTH REGIMENT. -- This regiment, which has now been encamped at Fort Richmond, Staten Island, for more than a week, is to be mustered into the United States service to-day, and to-morrow will proceed to Washington. All members are required to report to-day, or be considered as deserters. The number of men in camp on Saturday was 563. The number will be increased to-day to over 600. This is the first and only regiment from Brooklyn which has answered the call of the President for 100 days' service. A large number of the friends of the members paid a visit to the camp yesterday.
lead_paragraph: THE FIFTY-SIXTH REGIMENT. -- This regiment, which has now been encamped at Fort Richmond, Staten Island, for more than a week, is to be mustered into the United States service to-day, and to-morrow will proceed to Washington. abstract: Early's New Invasion; Invasion of, Sympathizers
snippet: Early's New Invasion; Invasion of, Sympathizers
lead_paragraph: It would be vain to attempt to found a theory of the new incursion of EARLY's raiders into the districts of the Upper Potomac from any one of the disjointed reports which the telegraph has been permitted to convey to the public. We see in these reports, so far, simply the sudden dash of two or three separate squads of cavalry or mounted infantry, firstat one point, then at another -- at ,Point ofRocks, at Adamstown, near the Monocacy, close to Shippensburgh, at Chambersburgh, at St. Thomas, at Mercersburgh, at Waynesboro', at Greencastle, and at a number of less important points in-Upper Maryland and South-western Pennsylvania. At none of these points is the rebel force estimated at more than eight hundred, and it is possibly the same squad that reappears at different points and succeeds in duplicating itself by quick movements. Be this, however, as it may, we can find nothing to indicate that the band operating in Pennsylvania, the advance portion of which occupied Chambersburgh early on Saturday morning, and burnt the town later in the day, is much superior in numbers or equipment to the flying squads that pounced on the railroad lines round Baltimore a few weeks ago. They move quickly. They show a bold front. They do not burden themselves with trains. And they have a thorough appreciation of the kind of resistance they may expect from the State cavalry or Pennsylvania. We do not see, then, what is to hinder a force, say of a couple of thousand mounted rebels, to burn a score or more of border towns and villages, at the same time that they keep up the appearance of being the advance of a large invading army.

abstract: The first meeting over the new race-course commences to-morrow (Tuesday.) The course is admirably arranged, and, thanks to a genial rain, in fine condition for racing purposes. The liberal charactor of the numerous stakes and purses each day of the five to which the season extends, has attracted all the best racing stock from all parts of the Union.
lead_paragraph: The first meeting over the new race-course commences to-morrow (Tuesday.) The course is admirably arranged, and, thanks to a genial rain, in fine condition for racing purposes. The liberal charactor of the numerous stakes and purses each day of the five to which the season extends, has attracted all the best racing stock from all parts of the Union. Eleven are also on the ground from Canada. On Saturday evening over fifty thoroughbreds were already stabled in the vicinity of the scene of action. The Grand Stand is admirably located, and a model of comfort and convenience, and no effort will be spared to render the meeting a most brilliant one. Saratoga is already crowded with visitors, in anticipation of this racing carnival, and each hour adds to their number. Those who leave by the night boats for Albany, or the evening trains, will be in ample season for the commencement of the meeting to-morrow, full particulars of which will be found in our advertising columns.

abstract: After two of the severest conflicts of the campaign, Gen. SHERMAN has pushed his lines from the Chattahoochee River to within two miles of Atlanta, at whose gates he is now loudly knocking. On the 18th all the army had crossed to the south side of the river. On the 20th Gen. McPHERSON cut the railroad at Decatur, between Atlanta and Augusta. All communications by railroad from Atlanta are now severed, except the Macon route.
lead_paragraph: TWO MILES FROM ATLANTA, Sunday, July 24, 1864.

abstract: The pirouettings of the rebel brigands north of the Potomac assume their proper and insignificant magnitude this morning alongside of the great operations which Gen. GRANT has inaugurated before Petersburgh. He has, in a two-fold sense, sprung a mine upon the rebels.
lead_paragraph: The pirouettings of the rebel brigands north of the Potomac assume their proper and insignificant magnitude this morning alongside of the great operations which Gen. GRANT has inaugurated before Petersburgh. He has, in a two-fold sense, sprung a mine upon the rebels. The mine under the rebel works, to which the match was applied as the sun was rising on Saturday morning, resulted in an eminent success. Not only was an immense volume of earth thrown for three hundred feet into the air; but the rebel position was at once charged by the gallant. Ninth Corps through the gap made, and the explosion was the signal for the discharge of every piece of artillery that we have in position from the Appomattox to our extreme left -the whole resulting in the capture of the entire line of rebel works and a good number of prisoners. The play of strategy, of skill and of genius in this whole affair and in the preliminary and collateral movements on both sides of the James River, will be found finely and picturesquely set forth in our special dispatches from army headquarters and from Washington. The intelligent reader will see the connection between this operation and the movement to the north bank of the James, of which we had intelligence on Saturday, and he will also see in it the realization and issue of several indications that have latterly been reaching the public.

abstract: Wise, H A; Capt Brand, of the Schooner Centipede; Smith, Prof H B; Christian Life in England; Maurice Dering
snippet: Wise, H A; Capt Brand, of the Schooner Centipede; Smith, Prof H B; Christian Life in England; Maurice Dering
lead_paragraph: The authoress of the Schonberg Cotta Family needs no recommendation from critics. Any new work of hers is sure to win its way to thousands of family circles where the story of the great reformation has acquired new life and significance from her attractive treatment. In her Sketches of Christian Life in England she employs a larger canvas and covers a wider extent of time with her historic groups. The nine sketches or stories, indeed comprised in the volume, relate to characteristic and remarkable events in the religious history of England from the introduction of Christianity by the companions of the Apostles to the era of WYCLIFFE and the Lollard persecution at the beginning of the Fifteenth Century. They show a familiarity, far from common, with remote times, and are evidently the production of one who has studied diligently the literature and existing monuments of the epochs she delineates. At the same time, she does not allow her learning to stifle or overshadow the vivid dramatic power, that recognizes the essential elements of humanity through every garb and costume, however strangely it may strike on our modern eyes. In what are commonly called the Dark Ages, through which these stories pleasantly and instructively lead us, the authoress has the good sense to see that it was not all one "palpable obscure," but that the various influences then working to produce the results now presented to us, must have had their oases of light where the germs of Christianity flourished individually with a strength and vigor that gave no uncertain promise of the better days to come. In sketching the elder days of English Christianity, the authoress has the advantage of more perfect acquaintance with the scene than she could possess of Germany, and her subjects naturally come nearer home to our sympathies and associations. The book is, therefore, likely to meet with a more extended demand than has welcomed the Cotta Family, and cannot be perused without deepening faith in the Divine government of the world, so wonderfully displayed in the memorable historic record of Christianity.

abstract: -- Just as the Express Train was leaving Albany yesterday at 12:40 P.M., two ladies had their pockets picked -- one of them losing only $20, which was all she had, and the other a much larger sum, according to her story, which we obtained from her own lips. Her loss was as follows: $800 in greenbacks, $21 in gold, $20 in other paper money, five cluster diamond rings, which cost at BALL, BLACK & Co., New-York, a few days since, $3,000; one gold tooth-pick, two silver pen knives, and her railroad ticket to Indianapolis. She gave her name as CROUSE, and said that her father resided in New-York City, but she resided in Indianapolis. Her father gave her the purse when she started from New-York, at the same time cautioning her against pickpockets. She reminded him that she had never lost any money, though she had traveled much, carrying with her large sums of money and other valuables, and assured him she would be on the lookout for thieves. Her impression was that the rascal was near by when this conversation occurred, and followed her to Albany, where, watching an opportunity, he accomplished his object.

abstract: The happiest augury of peace which the telegraph wires have flashed to us for two years, is the action of the Democratic Convention of Kentucky, Ohio and Illinois. They have sent delegates to the National Convention with instructions to vote for a peace platform framed upon the principles of LONG's speech. At last, then, the banner of truth is being lifted over the heads of a people who have been staggering in passion, blood and darkness for three years. Oh! that precious banner! -- if the Chicago Convention but have the illumination and the courage to lift it up and plant it as their rallying point in their coming struggle with their enemies, our enemies, the enemies of freedom and of humanity. Mr. LONG, of Ohio, was the brave and sagacious man, who, like another John the Baptist, came before to herald the banner of peace. Pointing it out to the great Democratic Babel of the North, confused of tongues and blinded of passion by the cunning of its adversary, he proclaimed in hoc signo vinces. He told his auditory that the great speech was well pondered in a month of preparation. Was it not the well-considered voice of his party at the time, and Mr. LONG the honored and chosen instrument of preaching a new and life giving political gospel to a great party reft and scattered by the storm of war? It bore these marks at the time, and we pray God what we see now is but the first budding of the sweet, ripe fruit that gospel is destined to bear. Some few weeks ago we outlined a platform for the Northern Democrats, and expressed the belief that they would grasp permanent power by adopting it. We are equally of opinion that on any platform having a single war plank in it, their chances are hopeless. If, now, the Chicago Convention take Mr. LONG's speech as the guide for the principles it shall put in issue before the North, we have no more doubt of its triumph than we have that LEE and JOHNSTON can whip GRANT and SHERMAN on any day in which they will give them battle in the open field.

abstract: On Sunday, the 24th ult:, in Cedar Grove, Walker County, Ga., two unoffending Union citizens were brutally murdered by the internal guerrillas who prowl around these regions.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, the 24th ult., in Cedar Grove, Walker County, Ga., two unoffending Union citizens were brutally murdered by the internal guerrillas who prowl around these regions. The gang of murderers were headed by a notoriousand bloodthirsty wretch named GATEWOOD, who has thus far escaped the halter. They approach, unawares, the house of their first victim, WILLIAM CLARKSON, and at once secured and took him out of doors. His cries for mercy were of no avail. The inhuman wretches deliberately laid the unfortunate man across two logs, and fairly pierced his brain with a whole volley of bullets. They next went to the house of a man named JIM JOHNSON who had twice deserted the rebel army, and is said to have, at no time, been anything but a true Union man, his connection with the rebel army being compulsory. Him they murdered in cold blood. After that they proceeded to the house of another Union citizen, but he, apprised of their movements, made good his escape.

abstract: The death of AARON D. PATCHEN, of Buffalo, is announced. The Express says: He was born at Ho[???]sack, in this State, in 1808. Left, when a boy, the head of a poor family, he so deported himself as to conciliate respect for himself and them. He proved himself a sterling man of business. He won the confidence of capitalists, and as a banker had filled, withcredit, several positions of great trust, when he removed to Buffalo in 1844. His career among us is well known. His extraordinary capacity as a financier, his wonderful quickness of perception and versatility of resource, and his daring and indomitable enemy, were well proven in the long, closing struggle of his business life. In his domestic relations he was kind, judicious, firm. His nature was genial. His address was easy, his manners pleasing, and has always succeeded in society. Like most men devoted to business he was truly known to but a few, but those who knew him truly admired and respected him, and there is among us much sincere mourning for his death.

abstract: -- There were two noticeable features in EARLY's last raid into Maryland. One was the large numbers of his men who deserted while north of the Potomac. It is estimated that where EARLY received one recruit to his forces, he lost fifty men by desertion. Another feature was, that many of the rebel sympathizers took up arms to expel the invading rebels. The Maryland Secessionists were for a long time a formidable body; but even they have at last become disgusted with their whilom friends from the South. One of our correspondents in Maryland  who is well acquainted with the state of feeling there, says that the Maryland sympathizers have been cajoled and deceived and abused and robbed by their own party until forbearance has ceased to be a virtue, and they have turned upon those who smote them. Many of these men are the most bitter enemies the rebels have in Maryland, and were the first to take up arms against EARLY's ruffians. The same state of feeling will yet appear and become dominant all over the South.
lead_paragraph: -- There were two noticeable features in EARLY's last raid into Maryland. One was the large numbers of his men who deserted while north of the Potomac. It is estimated that where EARLY received one recruit to his forces, he lost fifty men by desertion. Another feature was, that many of the rebel sympathizers took up arms to expel the invading rebels. The Maryland Secessionists were for a long time a formidable body; but even they have at last become disgusted with their whilom friends from the South. One of our correspondents in Maryland who is well acquainted with the state of feeling there, says that the Maryland sympathizers have been cajoled and deceived and abused and robbed by their own party until forbearance has ceased to be a virtue, and they have turned upon those who smote them. Many of these men are the most bitter enemies the rebels have in Maryland, and were the first to take up arms against EARLY's ruffians. The same state of feeling will yet appear and become dominant all over the South.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Bremen off Cape Race, on Saturday, from Southampton, we have advices three days later than by the steamship Scotia at this port. In the House of Lords, on the 18th, Lord BROUGHAM presented a petition from Jamaica relative to the increase of the slave trade in Cuba and asserting that Spain had violated her treaty-agreement on this subject.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship Bremen off Cape Race, on Saturday, from Southampton, we have advices three days later than by the steamship Scotia at this port. In the House of Lords, on the 18th, Lord BROUGHAM presented a petition from Jamaica relative to the increase of the slave trade in Cuba and asserting that Spain had violated her treaty-agreement on this subject. The political relations of England with Brazil were discussed in the House of Commons. There is little news of importance from the Danish war. The Austrian took possession of Feohs on the 18th. An island on the west coast of Schleswig is in possession of the Allies. The proposed incorporation of Denmark with the German Confederation is not received with much favor in France. The Constitutionnel says it would disturb the balance of power in Europe, and pronounces the scheme inadmissible. On the other hand, Austria and Prussia have met the proposals of Denmark with apparent favor. A truce was agreed upon until the 31st of July, and Denmark was requested to send a Plenipotentiary to Vienna to come to an understanding with the Allies.

abstract: -- A gentleman just arrived from Little Rock gives us some items of interest in reference to affairs in Arkansas. He reports a great deal of sickness among the people, mostly a virulent type of diarrhoea. Capt. SPRAGUE, of the First Missouri Cavalry, Gen. CARR's Staff, was exchanged on the 10th inst., and returned from Camden. PRICE's infantry are at Camden, while Gen. PRICE himself is at Shreveport. KIRBY SMITH was supposed to be attempting to cross to the east side of the Mississippi. MARMADUKE was crossing in small squads in the neighborhood of James' Landing, JOE SHELBY was at Searcy, on the Little Red River, midway between Little Rock and Batesville. On the 10th instant he captured 180 of the Tenth Illinois cavalry, including eight or nine commissioned officers. It was judged that he would move west from that point, as a part of his force had already gone to Clinton, seventy-five miles west of Searcy. Guerrillas were infesting the banks of the Arkansas, but were without artillery. Gen. CARR is in command of the district of Little Rock. Gens. LEE and GORDON, from BANKS' department, were at the mouth of White River, with reinforcements for STEELE. -- St. Louis Union, July 28.

abstract: -- AN ATTEMPT TO RESCUE A PRISONER FROM OFFICERS -- ONE MAN SHOT. -- About half-past six o'clock last evening, a disturbance occurred in a lager beer saloon, in Tenth-avenue, near Twenty-seventh-street, during which a man named JOHN MURRAY assaulted a woman. Officers KERNON and RINN, of the Sixteenth Precinct, arrested the man and were immediately assailed by the crowd, who threw stones at them and attempted to rescue the prisoner. The officers rapped for assistance, and used their clubs with such effect as to beat back the rescuers and take several of them to the stationhouse. They gave their names as JOHN MURRAY, TERRENCE O'KERNON, JOHN OWENS and MICHAEL OWENS. The officers returned to make still further arrests, and were again attacked when near Twenty-sixth-streat, by a crowd led on by MICHAEL CRANE. They were knocked down and badly beaten, when they drew their revolvers and fired. CRANE tell mortally wounded. He was carried to the stationhouse, but died on the way. An inquest will be held on his body this morning. JOHN LOWLER was taken into custody at the same time, and the crowd dispersed. The prompt action of the police doubtless saved much trouble.

abstract: On Thursday the primary department of Public School No. 13, situated in Houston-street, near Norfolk, gave an exhibition which was highly satisfactory, and gratifying both to the parents of the scholars, and to the citizens of the ward generally. Mrs. MARY L. HAGGERTY, the Principal, is entitled to great credit for the care and attention she has given to her department, and that her duties have all been well performed is proved in the proficiency exhibited by her scholars, That she is truly loved by them all, was shown by the exertions they made to please her, and the pleasure they exhibited at her smile of approval. At about 1 o'clock the school was called to order by Commissioner JAMES L. MILLER, a gentleman well known for the great interest he has taken in all matters concerning our Public Schools, and his prompt and decisive action in the investigation of the Fourth Ward schools. The order of exercises was as follows:

lead_paragraph: There are no changes to announce at the theatres now open to the public. Mr. DAN. BRYANT's success has more than justified the best expectations of his admirers. Wallack's Theatre has been crowded to its greatest capacity every eight since the gentleman's debut. The same pieces are still being played there, but BOURCICAULT's "Colleen Bawn" is announced forto-morrow evening, Mr, BRYANT appearing asMiles Na Coppaleen. At the Olymyic Theatre BALFE's opera of the "Rose of Castile" will be given to-night. At Nlblo's the "Sea of Ice." At the Broadway Theatre the "French Spy." It is the last week of the successful engagement of Miss HELEN WESTERN at this establishment. BARNUM announces "Mazulm, or the Night Owl" for another week, with extra performances and exhibitions in the principal saloons.

abstract: We have startling news this morning from the Army of the Potomac. Shortly before 5 o'clock  on Saturday morning, a mine which had been excavated under the rebel works in Front of Gen. BURNSIDE'S corps, was fired by the application of a lucifer match, and instantly a vast volume of dirt was thrown very high into the air, and a gap formed through which our troops rushed and carried the first line of rebel works.
lead_paragraph: We have startling news this morning from the Army of the Potomac. Shortly before 5 o'clock on Saturday morning, a mine which had been excavated under the rebel works in Front of Gen. BURNSIDE's corps, was fired by the application of a lucifer match, and instantly a vast volume of dirt was thrown very high into the air, and a gap formed through which our troops rushed and carried the first line of rebel works. Simultaneously with the springing of this mine all our artillery from the Appomattox to our extreme left -- about a hundred pieces -- opened upon the enemy, and, of course, aided the charge of the infantry. The rebels stiffly contested their next defences, and up to afternoon of Saturday, fighting was still going on.

abstract: The Mine Explosion Before; Mine; The
snippet: The Mine Explosion Before; Mine; The
lead_paragraph: -- We have news of the explosion, on Saturday, of a mine before Petersburgh, which had been constructed under a certain part of the rebel works. The rebels had known for some time of the existence of this mine; for the Richmond Examiner of Wednesday last mentions that GRANT had been mining for a month, and that it was quite time he was springing some of his mines. The difficulty they had was that they could not tell on what part of their works the mine was, or how great was its extension; and consequently they had stories such as that we published last week, that GRANT's mine extended under Petersburgh, and that he would suddenly send the whole town sky-high. In our own army there were very few men beside the engineers who constructed this mine, who knew of its existence; and only a few general officers were aware of its locality.

abstract: A Legitimate Prisoner of War
lead_paragraph: The strain in which some journals discuss the present position and future prospects of SEMMES, of the Alabama, is well calculated to make us objects of ridicule all over Europe. A few days ago the Washington correspondent of the Evening Post gravely announced that SEMMES' case was under consideration in that city; that his surrender would be demanded, but that the probabilities were that the British Government would deliver him up without waiting to be asked. This amusing story was, of course, strictly in keeping with an equally amusing editorial which preceded it by a few days in the same journal, desiring Mr. ADAMS to demand his passports if SEMMES were not handed over to him.

abstract: BURGLARY IN EAST NINETEENTH-STREET -- RECOVERY OF THE GOODS AND ARREST OF THE BURGLAR. -- The dwelling-house of Mr. EDWIN L. GODKIN, NO. 37 East Nineteenth-street, was entered on the night of the 28th instant by PATRICK LANE, an Irish lad, 17 years of age, who stole there from $419 worth of jewelry and clothing. The family, it appears, were all out of town at the time, and the burglar entered the house through the coal-hole. Officer FAWCELT, of the Eighteenth Precinct, made the arrest of LANE, who confessed his guilt and gave information which enabled the officers to recover a large portion of the goods. The accused plead guilty and was committed in the sum of $2000 by Justice DODGE.

abstract: Mulligan, Col James
lead_paragraph: The reports we have had regarding the wounding and death of the gallant Col. MULLIGAN are at last confirmed by the announcement of the arrival of his remains at Chicago. Col. MULLIGAN was born in the City of Utica, N.Y., in the year 1829, consequently was thirty-five years old at the time of his death. After the death of his father, which occurred when young MULLIGAN was but a child, his mother removed to Chicago. JAMES was educated at the University of St. Mary of the Lake, and in college, both with professors and with pupils, stood highest among the high. He was a Roman Catholic. He was, from boyhood to his death, a regular communicant of that church. In 1852. '53 and '54 he read law in the office of Hon. GRANT GOODRICH, and at the time of his admission to the bar was a student in the law office of Hon. ISAAC N. ARNOLD. After leaving college, and before entering on the study of law, he accompanied Mr. STEPHENS on one of his expeditions in Central America. In 1854 he edited, for a short time, a religious Roman Catholic weekly paper published in Chicago, called The Tablet, but in 1856 he commenced the practice of the law. He always had a taste for military life, and even while a law student he volunteered as a private in the Shields Guard, a company then organized in Chicago. In this company he was soon promoted to a Lieutenancy and afterward became Captain. In 1857-8 he desired to see life at the capitol, and through the kindness of Senator FITCH he was appointed by Mr. BUCHANAN to a clerkship in the Interior Department. He spent one Winter in Washington and saw enough. When the war broke out he was Captain of the Shields Guard and proposed to organize a regiment of Irishmen for the war. The regiment was raised, but others were elected to its command, he being given but a subordinate position. The supply of volunteers was so great that the State authorities could not accept it. MULLIGAN, however, was not to be repressed in that way. He obtained from Senator DOUGLAS, then on his death-bed, a letter to Secretary CAMBRON, who at once gave him authority to raise a regiment. He returned, and in a few weeks he succeeded in enlisting as fine a regimentas ever left Chicago; he was made Colonel, and was at once sent to Missouri. He left Chicago in June, 1861, and skirmished his way up to Lexington, which point it was deemed important to hold. He had with him, besides his own regiment, a regiment of Illinois cavalry armed with cutlasses, and a regiment of Missouri "Home Guards." PRICE, with his 15,000 troops, soon surrounded Lexington, demanding its surrender. For five or six days the heroic Bommander maintained the unequal contest, and it was not until he had neither ammunition, water nor food that the demand for surrender was compiled with. The officers and men were paroled, and allowed to return; MULLIGAN, however, refused a parole, and being joined by his wife and babe, was carried off as a prisoner by PRICE, who treated him with the most marked kindness and respect Early in November he was exchanged for Gen. FROST, and on his arrival in Chicago was honored with a magnificent ovation. In the Spring following he was ordered to Western Virginia, where he has since served in various capacities faithfully and gallantly, at times discharging the duties of a Major-General, while holding the rank of Colonel. Once he declined promotion to a Brigadiership unless he could take his old regiment with him, and lately the prejudices of some of those high in office have stood in the way of his preferment.

abstract: The last steamer from Europe brought several expensive luxuries to MAX MARETZEK, in the shape of contracts for the coming season. We are glad to hear that our empresario's arrangements are now completed. He of all the New-York managers, is the first in the field.
lead_paragraph: The last steamer from Europe brought several expensive luxuries to MAX MARETZEK, in the shape of contracts for the coming season. We are glad to hear that our empresario's arrangements are now completed. He of all the New-York managers, is the first in the field. It must not be supposed, however, that he will also be the first to open. The regular theatres commence operations in September, when hungry provincials do most abound. The opera being for a more select class, has to wait until that class returns from the watering-places, the hilltops, and the pleasant vallies. Hence the season will not commence until October.

lead_paragraph: THE WEATHER. -- Yesterday was another of those fearfully hot days which severally try the temper of even the best-natured people. Gentlemen of 200 lbs. and over were looked upon by their fellow-mortals as objects of pity. Vapor baths were indulged in by many at the cheap price of five and six cents, the difference being in the choice of stage or car. At five o'clock in the morning, the thermometer marked over 70°, and the sky assumed that brassy appearance which always precedes an extremely hot day. At 6 o'clock, the mercury at DELATOUR's, in Wall-street, stood at 77°, and at noon at 91°. It is to be hoped, for the benefit of the poor jaded animals in the City, that the clerk of the weather will not favor us with many such days.

abstract: The Action at
lead_paragraph: The attempt on the lines of Petereburgh on Saturday did not result in a success. It was an effort whose success or failure must occur at once, and must at once be apparent. It was of the nature of a coup de main, or a sudden effort or enterprise, which, though it might embrace many parts and much laborious preparation, must necessarily come to a conclusion very quickly after it was fairly got under way.

abstract: The high estimate of the services of United States sailors entertained by the Government once more results in the sending of sailors to the battlefield. Within a few days the different receiving-ships at the Navy-yards have contributed to the fleets and batteries of Virginia, the magnitude of which cannot be stated. The United States steam transport Newbern, the regular supply-ship of the North Atlantic blockading squadron, left here on Saturday with a large number, and hundreds have been probably dispatched since. Those who were forwarded to Baltimore during the existence of the late rebel raid, had, we believe, all returned, and the experience gained by them during their brief stay in Maryland will certainly improve their abilities.

lead_paragraph: It is worthy of notice that the first brigade to enter the Petersburgh fort after the explosion was the Forteenth New-York Heavy Artillery, the Second brigade of LEDLIE's division, commanded by Col. ELISHA G. MARSHALL. This brigade also stormed the rifle-pits before Petersburgh, and bore an important part in the successful assault on the second line of rebel works. It is now found again at the post of honor and of danger. Col. MARSHALL, acting-brigadies, is a native of New-York, and was educated at West Point.

abstract: Charges and Specifications Against
lead_paragraph: In this City, recruiting, for the past few days has been remarkably dull. The new barracks on the Battery, which were expected to do a very lively business have done little or nothing, and Supervisor BLUNT and his assistants have been rendered almost desperate for want of something to do. That there must be some peculiar cause for this sudden falling off was evident to all. That cause has been discovered, and it is to be hoped, removed.

abstract: DEATH BY FALLING OUT OF A WINDOW. Coroner NORRIS held an inquest on JOHN T. MATHEWS, who died of injuries sustained by falling from a window of the house of PATRICK CARNEY, corner of Atlantic and Flatbush avenues, on the night of the 26th  ult. MATHEWS had secured a substitute and took  him to CARNEY'S house for safe keeping till morning.
lead_paragraph: DEATH BY FALLING OUT OF A WINDOW. -- Coroner NORRIS held an inquest on JOHN T. MATHEWS, who died of injuries sustained by falling from a window of the house of PATRICK CARNEY, corner of Atlantic and Flatbush avenues, on the night of the 26th ult. MATHEWS had secured a substitute and took him to CARNEY's house for safe keeping till morning. During the evening they imbibed frequently, and CANNEY threatened to eject MATHEWS from the house for some improper expressions in regard to his daughter; MATHEWS, in order to get out of the way went to the window, and either jumped or fell out, no one being near him at the time. He was picked up and taken to the City Hospital by Officer MOWBRAY, where, a few days subsequently, he died. The jury rendered the verdict that deceased came to his death from injuries sustained by accidentally falling from the window, and CARNEY, who had been arrested, was discharged from custody.

abstract: From Petersburgh our news is not of the success anticipated. After the explosion, at an early hour on Saturday morning, everything betokened a brilliant victory; but by the failure of the colored troops to carry out their part of the programme, affairs began to wear a different aspect.
lead_paragraph: From Petersburgh our news is not of the success anticipated. After the explosion, at an early hour on Saturday morning, everything betokened a brilliant victory; but by the failure of the colored troops to carry out their part of the programme, affairs began to wear a different aspect. The explosion of the mine, which was delayed beyond the appointed time, took place precisely at 4:40 o'clock, and the roar of artillery which immediately followed is said to have been indescribably grand. At 5:30 the charge was made, and the fort, with a portion of the line on each side, was carried in the most gallant manner. The second line, a short distance beyond the fort, was also attempted; but at this critical moment the colored troops, which had advanced in good order to the first line, wavered and broke under a galling fire. They were rallied and again pushed forward, but without success, most of their officers being killed or wounded. Their losses were very severe. Their struggle continued for some time, but the rebels had such great advantage that the highest efforts were unavailing. The reserve were not ordered to advance, and our troops fell back as best they could. Our losses in the affair have been estimated as high as four or five thousand.

abstract: Decline of Assistant Treasuryship; Service; Unwillingness of Wealthy Men to Enter
snippet: Decline of Assistant Treasuryship; Service; Unwillingness of Wealthy Men to Enter
lead_paragraph: The refusal of Mr. MOSES TAYLOR to accept the place of Assistant Treasurer offered him by Secretary FESSENDEN, owing, we believe, to his unwillingness to withdraw his attention from the various private enterprizes in which he is engaged, suggests one or two considerations, possessing just now a great deal of interest. There is no man of intelligence and patriotism at the North who does not acknowledge that Government is not only one of the most important of human pursuits, but that too much talent, integrity, learning, experience and wisdom, cannot be brought to it, and that the happiness of nations and the progress of mankind in civilization is in the highest degree dependent on the manner in which it is carried on. And there is nobody who acknowledges this, who will not also acknowledge that, like all other arts, it has to be acquired by the usual mixture of study and practice, that it needs much knowledge and much experience, and the entire devotion of his time and attention to it to enable any man to succeed in it. To be well done, therefore, the work of Government has to be made the business, the whole and sole business, of some class or other. It can no more be carried on successfully by men whose training and pursuits draw them away half the time in other directions, than the profession of the law or of medicine. In England and the South, the class which takes up Government as a calling, has been and is the aristocracy of birth and wealth; and nobody can deny that, in both places, the ideas of the end and aim of Government, held by this class, have been admirably carried out. Their theory of the best form of polity, and of the great objects of political institutions, differ widely from ours; but it is impossible to deny that, such as it is, it has been properly practiced. The problem before them has been to construct and perpetuate, under given conditions, the strongest form of oligarchy; and the world knows what skill, courage, tenacity, and fertility of resource, they have brought to its solution.

abstract: Coroner RANNEY held an inquest yesterday on the body of MICHAEL CRANE, at the Sixteenth Precinct in Tenth-avenue, near Twenty-sixth-street. The testimony in the case showed about the same state of facts as published in the TIMES of yesterday.
lead_paragraph: Coroner RANNEY held an inquest yesterday on the body of MICHAEL CRANE, at the Sixteenth Precinct in Tenth-avenue, near Twenty-sixth-street. The testimony in the case showed about the same state of facts as published in the TIMES of yesterday. The affray commenced in a lager-beer saloon, corner of Tenth-avenue and Twenty-seventh-street, growing out of an attempt by one of the men to pass a coun-Station-house, the man who was shot on Sunday night, terfeit fifty cent note in payment for some drinks. The disturbance at length became so great that the police bad to interfere when the rowdies made an attack upon them, and beat them severely. One or two of the offenders were, however, taken to the station-house and locked up. Some of the prisoners' friends became highly exasperated at these arrests, and continued their disorderly conduct along the street, when two policemen, who were returning to their posts, undertook to preserve order. In their attempts to secure the offenders, the officers were, some of them, knocked down and beaten with stones and other missiles. During the melee six or eight pistol shots were fired, but by whom, did not transpire. CRANE, the deceased, was shot twice, and wounded so severely that he died while being conveyed to the station-house soon after.

In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: -- A correspondent writes us suggesting the propriety of country postmasters obtaining subscriptions to the new seven-thirty loan, called for by Secretary FESSENDEN. There are thousands of small towns and villages where there are no bankers, and where the postmasters are in continual intercourse with a large class of small capitalists, who hoard money, not having the knowledge or convenience to make a profitable and patriotic investment of it. It would be a fine way to make it a people's loan. There are many other obvious reasons, which make this course a very wise, necessary and effective one to pursue.

abstract: If there is any one class of men who, at this time, deserved to be remembered by our benevolent citizens, it is the noble sailors who are now stationed on the coast of South Carolina and on the Mississippi River. The weather there is, at this season, very oppressive and disastrous to health and life, and this year even worse than usual. We have now stationed in these latitudes perhaps 8,000 sailors and marines who are deprived, to a great extent, of what we at home think the necessaries of life. And going kept so long a time aboard ship and away from home, they have no means of getting any of these comforts except such as are sent to them by friends.

abstract: The, in Missouri
lead_paragraph: The bush whackers or brigands who have appeared in such numerous and formidable bands throughout Missouri during the Summer months, and who have threatened to reduce the whole of that rich State to a desolation, are likely henceforth to be promptly and effectively dealt with. Gen. ROSECRANS has called for ten regiments of volunteers to operate against them, and Gen. FISK, commanding in Northwest Missouri, has called upon "five thousand true and loyal men, with each a horse and such arms as they may have or can procure, and ammunition therefor, to rally for the protection of life and property and the extermination of the Confederate guerrilla fiends that infest Northwest Missouri." The Governor of the State has issued a proclamation to the people, appealing to them to respond promptly and with alacrity to the call of Gen. ROSECRANS. If the volunteers called for are not quickly furnished, he will draft a sufficient militia force for the purpose, and that militia force, he says, "cannot be paid, for the reason that the State has not sufficient means for the purpose." In the appeal of Gen. FISK, which does not interfere with that of Gen. ROSECRANS, a terrible picture is given of the doings of the "robbers and murderers who are spreading death and desolation in their bloody pathway," and he urges loyal men to promptly respond to this call for their "swift and sure destruction."
headline: {'main': 'The Guerrillas in Missouri.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Guerrillas in Missouri.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: This Society held its last session for the season at its rooms, Society Library, July 28, DAVID T. VALENTINE. Esq., was unanimously elected an honorary member, and Mr. ISAAC J. GREENWOOD, Jr., chosen to fill the vacancy of Second Vice-President, Various special committees reported favorably. Mr. HANNA, Chairman of Committee on Printing, announced that the new constitution and by-laws were in the hands of the printer and would be ready for distribution in a few weeks. By the adoption, within the past few months, of the new constitution, the society has introduced various long-contemplated improvements into its code, and enlarged its name and sphere to a corresponding degree or usefulness that is already giving promise of great success.

abstract: Immigration; An Act to Encourage
lead_paragraph: Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, That the President of the United States is hereby authorized, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate, to appoint a Commissioner of Immigration, who shall be subject to the direction of the Department of State, shall hold his office for four years, and shall receive a salary at the rate of $2,500 a year. The said Commissioner may employ not more than three clerks, of such grade as the Secretary of State shall designate, to be appointed by him, with the approval of the Secretary of State, and to hold their offices at his pleasure.
headline: {'main': 'An Act to Encourage Immigration.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'An Act to Encourage Immigration.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: --The copperheads, who for two years accused President LINCOLN of interfering with army operations, and abused him therefor, seem now to be clamorous that he should take the active control of all military movements over the entire surface of the Union. They assault him because the rebels are in the Shenandoah Valley, and demand that he shall drive them out. They assail him because the rebels are raiding in Pennsylvania, and insist that he shall instantly expel them. They accuse him of causing a repulse to our arms at Atlanta on the 22d, and are not afraid to say that he is responsible for the failure before Petersburgh last Saturday. In the same breath they find fault with the President for formerly interfering in military matters, and because now he does not seem to interfere with them.
lead_paragraph: --The copperheads, who for two years accused President LINCOLN of interfering with army operations, and abused him therefor, seem now to be clamorous that he should take the active control of all military movements over the entire surface of the Union. abstract: DUMMIES IN JERSEY CITY. -- A few weeks since the Common Council of Jersey City adopted an ordinance prohibiting the running of dummy engine cars within the limits after August 1. Subsequently, the board extended the time of running the cars six months, but it failed to become a law, in consequence of having been vetoed by the Mayor. Consequently, since Monday morning, the dummy cars from Bergen Point have ceased running in Jersey City.
lead_paragraph: DUMMIES IN JERSEY CITY. -- A few weeks since the Common Council of Jersey City adopted an ordinance prohibiting the running of dummy engine cars within the limits after August 1. abstract: DEATH BY SUN-STROKE. -- Yesterday forenoon an unknown man, about forty years of age, was overcome by the heat in South Sixth-street, (Eastern District). He was conveyed to the house of Mr. G. VALE, where he died in about an hour. The man is apparently a native of England, is about five feet six inches in height, brown hair and red whiskers. He had on linen coat and pants, no vest, congress gaiters, and mixed socks.

abstract: An election was held throughout the State, today, on three amendments to the State Constitution, the first being in favor of soldiers voting. A comparatively small vote was polled, and it is believed, from the returns thus far received in this city, that all the amendments have been carried. But few returns have yet been received from the interior, but they indicate the same result.

abstract: SUN-STROKES. -- CHAS. EVANS, aged about 35 years, was found by Officer MURRAY, of the Fifth Precinct, in Washington-street, near Duane, prostrated by the heat. He was conveyed to the New-York Hospital....JANE ANDREWS was found in a helpless condition, by reason of the heat, on the sidewalk in West Broadway, near Thomas-street, and taken to the New-York Hospital....JOHN SINGER, aged 61 years, residing at No. 486 Ninth-avenue, was prostrated by the heat, at the corner of that avenue and Thirty-seventh-street. He was so much affected that no hopes are entertained of his recovery.

abstract: This morning the troops across the river, under Gen. FOSTER'S command, captured, almost by surprise, and with little loss, a four-gun battery. The discharge of cannon was pretty lively for a few minutes, and then came volleys of musketry. Last night all left in camp were again called to the breastworks, expecting an attack, but we on picket saw no signs of it.

abstract: the Infested
lead_paragraph: The public here have been struggling for several days against being driven to the belief that this invasion disorder in Upper Maryland and Southwestern Pennsylvania has become chronic. It is not the mere wantonness of the rebel forays -- at a score of different places of a night -- nor the deliberateness with which a succession of villages are laid possession of, stores gutted and whole streets given to the flames, nor the harvest of greenbacks gathered up in the shape of levies, nor even the insolence with which a contemptible squad of two or three hundred rebel freebooters wheel round and round those bodies of troops which are supposed to be in pursuit of them, that would lead us to regard the border trouble as endemic. It is rather the attitude of the border people themselves. It is that stoical indifference which, up to a certain point, holds absolute possession of them, and which is, anon, succeeded by a wild and feverish turmoil, in which reason and common sense are entirely lost.
headline: {'main': 'The Infested Border States.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Infested Border States.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Yesterday was a busy day for Lieut. WRIGHT and his aids in the office of the Military Prison The rebels fairly besieged the premises. Before night, however, the dense mass of grayback humanity, which crowded and jammed the streets in the neighborhood. were all started on their journey northward, leaving the vicinity as quiet and placid as if nothing unusual had transpired. It is understood there are about eleven hundred more prisoners en route from the front, who are expected here every honr.

abstract: WALLACK'S THEATRE. Mr. BOUCICAULT'S drama of the "Colleen Bawn" is certainly one of the best of that gentleman's many excellent productions. Its revival at any time is sure to attract a fair degree of attention, and what is better, to merit it. We owe the work in the present instance to Mr. DAN BRYANT, who last evening assumed the rule of Miles-na-Coppaleen for the first time.
lead_paragraph: WALLACK's THEATRE. -- Mr. BOUCICAULT's drama of the "Colleen Bawn" is certainly one of the best of that gentleman's many excellent productions. Its revival at any time is sure to attract a fair degree of attention, and what is better, to merit it. We owe the work in the present instance to Mr. DAN BRYANT, who last evening assumed the rule of Miles-na-Coppaleen for the first time. It is by no means a stereotyped Irish part. Mr. BOUCICAULT created it for himself, and was careful to introduce into it many niceties of personality which could hardly be intrusted to the average stage Irishman. The best points of the part are quiet and subtle, and they were always rendered exquisitely by the dramatist. Mr. BRYANT has many of the qualities that are needed in the formation of such a character, and although not quite at ease in it, and altogether too respectable in his "deportment," was decidedly acceptable, inasmuch as overacting reduces Miles to the condition of a bore. The gentleman appeared to be somewhat hoarse last evening, and is, we are sorry to learn, in such poor health, that the opportunities of seeing him will terminate with the present week.

abstract: Harker, Gen--Gen Howard's Letter
lead_paragraph: Gen. HARKER, who lately fell before Atlanta, was a native of New-Jersey, but entered the volunteer army from the regulars, as Colonel of the Sixty-fifth Ohio, early in 1861. He was about twenty-six years of age. A Western correspondent writes of him: There are many left who will long mourn his loss. Poor HARKER was the most noble and true man I ever knew. We had been intimately associated for nearly three years. Magnanimous and pure at heart, he was the bravest of the brave. By nature he was apparently effeminate, being truly kind and good, and too modest to make himself conspicuous except in battle, when, as if by magic, he at once became a lion and king. In the death of the noble HARKER our country lost one of her brightest stars.

abstract: in general rant about the failure of our army; but they should beware of specifications. Fustian is not only easier in itself, but it is hard of dissection. One of their organs in this City, in declaiming yesterday on the failure of our military efforts generally, ventured to say grandiloquently: "The Mississippi River we hold in name, but no keel of commerce vexes its guerrilla-haunted waters." Now, for a year past, the entire Mississippi River -- including the thousand miles from Cairo to the Delta -- has been ceaselessly traversed by commercial steamers, and a very large general traffic has been carried on. Not one vessel in ten of the scores that pass to and fro between New-Orleans, Vicksburgh, Memphis and the ports above, has been fired upon by guerrillas, and not one in fifty has ever been seriously damaged.

abstract: It was the custom of the Parsees, we believe, when they met discomfiture in war, to offer up a common supplication for forgiveness, to the Sun; as their faith led them to conclude that any reverse they sustained bore an immediate and direct relation to some special iniquity they had committed. Our Christian Fasts, we suppose, imply no such literal interpretation of the inscrutable purposes of Heaven.
lead_paragraph: It was the custom of the Parsees, we believe, when they met discomfiture in war, to offer up a common supplication for forgiveness, to the Sun; as their faith led them to conclude that any reverse they sustained bore an immediate and direct relation to some special iniquity they had committed. Our Christian Fasts, we suppose, imply no such literal interpretation of the inscrutable purposes of Heaven. Our national days of worship and confession, we take it, are simply a formal public acknowledgment of the Supreme Wisdom, whether evil or good has befallen us. Some one has said that divine things reduced to our balance lose their weight; and it is not the business of a Christian community, at least, to take either failures or reverses in the battle-field or elsewhere, as tokens of signal favor or special reproof from the Providence that overrules us. The President, in quoting in his Proclamation the admirable concurrent resolution of both Houses of Congress, gives a [???]ous comprehensive and felicitous statement of the individual and national,, temporary and everlasting, boons to be craved from Heaven by the whole people of the land to-day. We shall implore the compassion and forgiveness of the Almighty -- implore Him, as the Supreme Ruler of the world, not to destroy us as a people, or suffer us to be destroyed by the hostility [???] connivance of other nations, or by obstinate adhesion to our own counsels, which may be in conflict with His eternal purposes, -- implore Him to enlighten the mind of the nation to know and do His will, humbly believing that it is in accordance with His will that our place should be maintained as a united people among the family of nations; implore him to grant to our armed defenders courage and endurance, and implore him to soften the hearts of those in rebellion that they be not utterly destroyed, and that unity and fraternity be restored. To ask these blessing, all the heads of the Executive Departments of this Government, together with all legislators, all Judges and Magistrates and all other persons exercising authority in the land, whether civil, military or naval, and all soldiers, seamen and mariners in the national service, and all other loyal and law-abiding people of the United States, are invited by the President.

abstract: COTTON -- The sales in the Liverpool market for the week foot up 88,000 bales. The market was quiet but firm, at an advance 1/[???]d.@ 1/2d. for American. The sales to speculators were 7,500 bales, and to exporters 9,000. The sales on the day of the sailing of the St. David were 7,000 bales, of which speculators and exporters took 2,000, the market closing quiet but unchanged. The following are the authorized quotations: Midling Orleans, 31 3/4 d.; Middling Mobiles, 31 1/2d.; Middling Uplands, 31 1/4d. The stock in port was 185,000 bales, of which 4,000 were American.

abstract: Armistice, The; with German Powers
lead_paragraph: which we receive by the Bremen's mail respecting the cessation of hostilities between the Danes and Germans, confirm the previous intelligence of the probability of a permanent settlement being effected by the admission of Denmark into the German Federation. The Copenhagen Government has addressed its proposals direct to Berlin and Vienna, and the truce which had been agreed to was to last from the 20th to the 30th of July. A feeble protest is put forward by a non-official Paris journal against the the projected enlargement of the German Confederation, and it may be that this protest is a premonitory hint of the view which the Emperor's Government takes of the situation in its latest bearings. But it is not easy to see wherein there should lie an objection to the voluntary union of Denmark with Germany, which would not lie against the conquest of Denmark, and its absorption by the great German Powers -- an issue to which the Emperor, by his silence at the Conference, made himself practically a consenting party.

abstract: There is no news of importance from the front. On Wednesday a flag of truce was allowed by the rebels from 9 A.M. until 5 P.M. to bury the dead and bring off the wounded.
lead_paragraph: There is no news of importance from the front. On Wednesday a flag of truce was allowed by the rebels from 9 A.M. until 5 P.M. to bury the dead and bring off the wounded. Very few were found alive, but the ground in front of the crater for a distance of about two hundred yards was thickly covered with the dead, the greater proportion being colored. The season of this disparity is the fact that the fire from the rebel guns, on both flanks, was concentrated upon this ground, after the white troops had charged across it; and when the colored division crossed the spot, they were mowed down with grape and canister, and when they retreated they fell in dozens, our sharpshooters being unable to disturb the rebel gunners. According to the statement of our special correspondent, the rebels, while claiming a victory, admit a loss of 3,000.

abstract: Editor Bergen County Democrat, Arrested for Resisting Draft
snippet: Editor Bergen County Democrat, Arrested for Resisting Draft
lead_paragraph: Mr. EBEN WINTON, editor and publisher of the Bergen County Democrat, was arrested on Saturday last under a warrant issued by United States Commissioner WHITEHEAD, under Section 25 of the Enrollment Act, for counseling resistance to the draft. The matter was called to the attention of the United States District-Attorney, in this city, by Maj.-Gen. PECK, commanding the Department of the East in the absence of Gen. Dix. Mr. WINTON was subsequently arrested, but there being no United States Commissioner in town at the time he appeared here, he was released on his parole till Tuesday morning. Mr. WINTON was attended by Mr. HOOSMAN and other citizens of Bergen County, who volunteered the necessary security for his appearance at the United States District Court in Trenton next September. This arrest, like that of Mr. FULLER, of the Journal, was made by the civil authorities, and not by the military, but on information received from the latter.

abstract: Capt. H.P. WEST, Provost-Marshal of the Fifth District, yesterday arrested a fellow calling himself FRANCIS STEWART, on a charge of attempting to defraud JOSEPH LUTTENCHLAGER, of No. 472 Broome-street, of $200. STEWART had procured a shield, and represented himself to be a United States detective, and, under threats of arrest, endeavored to swindle LUTTENCHLAGER out of the above amount. These facts coming to the knowledge of Capt. WEST, he so arranged his plans as to catch STEWART in the act. When arrested, he acknowledged his guilt. He was locked up for trial.

abstract: We have already given a full summary of the news brought by the Bremen, and have to add this morning only a few items of particular interest. The murderer of Mr. BRIGGS, the man who was lately murdered in a first-class railway car near London, turns out to be a Mr. FRANZ MULLER, who left in a sailing vessel, several days before the crime had been traced to him. An Admiralty steamer immediately started for this City with English detectives on board, and it is supposed in London that they will reach this port before the ship in which the murderer sailed. The Alexandra, about which so much discussion has taken place in the Court of Queen's Bench, left the Mersey on Sunday, July 17, for Nassau, with a general cargo of merchandise. The name of the vessel has been changed, and she is now called the Mary; and it is said that she is to be a trader between the Mersey and Nassau. The Paris correspondent of the London Times says that the intelligence from the wheat growing districts is not unfavorable. A dispatch from Vienna of July 16, says: "The proposals of Denmark, addressed direct to the courts of Berlin and Vienna, have been met on the part of Austria and Prussia by a suspension of arms on land and sea until July 31, during which period the blockade will be raised. The German Powers have added the request that Denmark will immediately send Plenipotentiaries to Vienna in order to come to an understanding with Austria and Prussia relative to the basis of peace." GARIBALDI, who appears to be in poor health, left Ischia July 19 for Caprera. His reception by the public was very enthusiastic. The steamship St. David, from Liverpool on the 21st, via Londonderry on the 22d of July, was signaled yesterday off Father Point. Her dates are two days later than those by the Bremen. The Africa, with four days later news, arrived yesterday at Cape Race. The Richmond correspondent of the London Times compares GRANT to the Russian Gen. SUWARROW. He thinks his chances of success very small, and declares that Gen. LEE has inflicted upon him a loss of 15,000 men in the battle of June 1. The French Government has invited the European Powers to an International Congress next Autumn, to regulate telegraphic communications in Europe.
lead_paragraph: We have already given a full summary of the news brought by the Bremen, and have to add this morning only a few items of particular interest. The murderer of Mr. BRIGGS, the man who was lately murdered in a first-class railway car near London, turns out to be a Mr. FRANZ MULLER, who left in a sailing vessel, several days before the crime had been traced to him. An Admiralty steamer immediately started for this City with English detectives on board, and it is supposed in London that they will reach this port before the ship in which the murderer sailed. The Alexandra, about which so much discussion has taken place in the Court of Queen's Bench, left the Mersey on Sunday, July 17, for Nassau, with a general cargo of merchandise. The name of the vessel has been changed, and she is now called the Mary; and it is said that she is to be a trader between the Mersey and Nassau. The Paris correspondent of the London Times says that the intelligence from the wheat growing districts is not unfavorable. A dispatch from Vienna of July 16, says: "The proposals of Denmark, addressed direct to the courts of Berlin and Vienna, have been met on the part of Austria and Prussia by a suspension of arms on land and sea until July 31, during which period the blockade will be raised. The German Powers have added the request that Denmark will immediately send Plenipotentiaries to Vienna in order to come to an understanding with Austria and Prussia relative to the basis of peace." GARIBALDI, who appears to be in poor health, left Ischia July 19 for Caprera. His reception by the public was very enthusiastic. The steamship St. David, from Liverpool on the 21st, via Londonderry on the 22d of July, was signaled yesterday off Father Point. Her dates are two days later than those by the Bremen. The Africa, with four days later news, arrived yesterday at Cape Race. The Richmond correspondent of the London Times compares GRANT to the Russian Gen. SUWARROW. He thinks his chances of success very small, and declares that Gen. LEE has inflicted upon him a loss of 15,000 men in the battle of June 1. The French Government has invited the European Powers to an International Congress next Autumn, to regulate telegraphic communications in Europe.

abstract: SEEKING DANGER. A cow, made wild by being driven through the streets, found refuge in the Park for a while, yesterday, in one of the inclosures of sward. The sight of a noisy crowd that gathered ...
lead_paragraph: SEEKING DANGER. -- A cow, made wild by being driven through the streets, found refuge in the Park for a while, yesterday, in one of the inclosures of sward. The sight of a noisy crowd that gathered along the chains increased her wildness, and for the safely of the over-curious, those who evidently wanted to provoke the animal to an interesting and exciting degree of phrenzy, the police captured and removed it, amid considerable commotion by the spectators. This incident is a lesson upon the impropriety of permitting cattle to be driven through the streets, a practice that City Inspector BOOLE has again and again condemned.

abstract: Yesterday thirty-five more Yankee prisoners were received at the Libby from Deep Bottom, where they were captured. One commissioned officer, Lieut. J.G. SEDGWICK, Twentieth Massachusetts, was among them. Fifteen out of the thirty-five were Germans, being part of a lot of three hundred enlisted by Yankee agents in Germany and just arrived in this country. The plainest word in the English vocabulary was a jaw-breaker to the best of them. "Yah!" was the highest approach to an English alphabetical sound that could be gotten out of any of them, and "Yah" they grunted like so many pigs while their names were being recorded. -- Examiner.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamer Roanoke at this port yesterday, we have news from Havana to the 29th, and from Mexico to the 23d ult. There had been fighting about a league's distance from San Martin, between the French and the Juarest men.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamer Roanoke at this port yesterday, we have news from Havana to the 29th, and from Mexico to the 23d ult. There had been fighting about a league's distance from San Martin, between the French and the Juarest men. The Imperialists were attacked by a force of about 500. The result is not given. There had also been some fighting going on in the district of Vera Cruz, which shows that even in the provinces which have been the longest occupied by the French the spirit of resistance still exists in a tangible form. MAXIMILIAN has granted "an amnesty to all prisoners whose offences were strictly political." There is a large class, however, of Juarist men who are classed under the name of "Banditti," and to whom the amnesty will not extend. The Imperialists and Republicans have had several engagements in the Sierra Hermosa. An English Company had undertaken to finish the railroad from Vera Cruz to the Capital. MAXIMILIAN has ordered the French military code to be introduced. Baron GROX, ex-Envoy of Belgium, had died at the Capital.

abstract: The Duty of
lead_paragraph: There can be no doubt that the mass of the people are pouring forth everything -- lives and means -- for the successful termination of this war. But is Capital doing the duty of the hour? Are our rich men straining every nerve to help the Government in its two great wants for the present moment -- men and money? A reserve of three hundred thousand men ought to be formed this Autumn, and must be obtained, if we hope to see Gen. GRANT's campaign successful. It should be raised with the least possible strain on the resources of the community.

abstract: Rebel Losses at
lead_paragraph: All accounts, official and unofficial, agree as to the vast losses suffered by the rebel army at Atlanta, in the late assaults upon our positions. They were as much greater in proportion to ours, as our losses were greater than the rebels in our recent assaults upon their works in Virginia, at Spottsylvania, Cold Harbor and Petersburgh. The conditions between the two combatants were reversed in the West and in the East. In the West it was the rebels who assaulted, and our troops were, to some extent, enabled to throw up their lines of works, from behind which they poured their fire into the enemy's ranks. We had, the other day, a telegraphic abstract of an official statement made by Gen. THOMAS upon this matter, of which to-day we give the text. Gen. THOMAS is too cool and careful an old soldier to indulge in any misapprehensions upon this subject. He vouches for the statement that, in the battle of the 22d ult., the total Union loss in killed, wounded and missing was 1,733, while the rebel loss was over 6,000 -- the main portion of their dead being buried by our troops.

abstract: A dispatch from Bucharest of July 17, says: "The principal modifications of the Constitution mutually agreed upon between Prince COUZA and the Porte have been published to-day. In reference to the Constitution of the Senate, it was determined that the Senators directly appointed by the Prince are to possess a yearly income of 800 ducats, while a yearly income of 200 ducats is necessary for elegibility to the Chamber of Deputies. It is, however, reserved for the Chamber of Deputies, at their first sitting, definitely to decide upon this qualification."

abstract: RECRUITING IN BROOKLYN. -- The naval rendezvous in York-street is doing a brisk business in recruiting men for the navy. On Tuesday ninety-two presented themselves, and yesterday about the same number -- more than could be examined and passed. The clerical force of the office has been increased in consequence of the large amount of business. Provost-Marshal FOWLER is equally busy, it having been found necessary to procure the appointment of an additional Surgeon to aid in the examination of substitutes.

abstract: The President of the United States having set apart THURSDAY, THE FOURTH INST., for National Fasting, Humiliation and Prayer, I, HORATIO SEYMOUR, Governor of the State of New-York, do recommend that the day be observed throughout this State with suitable religious solemnities. Let us repent of our manifold sins and offences, and humbly pray that Almighty God will put down all rebellious resistance to righful authority; all sectional hatred; all bigotry and malice; all brutal ambition or partisan purposes which tend to discord and strife. That He will restore the Union of our States and fraternal affection between the inhabitants thereof, and give peace to our land. Acknowledging the justtice of His punishment for our national and personal sins, let us entreat Him to have mercy upon us, to turn away his wrath, to stop the shedding of blood, to return our soldiers to their homes, to relieve the sick, wounded and suffering, to comfort those in mourning; to reward the industry of our people; to relieve them from heavy burdens, to make them safe in their persons and homes from all violence and oppression, and to give the protection of law to all conditions of men. To these ends let us pray that God will give wisdom to our rulers, purity to our legislators, uprightness and boldness to our judges, meekness and charity to our clergy, and virtue, intelligence and godliness to our people.

abstract: -- ARREST OF THE MURDERER IN CANADA. -- Last Wednesday evening, July 22, Mr. JAMES WARD, a wealthy and prominent citizen of Niles, Ohio, was shot down dead in the street by FRANK O. ROBBINS. The latter had been paying illicit visits to a married woman named STEVENSON, living in a house of Mr. WARD's, and she had been warned by the latter to leave the premises. To wreak revenge upon Mr. WARD, the guilty pair, both heavily armed, were on their way to his house, but meeting his son, they attacked and beat him severely and Mr. W. coming to the rescue, ROBBINS drew a pistol and shot him through the head.

abstract: There is no intelligence of much importance from either of our main armies. From before Petersburgh, we learn only that the rebels are busily engaged in repairing their lines, and that our skirmishers annoy them as much as possible --doing them little damage, however, as they perform most of their labor at night. A Court of Inquiry is about to be convened to inquire into the causes of the late disaster. The exact number of our losses in the action of Saturday is now ascertained to have been 5,640.
lead_paragraph: There is no intelligence of much importance from either of our main armies. abstract: Brigandage on the
lead_paragraph: We search in vain, either in the reports of our special reporters or in the correspondence of the Philadelphia journals, for any evidence to show that this last raid on the Pennsylvania border has in any place or at any moment attained proportions beyond the control of a local mounted police. We see nothing in any one of the freebooters' exploits, or in the aim of these exploits, which represents the military organization of the public enemy. We find small bands of well-drilled brigands, acting as independently of the main rebel force as if the scene of their adventures were Northwestern Missouri or New-Mexico, instead of the Cumberland Valley. We find them engaged in nothing that can be said to rise to the dignity of warlike enterprise. What railroads have they destroyed? What bridges burnt? What public stores have they laid hold on? Where have they sought to make anything approaching to the semblance of a military assault? Destroying railroads, bridges, public stores, or even making such haphazard assaults upon passing trains as that at Gunpowder Bridge, may come properly into the category of military enterprises. They do more or less to diminish facilities of communication. They serve to delay the concentration of troops. They injure the commissariat. Or they run a chance of making such valuable captures as that of Gen. FRANKLIN. Coming with these intents, they have usually a responsible leadership, and we give them a consideration which is not extended to mere bushwhackers or prowling thieves. We see in their very mode of doing business that their operations are part of a well-considered plan; that their relations are immediate and direct to the main invading force, and that they are worth the attention, at least, of whatever portion of the regular cavalry force can be spared.

abstract: Our military correspondent at Washington has already made the observation, that the next phase of the Virginia campaign will appear, not near Richmond, but in the neighborhood of the Upper Potomac.
lead_paragraph: Our military correspondent at Washington has already made the observation, that the next phase of the Virginia campaign will appear, not near Richmond, but in the neighborhood of the Upper Potomac. We incline to the same opinion; still, in a matter so uncertain, and dependent on unknown combinations of Gen. GRANT's strategy, it is difficult to form any positive judgment. But it is apparent on both sides that 20,000 or 30,000 men can hold the respective capitals, behind scientifically planned intrenchments, against the whole force of either army, unless the regular approaches of a siege be made. Therefore the rebels can, during any short interval of time -say two or three months -- leave Richmond almost out of view, and we equally Washington. There are, it is true, combinations always possible with a General like GRANT, which make it dangerous to have a weak force in front of him. Mining attacks may not always fail. He may suddenly, before a weakened enemy, transfer great masses of his army entirely to the rear of Richmond and attack it, as he did Vicksburgh; or he may make another attempt on the north of the James, or, in fine, he may try some new expedient which no one has thought of. The enemy must calculate on this, and take the risk of it. We are convinced that they will do so. War is a game of risks, and they have never shown themselves unwilling to accept its chances.

abstract: -A few days before the late rebel raid, a Copperhead sympathizer with treason and traitors named WM. MCSPARREN, residing in Peabhbottom Township, York County, was neatly entrapped by some Union citizens residing in the neighborhood. These citizens knew of the proclivities of this man MCSPARREN, and had been informed that he was willing to give the rebels all the information in his possession, should the rebels attempt a raid into Lancaster County. In order to test the correctness of their information, they disguised themselves in rebel attire -- burning the graybacks -- and presented themselves at MCSPARREN's house. Introducing themselves as the special friends of JEFF. DAVIS, they were most hospitably received and generously entertained. The best the hoose afforded was placed at their disposal, and over the dinner table MCSPARREN unbosomed himself to his supposed rebel friends. He told them where the best fording places in the river could be found, and the most accessible roads to them, pointed out each Union man who had the best horses, fattest stock, and the largest quantity of wheat, corn and oats. After he had delivered himself of all his information and abuse of his Government, his friends told him that they were no rebels, but good Union men, and that he should prepare to accompany them to Bell-Air. To this MCSPARREN objected, but finding his guests determined, made a virtue of necessity and accompanied them. At Bell Air he was taken before an officer, who told him that he must take the oath of allegiance. Here he again dissented, avowing that he would do no such thing. He was then taken to prison, when a few days rations of bread and water subdued his hatred of the North to such a degree that he wished to take the oath. It was administered to him, after which, chop-fallen and in no amiable mood, he wended his way home. -- Lancaster Examiner, Aug. 3.

abstract: A "dummy" car filled with excursionists, on its way to Jersey City, last evening, at about 8 o'clock, came in collision with an empty dummy and car standing partially on a side track, on the grade near "Bull's Head," where the dummies are changed for horse cars, causing severe injury to three persons, one of whom, it is thought, will not survive. The cries of the passengers while approaching the collision were unheeded by either conductor or engineman, and it is states that at the moment of collision the speed of the car was quite us great as at any time during the trip.

abstract: This organization met last night. A large attendance, was present. The Hon. JOHN MCCOOL was called to the chair in the absence of the Chairman; Mr. P. DALEY, Secretary. A series of resolutions, declaring that the masses of the Democratic party of this City and State are in favor of peace, and of the instant inauguration of negotiations for ending the present war; that the members of the General Committee, who have been placed upon the delegation from this. State to the Chicago Convention, be instructed to cast their votes for no man as a candidate of the Democratic party for President or Vice-President in favor of the further prosecution of the war, &c., was unanimously adopted.
