abstract: -- Mr. A. MORTON, the eminent manufacturer of Gold Pens, has at length been compelled by the continued advance in nominal values, caused by the inflation of our Currency, to advance the prices of his goods. He has stood out through many months, incurring heavy losses, in the hope that the end of the War would speedily enable him to boast that he had sold his Pens throughout at Peace prices; but he gives notice to-day that he can stand out no longer, and must henceforth charge enough for his goods to cover their cost. This is termed an advance in prices, but not quite accurately. Every farmer can buy one, a dozen, or a hundred of MORTON'S Pens for less Produce, every manufacturer for less Cloth, every Workman fat less Labor, than in 1860. It is simply a readjustment of nominal to actual values. We hope to hear that his trade is unaffected by it; for we hold it no man's true interest to buy anymore than to sell goods for less than their honest cost. -- Tribune, July 12.

This is termed an advance in prices, but not quite accurately. Every farmer can buy one, a dozen, or a hundred of MORTON'S Pens for less Produce, every manufacturer for less Cloth, every Workman fat less Labor, than in 1860. It is simply a readjustment of nominal to actual values. We hope to hear that his trade is unaffected by it; for we hold it no man's true interest to buy anymore than to sell goods for less than their honest cost. -- Tribune, July 12.

abstract: FAST DAY IN THE EASTERN DISTRICT. -- The day was observed yesterday in Brooklyn (E.D.) by a general suspension of business. Prayer meetings and other religious services were held in several of the churches, and were quite well attended. In the afternoon a trial of engines took place in front of the house of Engine Company No. 1, in North Second-street. The companies participating were Nos. 1, 5, 7, 9 and 21 of the Eastern District, and Steam Fire Engine No. 2 of New-York. No. 21 Engine Company was the victor, playing 210 feet, or about 15 feet above the top of the pole. The steam fire engine played the second highest stream, and there was but little variation amongst the other companies.

abstract: Several boat loads of uniforms, picked up on the different battle-fields, have recently arrived in the vicinity of Atlantic Docks. They are all soiled and many are blood-stained and perforated with bullet holes. The Health Officer was advised of the matter, and ordered that they should be stored until Fall. It has since been shown, however, that the clothing was legitimately procured, and that there was no danger to the public health to expose them for sale. One cargo of between 1,000 and 1,500 uniforms was, therefore, landed at the Hamilton-avenue bridge yesterday and disposed of to such parties as desired to purchase these melancholy relics of brave men who fought and died for the Union.

abstract: Gen. STONEMAN'S raid along the Macon Rail  road met with a great success in cutting the rebel line of communication, and thus completely isolating Atlanta. But I regret the necessity to add that one division of cavalry, while returning, met with a serious disaster. The Macon Railroad was torn up for eighteen miles, the rails twisted, the ties, tanks, bridges and depots burned, and the road rendered useless for months to come.
lead_paragraph: FROM NASHVILLE.

abstract: The New Act
lead_paragraph: The main provisions of the amended postal law, applying to the house delivery of letters, to the issuance of stamps as an article of trade for public convenience, to correspondence with countries not now represented by a postal treaty, to dead letters, and to the salaries of postmasters, are in principle a most essential reform. We cannot help thinking, however, in looking over its provisions, that in some respects it anticipates other improvements which are really prerequisites to a practical application of the proposed changes. Our readers who may have examined the synopsis of the act, which appeared in Wednesday's issue, will have readily perceived this.

abstract: Mission to Richmond--Evening Post on
lead_paragraph: "The friends of Col. JAQUES have a desire that it shall be understood that the recent visit to Richmond was not the more venture of a curiosity hunter, nor made from a wish for notoriety, Col. JAQUES is an army officer. He has fought in nearly every Western battle, with the exception of the Vicksburgh campaign, from the beginning of the war. He commanded a regiment at Perryville, Murfreesboro', Chickamauga, Mission Ridge, and led a brigade in the march and fight which relieved Knoxville, and at Tunnell Hill, Dalton, Resaca, Rocky Face and other battles in the present campaign of Gen. SHERMAN. At Chickamauga he had two horses killed under him, and lost three-fourths of his regiment, in the most desperate part of the battle.

abstract: Fast Day Sermon; Fast Day Sermon; Fast Day Sermon; Rev Dr. Fast Day Sermon; Fast Day in New-York; Fast Day Sermon; Fast Day Sermon
snippet: Fast Day Sermon; Fast Day Sermon; Fast Day Sermon; Rev Dr. Fast Day Sermon; Fast Day in New-York; Fast Day Sermon; Fast Day Sermon
lead_paragraph: In accordance with the Proclamation of President LINCOLN, yesterday was observed as a day of fasting and prayer. All business was voluntarily suspended, the public offices, the banks and stores were closed, and our citizens flocked to such places of worship as were open for services. Owing to the absence of a great many clergymen in me country, a less number of sermons were delivered than is usual on such occasions; but wnere the pastors were absent, the people gathered together in the churches and held Union prayer-meetings, where all joined in supplications for the welfare of their country. Notwithstanding the advice of His Honor the Mayor to the divines of this City, neither the ministers in their sermons, nor the congregations in their prayers seem to have sought for "peace on any terms," but the feeling seemed to be peace and reunion on a lasting basis. The. general observance of the day showed itself not only in the putting aside of all business, but the citizens seemed to feel that it was not a day simply for idleness and recreation, not a holiday, but a day of solemn mourning. The parks and places of amusement in the suburbs were, not much resorted to, the streets were not crowded, and the City, as a general thing, was quieter than on Sunday. Our reporters visited such of the churches as were provided with ministers, and abstracts of the sermons are given below; but in most of the various places of worship only Union prayer meetings were held.

abstract: THE OBSERVANCE OF FAST DAY. -- The fast day recommended by the President of the United States was generally observed in this city yesterday. The public offices and all places of business, excepting liquor-selling establishments, were closed, and work of all sorts was suspended -- it being recognized as a general holiday. Religious services were held in several churches, which were well attended, but most of the places of worship were closed, in consequence of the absence of the pastors, who are rusticating in the country.

abstract: A MAN FATALLY INJURED. -- On Wednesday night last a serious disturbance occurred in Sixth-avenue, near Forty-third-street, during which a German, named HENRY MILEY, was beaten so badly that it is believed he cannot survive. It seems that the horseshoers employed in a blacksmith's shop, situated in Twenty-fourth-street, between Sixth and Seventh avenues, have for several weeks past been on a strike. MILEY was employed in that shop, and after the others had struck he kept on at the old rates. This conduct on his part greatly exasperated his fellow-workmen, who threatened to punish-him severely when he left the shop. These threats were, however, unheeded, and MILEY continued to work as usual until Wednesday night. He then left the shop and proceeded up Sixth-avenue, followed by several of the strikers, among whom was one JAMES BRANNIGAN. The latter was armed by what is known among that trade as a "turning hammer," a broad-faced tool with a handle about 18 inches in length. When near the Sixth-avenue railroad depot, MILEY was stopped and violently assaulted and beaten by the strikers. BRANNIGAN struck MILEY a powerful blow with the hammer above mentioned, sinking the whole face of the weapon into the skull. MILEY fell to the pavement, and the brows on his head were then several times repeated. BRANNIGAN ran away. Several citizens, who witnessed the affair, attempted to stop him. He was finally arrested by Officer NEWLET, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct. The instrument he had used on his victim was found in his possession, covered with blood. MILEY was conveyed to the Station-house, where he received the requisite medical attendance. His physicians say he cannot recover. The prisoner was taken into his presence, and by him positively identified as the man who committed the assault. BRANNIGAN was taken before Justice LEDWITH, at Jefferson Market Police Court, and committed to await the result.

abstract: The officers of HUNTER's command, who have recently passed through the Valley of the Shenandoah, state that the crops there are very abundant and that success in harvesting and conveying away even a fair proportion of them, would further pay the enemy for all the toll and losses of their present expedition. Our losses in the fight at Winchester, they say, did not amount to one thousand, though there was a large number of the troops who were so much worn by the fight, in addition to their previous privations and hardships, that they were not in efficient fighting or even retreating condition.
lead_paragraph: The officers of HUNTER's command, who have recently passed through the Valley of the Shenandoah, state that the crops there are very abundant and that success in harvesting and conveying away even a fair proportion of them, would further pay the enemy for all the toll and losses of their present expedition. abstract: Tho Actors' Protective Union held its third meeting at the Cooper Institute, yesterday afternoon, at 3 o'clock. Mr. DAVIDGE took the chair, and desired to say that this movement was not a strike of  the actors, but simply action for the mutual protection of both actors and managers.
lead_paragraph: The Actors' Protective Union held its third meeting at the Cooper Institute, yesterday afternoon, at 3 o'clock. Mr. DAVIDGE took the chair, and desired to say that this movement was not a strike of the actors, but simply action for the mutual protection of both actors and managers. Some writers for the press had assumed that the grievances of the actor should be settled by law, but this was an ineffectual remedy, citing one or two notable instances where the entering of judgment against managers was the end of the matter. Mr. DAVIDGE thought it should be understood that the object of this Union was completely in unison with the policy and profit of managers. They desired first the establishment of a minimum salary, and the establishment or the different lines of business as near as possible. Of course, the greater the popularity and talent of an artist, the greater his salary.
headline: {'main': "Actors' Protective Union.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Actors' Protective Union.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: At a late hour on Thursday afternoon a case of much interest just at this time, when the business of substitute brokers is so brisk in this City, occurred in the Second Ward. Policeman HIRAM B. FERGUSON, of the Second Precinct, in citizens dress, was passing along William-street, when he was accosted by a substitute broker named JOHN W. CHAPMAN. From all the testimony in the case, it appears that the latter supposed the officer to be a countryman, just arrived in the City and with this idea he asked him if he did not wish to enlist. If be wished to serve his country, now was his time. The broker would take FERGUSON to Philadelphia, where he could enlist and receive a bounty of $500; at the same time he, the broker, would be benefited to the amount of $150. The broker also said that if he, FERGUSON, was smart, he could desert and return to this City, after getting his bounty money in Philadelphia, by paying $100; that he had taken several men on there, and the affair had been managed in that way. CHAPMAN said that one day last week he took five men to Philadelphia and enlisted them there; that after they were sworn in and had received their bounty, they managed to escape and return to this City before he did. Officer FERGUSON, after listening awhile to the inducements held out to him by CHAPMAN, said he would go on to Philadelphia with him, and it was arranged that they were to meet at the Jersey City Ferry in time to take the evening train for Philadelphia. The officer meantime proceeded to the Station-house, and laid the whole case before Capt. MILLS, who instructed him to meet CHAPMAN pursuant to appointment. The two accordingly met, and just as they were about going on board the boat at the foot of Cortlandt-street, officer WILDEY, of the Twenty-second Precinct, who had been posted on the subject, made his appearance and look CHAPMAN into custody. The latter was taken before Superintendent KENNEDY at Police Headquarters and locked up for the night Yesterday Justice HOGAN committed him to the Tombs without ball.

CHAPMAN said that one day last week he took five men to Philadelphia and enlisted them there; that after they were sworn in and had received their bounty, they managed to escape and return to this City before he did. Officer FERGUSON, after listening awhile to the inducements held out to him by CHAPMAN, said he would go on to Philadelphia with him, and it was arranged that they were to meet at the Jersey City Ferry in time to take the evening train for Philadelphia. The officer meantime proceeded to the Station-house, and laid the whole case before Capt. MILLS, who instructed him to meet CHAPMAN pursuant to appointment. The two accordingly met, and just as they were about going on board the boat at the foot of Cortlandt-street, officer WILDEY, of the Twenty-second Precinct, who had been posted on the subject, made his appearance and look CHAPMAN into custody. abstract: From Gen. SHERMAN'S army we have the intelligence that Gen. STONEMAN, on the 26th ult., sent a large force of cavalry, under command of Gen. McCOOK, to destroy the Macon and Western Railroad. They destroyed some 18 miles of the road, and then started to capture a rebel train of 500 wagons, going from Atlanta to Macon or Columbus.
lead_paragraph: From Gen. SHERMAN's army we have the intelligence that Gen. STONEMAN, on the 26th ult., sent a large force of cavalry, under command of Gen. MCCOOK, to destroy the Macon and Western Railroad. They destroyed some 18 miles of the road, and then started to capture a rebel train of 500 wagons, going from Atlanta to Macon or Columbus. This they succeeded in doing, but were afterwards attacked by a greatly superior force under Gen. RANSOM, and, after a desperate engagement, were obliged to surrender. It is supposed that the rebels captured at least two thousand of our men.

abstract: Campaign, a Look at
lead_paragraph: The month of July, it seems, went out with two military mishaps -- one, a cavalry affair in Georgia, the other the more serious repulse before Petersburgh. What is done being now past recall, all we care to know of it is its effect on the grand campaign, though presently inquiry must be made as to who is in fault. Tactical mismanagement appears to have been the cause of the repulse at Petersburgh. In Georgia, if report be true, it was want of discipline and of control over the men. Our troops, it seems, drank too much of the liquor they captured, evidently holding the happy theory of BURNS, that fighting and tippling go hand in hand. But why the officers permitted this grand carnival within the enemy's lines, the oracular telegram does not announce.
headline: {'main': 'A Look at the Campaign.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Look at the Campaign.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The aspect of the Spanish question had not changed since the previous mail. Peru was waiting the decision of the Cabinet at Madrid upon the Chincha Islands seizure, but was actively strengthening her coast and naval defences.
lead_paragraph: The aspect of the Spanish question had not changed since the previous mail. Peru was waiting the decision of the Cabinet at Madrid upon the Chincha Islands seizure, but was actively strengthening her coast and naval defences. The neighboring Republics continue to manifest their sympathy with Peru by a great deal of talk, and many think that "when it comes to a pinch" they will limit their sympathy to this mode of assistance. The mail which left Panama for Callao on the 24th will carry the news that Spain has no intention of giving up the Islands till all her demands are satisfied, so in a month or so we shall know whether we are to have war or peace.

abstract: The attempts at revolution against the Government of President MORENO and Gen. FLORES seem all to have been suffocated, and the country is now quiet. These two leaders seem to have become alarmed at the determined attitude of their own people against their monarchical tendencies and are apparently changing front. Gen. JUAN JOSE FLORES publishes a letter in Lima, in which he says if war should result from the differences between Spain and Peru, Ecuador will sustain the sovereignty and independence of the American Continent. The Comercio, at Lima, throws doubt upon his good faith in this declaration.

abstract: The steamship Saxonia, from Southampton on the 26th ult., passed Cape Race on Thursday en route for New-York. The steamship City of Manchester, of the Inman line, arrived here yesterday. The news by the latter is anticipated; that by the Saxonia is two days later than the Africa's. Lord CAMPBELL, in the House of Lords, had elicited from the Government the statement that the treaty of 1852, which secured the Provinces to Denmark, was considered still binding. In the House of Commons, Mr. LINDSAY asked whether the Government intended, in concert with other European Powers, to endeavor to bring about a suspension of hostilities in this country. Lord PALMERSTON replied that at present there was no advantage to be gained by meddling. Mr. SLIDELL had left Paris on a visit to the Emperor at Vichy. Peace prospects between Denmark and Germany are said to have grown more certain. On Monday, the 25th ult., a meeting of the Austrian, Prussian and Danish Plenipotentiaries had taken place, and important preliminaries were settled. British Consols are as low as 89 7/8 for money. The Bank of England has raised its rate of discount to 7 cent.

abstract: Rebel Struggles for
lead_paragraph: The desperate character of the struggle for recognition which has marked the efforts of the rebel sympathizers in England during the past month, forms a strange comment on the boasted invincibility of their military organization. The return of MASON to his undignified post in the outer lobbies of the British Foreign Office; the parliamentary exercitations of LINDSAY and CLANRICARDE; the deputations of retired Admirals, rural Justices, and Tory parsons, expostulating with Lord PALMERSTON; the "honorable Secretary of the Southern Independence Association," assailing Lord RUSSELL with a mythical list of memorialists from the factory districts, all in favor of instant mediation, prove to us one thing, if they prove nothing else. They show beyond cavil that these European agents of DAVIS' Confederacy have no faith that the thing will last, if it is not propped up, and propped up speedily, from without. Whoever believes in the invincibility of LEE's army, these shrewd on-lookers do not. Their latest struggles for recognition are not inspired by confidence. They are fitful, spasm-like and desperate, at the very time when, by every accepted "Confederate" statement of the military situation, they might be expected to present a character of calm, resolute defiance.
headline: {'main': 'The Rebel Struggle for Recognition.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Rebel Struggle for Recognition.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Invasion, the Reports of
lead_paragraph: The Maryland reports of the invasion take a view of the rebel movements essentially different from those which reach us via Harrisburgh. But putting the two together, it does not appear that the situation can have materially changed. There is great probability that the farmers of the upper portion of the Cumberland Valley, who are leaving their homes in droves, along with all their movable stock, and to whose inspiration doubtless we are indebted for the Pennsylvania telegrams, have seen double in attempting to number the body of rebels said to have crossed early yesterday morning at Hancock.

abstract: Army, Consolidation of
lead_paragraph: The army of Gen. SHERMAN has lost heavily by the death of Gen. MCPHERSON, and by the removal from service within its lines of Gen. HOOKER. It was the "Army of the Tennessee," consisting of three corps under Gen. MCPHERSON, which performed most of the brilliant flank marches and splendid strokes which have illustrated the advance of our forces from Chattanooga to Atlanta. It was Gen. HOOKER -- "Fighting JOE. HOOKER" -- with his Twentieth Army Corps, who did much of the hardest fighting, and dealt the rebels the most effective blows in the score of battles which have taken place since the opening of the month of May. We earnestly hope that the Western army will neither be less effective nor less successful now that it has lost the services of both these eminent officers.

abstract: Since the great fleet of war-vessels, which some months ago was in course of construction in this neighborhood, has been diminished by the completion of several craft, those that remain are not so frequently brought into notice. The great steamship Dunderberg, the iron steamers building at Greenpoint and Jersey City, the Dictator and Puritan, the great double-turreted Navy-yard armored ships, the immense first-class fast wooden steam frigates, and a few of the light-draft monitors still occupy the attention of builders.

abstract: Rebel Army to be Looked to
snippet: Rebel Army to be Looked to
lead_paragraph: The rebels have undoubtedly large bodies of troops west of the Mississippi River, as appeared in Gen. BANKS' Grand Ecore campaign last Spring. They have a force sufficiently large to strengthen greatly either of the two main rebel armies, and yet it is incapable of effecting anything of value where it now is. Rumors have latterly been reaching us, both through Southern and other sources, that this force, under KIRBY SMITH, has been crossing to this side of the Mississippi, and is now, or recently has been, marching to reinforce Gen. HOOD at Atlanta.

abstract: Non-Intervention Policy; British Non-intervention; and on
snippet: Non-Intervention Policy; British Non-intervention; and on
lead_paragraph: The position taken by the English Ministry on the Danish question, is producing some curious results. It is generally looked upon at home as well as on the continent as a formal declaration that hereafter the English foreign policy is to be one of strict, isolation; that she will rigidly refrain from all interference in the affairs of other nations, excepting advice and "protests;" and that she will in no case use either fleet or army, except for the purpose of warding off direct and palpable danger to her own possessions or interests. The London Times is in reality, or pretends to be, on the whole, well pleased with this decision, and proceeds to base on it an elaborate and energetic argument in favor of the total cessation, on the part of Great Britain, of any attempt to repress the Slave-trade. It declares that the maintenance of a squadron on the Coast of Africa, for the purpose of preventing, the exportation of blacks, is a clear violation of the rule now laid down, as it is forcible inerference in defence of foreign sava ges, whose condition, calamities and prospects are of no sort of concern to England, and to whom kidnapping and Slavery is, after all, but one of the ordinary incidents of a life which is, at least, very miserable. It alleges that the English Government is in no way responsible for what happens to Africans, but it is responsible for the lives of Englishmen in its service, and that therefore it is open to the gravest censure every time an officer or sailor of the squadron falls a victim to the climate.

abstract: FIRE IN A BROADWAY MILLINERY AND HAT-STORE. -- Late on Friday night a fire occurred in the buildings No. 377 Broadway, near Walker-street, occupied on the lower floor by Messrs. PECK & SCHULHOFF, dealers in millinery goods. Their stock was badly damaged by water. They are insured for $32,000 In the following companies, viz.: Central, $2,500; Standard, $2,500; WilLiamsburgh City, $2,500; Croton,$2.500;Albany City, $2,500; Brevoort, $2,500; C[???]rn Exchange, $5.000; Park, $5.000; North Western. $5,000, and Firemen's Trust, $2,000. The second floor of the premises is occupied by WILLIAM E. WHITE, dealer in straw goods, whose stock is also much damaged by water. The third floor was occupied by FRANK & SCHWAB manufacturers of cloth hats. Their stock is a total loss. The fourth floor is occupied by BLAUVELT & PALMER, photographers, who sustained but a slight loss. The building is owned by Wm. HURRY, and is damaged to the extent of $1,500. The building No. 379, adjoining, was also damaged to the extent of $1,500. The store is occupied by HEGEMAN & Co., druggists, whose stock is damaged to the extent of $1,000; insured for $3,000 in Howard insurance Company.

abstract: Shooting with the Long Bow
lead_paragraph: Our people complain sometimes of the innumerable rumors which are daily set afloat, and the impossibility of putting reliance upon statements made. It must be confessed that there is some ground for the complaint. But we can give them on this point the same consolation that we can in reference to the high price of flour, viz.: advise them to think how much worse off they would be if they were in Richmond instead of New-York. For certainly there hardly could be another place where the people fill their bellies with the east wind of rumor, in default of the solid provender of fact, to that degree that they seem to do in Richmond.

abstract: Disabled Soldiers' Home
lead_paragraph: It would be worth while for those who have been earnest in urging on public attention the necessity of providing a permanent Home for Disabled Soldiers, to go round among them, and learn what the soldiers themselves think of the matter. It is easy enough, we apprehend, to get at an average opinion without going beyond the limits of New-York. The writer hereof, for several months past, has made it a regular practice, whenever the opportunity presented itself, to get into conversation with wounded or disabled soldiers, with the view to draw them on to the subject, by speaking of the provisions made in other countries for public servants of their class.

abstract: City Judge RUSSELL rendered his opinion yesterday in the case of Gen. DIX and his officers, who were charged with kidnapping, inciting to a riot, and forcibly and illegally detaining property in the matter of the arrest of one of the editors of the Journal of Commerce, and the seizure of the office of that paper and of the World. Judge RUSSELL decided that there was sufficient cause to hold the accused, and that the case, like any other criminal complaint, must be submitted to the Grand Jury.

abstract: Cession to France Spoken of
lead_paragraph: Again the cession of Sardinia to France is spoken of. This question was first broached in the columns of an Italian journal -- it is now revived in those of a French cotemporary, and some of the leading Transalpine journals have become, not unnaturally, alarmed at so very suspicious a circumstance. They do not hesitate, indeed, to declare their belief in the existence of a plot between the oracle at the Tuileries and the Government at Turin for the carrying out of the project. Even CAVOUR, they assert, was at one time favorable to the sale of Sardinia, provided a good price could be got for it, and the men who disposed of Savoy and Nice can hardly be trusted in such a matter. Under some pretext or other, too, all the Italian soldiers and officials are being removed from the island, and everything indicates that an act of treachery is in contemplation. But it is not exactly for the sale and purchase of Sardinia that NAPOLEON and the Turin Cabinet are now in treaty. The Italian King, according to our authorities, having eschewed the aid of revolution, and the instrumentality of arms, for the recovery of Rome, has no alternative save to let things remain in statu quo, or to offer some equivalent to the French Emperor which might induce him to withdraw his troops from the "Eternal City." The possession of Rome being indispensable to the maintenance of VICTOR EMANUEL's prestige, and the integrity of his Kingdom, he has determined to embrace the latter horn of the dilemma rather than the former, and so Sardinia is to be transferred to NAPOLEON in consideration of his recalling the French garrison from Italy, and leaving the old Pope to his fate.
headline: {'main': 'Cession of Sardinia to France.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Cession of Sardinia to France.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Under the Bonaparte regime the rights of French authors and their publishers are no more respected than those of French editors. A case has recently been decided in the First Chamber of the Cour Imperiale, which shows this. The Duke D'AUMALE, eldest son of LOUIS PHILIPPE, having, to while away the dreariness of exile, written a "History of the House of CONDE during the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries," arranged with M. LEVY, a Parisian publisher, for the bringing out of the first volume of the work. There was no attempt at concealment from the outset. The publisher and his printer had scrupulously fulfilled all the formalities required by the laws on the press. Two copies had been deposited in the Department of the Interior, and the proof sheets and revises had passed backward and forward from Paris to London, and from London to Paris, without any objection or impediment on the part of the Post-office authorities -- without any indication that the printing and publication of the book would be interfered with. When some four thousand volumes had been printed, however, the Prefect of Police, by order of M. DE PERSIGNY, suddenly sent his emissaries to the printing-office, and carried off the whole lot to a cellar of his prefecture, where for nearly two years they have remained under lock and key. Soon after, the Duke D'AUMALE and his publisher took legal proceedings against the Prefect, in order to compel him to restore the property which he had thus outrageously seized; but the civil Tribunal of the Seine, before which the case was, in the first instance, tried, decided that the act of the Prefect was in conformity with the order of the Minister of the Interior, and that it was therefore justifiable, while, by Article 75 of the Constitution of the year 8, the plaintiffs were debarred from proceeding against an agent of the Government for acts done in the discharge of his official duties, without the authorization of the Council of State. This "authorization" neither the Duke nor M. LEVY had solicited, from the conviction, doubtless, that it would be refused; and so they were not only nonsuited, but compelled to pay costs.

Soon after, the Duke D'AUMALE and his publisher took legal proceedings against the Prefect, in order to compel him to restore the property which he had thus outrageously seized; but the civil Tribunal of the Seine, before which the case was, in the first instance, tried, decided that the act of the Prefect was in conformity with the order of the Minister of the Interior, and that it was therefore justifiable, while, by Article 75 of the Constitution of the year 8, the plaintiffs were debarred from proceeding against an agent of the Government for acts done in the discharge of his official duties, without the authorization of the Council of State. This "authorization" neither the Duke nor M. LEVY had solicited, from the conviction, doubtless, that it would be refused; and so they were not only nonsuited, but compelled to pay costs.

abstract: -- The Franklin Repository printing Office in Chambersburgn was totally destroyed by the rebels -- all the presses, books, type, subscription list and accounts, nothing being saved. We are informed by Messrs. MCCLURE & STONER that as soon as material and presses can be supplied, they will resume the publication of the Repository, and also The Old Flag -- a campaign paper that has attained a very large circulation. The subscription lists of both papers are destroyed. Four copies were secreted in different parts of the town, but are burned. With their lists, their subscription accounts were also destroyed, and subscribers should at once inform MCCLURE & STONER of their address, and the state of their subscription accounts, and all sub[???] are promptly remit arrearages and advance subscriptions to aid the publishers. In addition to theirs offices, both of them had their residences [???]ed, with all their furniture and personal effects the rebels not allowing them to save their clothing. Mr. STONER was fired at in his own house for attempting to save the firm books, and the men who burned Mr. MCCLURR's residence had special orders that nothing belonging to him should be saved. -- Pheladelphia Bulletin.

abstract: Generous Donations
lead_paragraph: In the Boston Journal we find the following items regarding the proceedings at Williams College, during the commencement week, at the Alumni Meeting: President HOPKINS made some remarks in relation to the financial condition of the institution, and said that he had received a letter from Hon. J.Z. GOODRICH, of Stockbridge, Collector of the port of Boston, placing $25,000 at the disposal of the college. The announcement was received with cheers, and a vote of thanks to Mr. GOODRICH was passed. DAVID DUDLEY FIELD, of New-York, proposed to be one to make up the desired sum of $110,000 for the full endowment of the institution, and a committee was appointed to solicit subscriptions in its behalf.

abstract: The Moniteur de l'Armee publishes an article on the military forces of the various European Powers. He says: "Since the war in the Crimea and in Italy, we have frequently heard these questions discussed and we have ...
lead_paragraph: The Moniteur de l'Armee publishes an article on the military forces of the various European Powers. On the question as to whether the Russian or the Austrian troops are superior as soldiers, the writer professes inability to decide, but his leaning seems to be to the Russians. He says: "Since the war in the Crimea and in Italy, we have frequently heard these questions discussed and we have found among the French officers as many partisans for the one as for the other. A man whose voice was of immense authority half a century ago -- we speak of NAPOLEON I. -- in his sometimes harsh correspondence, allows himself to fall into severe expressions on almost all the troops of Europe; he, however, never makes use of an unfavorable word with respect to the Russians. In fact, under the First Empire, the armies of ALEXANDER I., although beaten by France at Austerlitz, Friedland, Moscow and Lutzen, and during the whole of the campaign of 1814, constantly showed themselves to be stout soldiers, worthy of combatting against the French legions. The Russian armies have not been in existence two centuries, as in 1689, when PETER the Great ascended the throne, he found only one regular corps of 15,000 men; at that period, however, they were making great progress. The Czar PETER in dying left to CATHERINE 110,000 soldiers, well disciplined and perfectly organized. In 1772. after the first partition of Poland, CATHERINE II, raised the peace footing of her troops to 270,000 men. At the moment of the campaign of 1805 Russia had 500,000 men, of whom 300,000 were combatants, for the armies of that Power always present a very great difference between the military element and the fighting one. For a long time, in fact, the sovereigns of Russia have the mania of assimilation, so that the real effective is very inferior to that which is enunciated by the regulation returns. At the end of the war of 1814, Russia had 900,000 men on her military rolls. Since that period her effective has always maintained very nearly that enormous figure, and yet she would have a difficulty in bringing into the field three armies of 100,000 men each. With her extent of territory, and the permanent germs of revolt on the extreme points of her distant provinces, which are ill subjected to her authority, she is obliged to maintain special corps -- in the Caucasus, 120,000 men and 120 pieces of artillery; in Siberia, 20,000 men and 40 guns, and on the frontier numerous bodies of irregular Cossacks. For a long time the Russian army tried to be a sort of Medusa's head for Europe; but the Colossus with feet, of clay, as it has been named and not without reason, has lost much of its prestige since the energetic Government of NAPOLEON III. succeeded that of July. The reverses of Russia on the Danube and before Silistria, with the loss of the battles of the Alma, Inkerman and Trakfir, and the fall of Sebastopol, have opened the eyes of all Europe. The efforts made now by Russia to reduce Poland confirm the existence of a radical vice in her military organization. That vice is above all the deplorable incapacity of almost all the men charged with the administration of the troops, and perhaps, also, of a part of those who exercise the commands. We must, however, admit that since the peace of Paris the efforts of the Emperor ALTXANDER have out been fruitless to introduce a little more regularity in the auministration of his numerous army. The Russian troops, we must admit, are becoming civilized, like the whole country. The period at which the Russian army was strongest was that during which the government succeeded, by means of deceitful promises, in amalgamating with its troops the Polish element, which is superior to all that exists in that vast empire. At present that element fails it.

abstract: I can give you no idea of the excitement in Atlanta. Everybody seems to be hurrying off, and especially the women. Wagons loaded with household furniture, and everything else that can be packed upon them, crowd every street, and women, old and young, and children innumerable, are hurrying to and fro, leading pet lambs, deer and other little household objects of affection, as though they intended to save all they could. Every train of cars is loaded to its utmost capacity, and there is no grumbling about seats, for even the fair ones are but too glad to get even a standing place in a box car. The excitement beats anything I ever saw, and I hope I may never witness such again. But in the midst of all this the soldiers are cool, and cheerful, and sanguine.

abstract: Our Paris correspondent mentioned, yesterday, a pleasing circumstance connected, with a hasty visit he had just made to Germany. Going from Paris, where little or no sympathy is heard for the Union cause, where the imperialist journals teach the people that the American Government is on the verge of ruin, and where American stocks are unknown, it was like a sudden change from darkness into light to find himself in the midst of many hundreds of bankers and brokers screaming themselves hoarse over American stocks, in a place (Frankfort-on-the-Maine) where more American stocks are bought and sold in one day than of all the European stocks combined, and where such an interest is felt in the national cause that the agency of the ERLANGERS in the Confederate Loan is charged against that house as almost a crime! These Federal bonds were bought in most part by permanent holders, and not by speculators -- by people who pay little attention to the fluctuations of war, because they have confidence in the future of the Union, and find this the best investment for their surplus funds. Nevertheless, the "bulls" and "bears" of the Frankfort Bourse speculate largely in these stocks on their own account, and appear to be quite as sensitive to small events as the same class of gentlemen on other Exchanges. Our correspondent went on to give the assurance that in the present situation of affairs at Frankfort, a loan of a hundred millions could be negotiated there by the American Government at a day's notice.

abstract: Notwithstanding the great efforts which have been and are being made to fill the quota of this City, under the last call for troops, it is evidently impossible that it should be filled by the time specified. The recruiting officers have done their utmost, but until within the past few days have been so seriously embarrassed by the agents from other States, and the large bounties offered by them, that their efforts have not proved successful. The new resolution adopted on Friday by the Board of Supervisors, directing the Volunteer Committee to furnish substitutes for residents liable or not liable to draft, in the numerical order of the registration of their names and of their payments, and to pay the substitutes the County bounty in addition to the private bounty, will, it is thought, have a very good effect, and greatly assist the officers in procuring recruits. There are plenty of men now in this City ready and anxious to enlist, but so many have been swindled and abused by scoundrels calling themselves bounty brokers, that they fear to volunteer lest they also should be robbed of their bounty money, and, perhaps, even more seriously injured. These men should remember, however, that if they are so robbed it is entirely their own fault. Let them go directly to the Park or Battery Barracks, represent their wishes to Supervisor BLUNT, personally, and he will see that their papers are made out correctly, that they are not abused or humbugged in any way, and that they get every cent of the bounty money to which they are entitled.

abstract: If the conscription of our experienced, active, skilful, disciplined and efficient Fire Brigade, is allowed to remain a "fixed fact," those veterans who so well know how to man the brakes and conquer the devouring element, can, of course, no longer "run wider machine." abstract: -- A man named WHITING, employed in Mr. PATTERSON's sawmill at the foot of North Third-street, (E.D.,) Friday, had his foot caught in one of the large circular saws, completely splitting the foot from the large toe to the ankle, also dislocating the knee joint. Amputation was performed at the knee joint by Dr. C. OLCOTT, assisted by Drs. E.S. OLCOTT and FISK.

abstract: Yesterday morning the ship Clara Morse arrived from Hongkong, and before her coolie passengers could be landed, the six Chinese companies had ascertained, that another lot of Shanghaied Chinese girls, brought out here to be sold into a life of Slavery and prostitution, were on board. The vessel was immediately boarded by Capt. DOUGLASS, of the police force, and Watchman BERNARD HAGEN, who took off nineteen of the unfortunate creatures -- some of them more children -- and had them conveyed to the depot established for the purpose by the agents of the companies on Sacramento-street, above Kearney, from whence they will by reshipped to China by the first vessel leaving for the "Central Flowery Empire." It will not be long before the dealers in human beings in Canton and Shanghai learn that the six companies in San Francisco are in earnest, and the successthat an end is to be put at once to the existence of one of the most infamous systems of Slavery which ever cursed the earth -- so far, at least, as California is concerned. Every right-minded American citizen will be heartily pleased with the position taken by the companies on this question, and earnestly [???] them complete success in their praise worthy undertaking. -- San Francisco Alta California, July 11.

abstract: The Memphis Bulletin says Major WILLIAM STUBBS, of the Eight Iowa Infantry, on entering the United States service at the commencement of the rebellion, was presented by the employes of the Chicago and Rock Island Railroad, on which he had been a conductor, with an elegant sword, bearing an inscription expressive of their regard.
lead_paragraph: The Memphis Bulletin says Major WILLIAM STUBBS, of the Eight Iowa Infantry, on entering the United States service at the commencement of the rebellion, was presented by the employes of the Chicago and Rock Island Railroad, on which he had been a conductor, with an elegant sword, bearing an inscription expressive of their regard. At the battle of Sutton, Where the Major, with many other federal officers, fell into the hands of the enemy, he was obliged to surrender it to a rebel Lieutenant-Colonel. He was then sent to Selma, Ala., where he remained a prisoner for more than a year. Meanwhile his sword, the loss of which he much regretted, was doing service in rebel hands. At the second battle of Corinth, in the following October, the rebel Lieutenant Colonel was wounded and taken prisoner by a private of the Tenth Missouri Infantry, who, on divesting him of the sword he carried, accidentally discovered the incription, which indicated that it once belonged to a Union officer. A private is supposed to have no use for a sword when carrying a musket and bayonet, so he gave it to the Lieutenant of his company to use until such time as he, perhaps, might be entitled to wear it. The sword once more did good service in the cause of liberty and Union, in the hands of the Missouri Lieutenant, through Gen. GRANT's great campaign to the memorable fall of Vicksburgh. In the meantime the rightful owner of the sword was exchanged, and arrived at Chicago with other returned prisoners. Their names were published in the Chicago papers, one of which came into possession of the brave private, who while glancing over it, observed the name of Maj. STUBBS, and all at once concluded he was the owner of the sword he took from the rebel officer so long before. He was then with the army besieging Vicksburgh. Writing to the Major at Chicago, he informed him that he had a sword which he thought was his, and asked, if so, what he should do with it. As the Major was about to rejoin his regiment, which was also before Vicksburgh, he answered in person. He reached Vicksburgh on the morning of the 4th of July, when it surrendered to the Union army under Gen. GRANT, and finding the Tenth Missouri, met the honest soldier, who seemed overjoyed at discovering the owner of the weapon which the fortunes of war had thrown in his way. He conducted him to his Lieutenant, who was loth to part with the sword which had accompanied him through the great campaign of the Southwest, but gave it up cheerfully, The Major warmly thanked the soldier for the restoration of his sword, and tendered him a handsome sum of money as a reward for his trouble; but the noble fellow respectfully declined it. It was sufficient reward to have found the owner, as he was satisfied. Thus the Major unexpectedly recovered his blade, nearly a year and a half after its surrender.
headline: {'main': 'The History of a Sword.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The History of a Sword.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A rebel deserter named WALKER, furnishes, via Harrisburgh, the intelligence, which is certainly important if true, that the rebel cavalry under JOHNSTON, MCCAUSELAND and JACKSON, is advancing on Cumberland, and they are to be joined by EARLY and IMBODEN. The whole force is to centre at Cumberland, and march on Pittsburgh and Wheeling. The whole strength is about 25,000 or 30,000. Should they succeed in capturing these cities, they will then march on Cincinnati, and continue their victorious career into Kentucky. Mr. WALKER, we apprehend, has a very brilliant imagination; and we very much doubt whether this magnificent programme originated anywhere but in his own brain. Meanwhile, the rebels are pursuing their predatory course in Maryland and Pennsylvania, where they have signalized themselves by extreme brutality toward non-combatants. There is still considerable mystery in regard to their movements, and it appears to be impossible to arrive at an accurate estimate of their numbers, or to penetrate their ulterior designs.

abstract: -- A shocking case of kidnapping a fifteen year old boy, and selling him as a recruit, has just come to light. Officer SQUIRE this morning arrested ROBERT MCGEE and DAVID MURRAY, of this city, and lodged them in jail. They are charged as principals in conjunction with others with kidnapping a boy residing in Vermont, named EDWARD WHEELER, and also with subornation of perjury. MCGEE has been arrested and lodged in jail heretofore, on a charge of kidnapping Mr. LAHEY's bov. On this charge he was bailed out and bound over to the next Court of Sessions. This forenoon the prisoners were brought up before Justice FLAGG, who committed them for examination on the 10th instant, without bail. The boy's statement to his father is that MURRAY gave the boy liquor until he became intoxicated, when he took him by the cars to Albany, and from thence to Poughkeepsie. Here he wanted the boy to swear that he was eighteen years old, but he refused to do so. The boy states that he was then brought to Troy and shut up in MURRAY's house, in South Troy, for two cays. Finally he was taken out by MURRAY, when McGEE took him to the Provost-Marshal's office, where he was enlisted as a substitute for THOMAS BUCKLEY. Of course Mr. B. knew nothing of these scandalous transactions. The sum of $600 was paid for him, but whether the boy received any or what portion of the money does not yet appear. In addition to being plied with liquor, the boy was taken to a house of prostitution in this city. He is now at Harts' Island, and his father has gone down to see Gen. DIX, for the purpose of laying the facts before him. Warrants are out for other parties who are implicated in this affair, and we therefore refrain from further comment until an investigation brings out the facts more fully. Taken altogether, it seems to be one of the most wicked cases of kidnapping for bounty purposes which has yet come to light. -- Troy Times, Aug. 5.

Warrants are out for other parties who are implicated in this affair, and we therefore refrain from further comment until an investigation brings out the facts more fully. Taken altogether, it seems to be one of the most wicked cases of kidnapping for bounty purposes which has yet come to light. -- Troy Times, Aug. 5.

abstract: and Charleston Prisoners under Fire
lead_paragraph: The news of the exchange of prisoners at Charleston, which is related in our correspondence from Hilton Head this morning, is an agreeable relief from the stereotyped report of a bombardment which brings results no more appreciable to-day than they were fifteen months ago. It is news which we may well hail with a satisfaction beyond even that of finding our brave officers released from the galling position of prisoners under fire. It constitutes, we take it, a practical announcement that the business of retaliation is the meanest, as it is the most barbarous, expedient of war; that it is at variance with the principles which regulate modern warfare; that its employment in a conflict such as this, increases existing animosities, ministers to a general spirit of vengeance, brutalizes the feelings of those who have partaken in the conflict, proclaims the irreconcilable nature of the struggle, and bars even the most distant approach of the evangel of peace.

abstract: The appalling murder committed with at least temporary impunity on a line of metropolitan railway by which thousands travel to and from the city every day, has very naturally raised the question as to how the traveling public, including not only ninetenths of the metropolis, but a large proportion of the whole community, may be best protected in future from exposure to such fearful risks.
lead_paragraph: The appalling murder committed with at least temporary impunity on a line of metropolitan railway by which thousands travel to and from the city every day, has very naturally raised the question as to how the traveling public, including not only ninetenths of the metropolis, but a large proportion of the whole community, may be best protected in future from exposure to such fearful risks. The only effectual method of doing this is undoubtedly that of establishing some system of communication between the passengers and the guards while the train is in motion. This question has more than once been talked about, officially inquired into, and discussed in this country; but as yet nothing has been done to correct the admitted and notorious dangers of our isolated and solitary-cell system of railway traveling. It will, however, be a most culpable neglect on the part of all concerned if, after the warnings we have just had in the murder of one passenger and the hair-breadth escape of another from a still more terrible fate, some reasonable precautions to prevent the recurrence of such atrocities are not generally adopted. The safety of the public in future imperatively; requires that the excitement of the present moment should be turned to practical account. The only wonder is that we have gone so long without the ordinary means of security in railway traveling, which, in some shape or other, have long since been adopted in every other quarter of the globe. The rapid development of our railway system, and the large annual increase in the passenger traffic, render the necessity of proper and effectual action in this vital matter more and more urgent. Something must be done at once to meet the obvious requirements of the public safety. It the government declines to interfere the appeal must be made to the railway companies themselves. Nor can it be supposed that the directors of these companies are insensible to their responsibility on this head, or unwilling to meet it at the loud and unanimous call of the travelling public. As intelligent and reasonable men they must know that the interests of the companies and the public in this matter are substantially indentical, and that the more completely they provide for safety and convenience of the public, the more effectualy will they in the end promote the interests of the capital and enterprise they represent.

abstract: Chambersburg Burning and Rousseau's Humanity at Talladega, >amp;c.; A Vulgar Brigand--A Contrast
snippet: Chambersburg Burning and Rousseau's Humanity at Talladega, >amp;c.; A Vulgar Brigand--A Contrast
lead_paragraph: A few days since a rebel leader, MCCAUSLAND, was burning an undefended village in Pennsylvania, which had never offered resistance, turning half-naked women and babes out from their flaming houses, destroying churches and hospitals, and violating, with his robber crew, all the laws of honorable warfare acknowledged among civilized nations. Two weeks earlier, a Union General -- ROUSSEAU -- was in the heart of the rebel country, in Alabama; he found in a certain, village, named Loachapoka, a depot of rebel stores and a factory. These were very properly burnt, but the adjacent houses of the citizens were saved by the personal exertions of the General and his soldiers -- the latter putting their own wet blankets on the roofs. In Talladega, a Confederate gun-factory was broken up rather than burned, for fear that private houses might also suffer. Again at another station, the hospitals and tents for the sick rebels were carefully spared.

abstract: About five o'clock Sunday morning Sergt. CRAFTS and Officer CAMPSIL, of the Forty-second Precinct Police, observed two suspicious looking men loitering about the corner of Plymouth and Main streets. On approaching them another man was seen coming through Plymouth-street with a lot of rope, and not being able to account for its possession in a satisfactory manner, was taken to the Station house. On going to the dock the officers discovered two boats, and also learned that a number of bags filled with allspice had been transferred to a junk-shop on the corner of Plymouth and Main streets. The police took possession of the boa[???]s and the officers visited the junk-shop, where they found eight bags of allspice, which had just been brought in. In the cellar they discovered a large quantity of allspice, cotton, new and old rope, sails, coffee, &c., which were taken to the Station-house, by order of Capt. JACOBS, where it now remains for identification. In working the case up the officers found that a large quantity of coffee had been removed from the junk-shop the day before. The expressman, who removed it, being found, said that he had taken it to WEDEMYER's store, in Raymond-street. The officers found there 9 1/2 bags coffee (1,281 pounds,) which had been sold to him by MULRANEY, the junkman. It was secured and conveyed to the Station-house. In connection with the above-named officers, policemen PEARCE and BOURNE succeeded in arresting HUGH MULRANEY, the keeper of the junkshop, PATRICK MALONE, and PATRICK BRESLIN, who are charged with stealing the goods and selling them to MULRANEY. The amount of property recovered is valued at $2,000. According to the account-books found, MALONE sold to MULRANEY, since July 2, coffee, wool, iron, rope, brass, &c., to the amount of $1,531 19. BRESLIN sold the same kind of goods since the same date, amounting to $323 75. The sugar and wool is supposed to have been stolen from the scene of the late fire at the root of Jerolamon-street. The cotton, it appears, was bought for fourteen cents a pound, and sold for seventy cents in New-York. The goods are in the possession of the police, and awaiting owners to identify them. The prisoners are locked up meantime, to await further developments.

abstract: Saratoga Races; Third Day
lead_paragraph: Large as had been the attendance on the two previous days of the meeting -- that of the third day exceeded it. The grand stand, capacious as it is, was crowded to overflowing, by elegantly dressed ladies, who then took possession of the steps in front, leading to the lawn, to which all the gentlemen were driven when the stand was filled. The show of equipages was also brilliant in the extreme. The receipts for day tickets, and independent entirely of season badges, and members' tickets were on the first day a trifle over $3,000; on the second, (Thursday,) $3,700, and on this, the third, considerably over $4,000 -- the interest culminating as the meeting progressed. And here we may add, in parenthesis, that on Saturday, the last day, that the attendance again increased in numbers and brilliancy, the receipts were over $5,000, which is a sufficient proof of the deep interest felt by the public in the meeting, and the satisfaction manifested at the admirable manner and high-toned style in which it was managed throughout.

abstract: -The St. Louis journals, of Friday, contain verbatim reports of the examination of Mr. GEO. B. SMITH. SMITH, whose business is that of drygoods clerk, it appears, was Grand Secretary of the so-called Order of American Knights, and instead of having been inveigled into its membership, he seems to have been prominent as a promoter of its doctrines -- which doctrines, it is now alleged, contemplate a combination with the rebels of the South to break up the American Union. SMITH professes to repent of his fellowship with the Knights, and his professions ought to be of some value. He broke his oath of allegiance to the United States when he joined the Knights. He swore falsely when he took his vows of fidelity to the Order. He perjured himself when he became an informer against his fellows. And now he desires the privilege of forswearing his allegince as a citizen once again -- when some new Order of Knighthood attracts his fancy. Can another such man be found to bring supporting evidence of this great conspiracy?
lead_paragraph: -The St. Louis journals, of Friday, contain verbatim reports of the examination of Mr. GEO. B. SMITH. SMITH, whose business is that of drygoods clerk, it appears, was Grand Secretary of the so-called Order of American Knights, and instead of having been inveigled into its membership, he seems to have been prominent as a promoter of its doctrines -- which doctrines, it is now alleged, contemplate a combination with the rebels of the South to break up the American Union. SMITH professes to repent of his fellowship with the Knights, and his professions ought to be of some value. He broke his oath of allegiance to the United States when he joined the Knights. He swore falsely when he took his vows of fidelity to the Order. He perjured himself when he became an informer against his fellows. And now he desires the privilege of forswearing his allegince as a citizen once again -- when some new Order of Knighthood attracts his fancy. Can another such man be found to bring supporting evidence of this great conspiracy?

abstract: If the intelligence which we publish this morning from the Upper Potomac does not make us thoroughly acquainted with the actual situation, it at least throws some additional light upon the movement of our own troops, and make apparent some of the probabilities of the new campaign in which the Army of the Potomac unless all the signs beguile us is to take its full share.
lead_paragraph: If the intelligence which we publish this morning from the Upper Potomac does not make us thoroughly acquainted with the actual situation, it at least throws some additional light upon the movement of our own troops, and make apparent some of the probabilities of the new campaign in which the Army of the Potomac -- unless all the signs beguile us -- is to take its full share. Our correspondent at Frederick City necessarily writes under a reserve; but it will be seen by a reference to his letter that vast preparations are going on in view of a great engagement. Whether he correctly places the enemy's main force around the district of South Mountain, we cannot well judge; but it seems as if the movements on the part of both armies pointed to the certainty of a decisive battle north of the Potomac. The news dispatches from the same quarter speak of the probability of a diversion by EARLY toward Wheeling. There is a report (unauthenticated) that LONGSTREET has joined EARLY. Possibly, the most important feature of the news is the report that Gen. HUNTER has been superseded, and that SHERIDAN is in command. The latest report points to the probability of the coming battle being fought at or near Middlebury.

abstract: -- The Brig.-Gen. GARRARD who commanded a a brigade of cavalry under Gen. ROUSSEAU during his late brilliant expedition, is A. KENNER GARRArD, formerly of Cincinnati. He is the second son of Mrs. Judge MCLEAN, and is a graduate of West Point. He was captured in Texas through the treachery of TWIGGS, and was exchanged a year later, when he was appointed Colonel of the "Halleck" Regiment of volunteer cavalry, recruited in this state. He is aged about 36 years, and is a man of fine character and ability. His elder brother, Col. ISRAEL K. GARRARD, commanding the Seventh Ohio Cavalry, greatly distinguished himself in East Tennessee. The younger brother, Col. JEPTHA D. GARRARD, aged about 25, graduated at Yale College in 1858, and now commands a regiment of colored cavalry in Gen. BUTLER's Department. Brig.-Gen. GARRARD received his promotion about eighteen months ago.

abstract: Invasion and Pennsylvania Militia
lead_paragraph: It is over a month since the rebels began their annual invasion of Pennsylvania and Maryland. It is nearly a month since they actually threatened Baltimore and Washington, and since the New-York militia were called upon to go to the assistance of the distressed citizens of the "Keystone State." During the whole of the interval which has since elapsed, the said citizens have not been for one moment free from panic. Large numbers of them have remained absent from their homes either as refugees in the fortified towns, or engaged in the pastoral occupation of driving their flocks and herds toward the northern part of the State, or in any other direction that promised safety from the raid. And during the whole of this period, too, it must be confessed, the soil of their State has never been entirely free from what is termed the "polluting tread of the invader," or, in other words, the presence of a greater or less number of ragged marauders, commonly called "raiders." More than a week ago, about three hundred of them burned a town of considerable size, containing probably four times as many able-bodied male inhabitants as the whole attacking force, and one of the incendiaries being caught after the main body had departed, was duly "stamped to death" by the "enraged citizens."

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Matanzas at this port, we have New-Orleans papers to the 31st  ult. We are indebted to the Purser of the Matanzas for favors. There is nothing further from ...
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship Matanzas at this port, we have New-Orleans papers to the 31st ult. We are indebted to the Purser of the Matanzas for favors. There is nothing further from Admiral FARRAGOT's station at Mobile, excepting a single reference to his purpose to commence operations. Gen. CANBY has issued an order which declares that all able-bodied male citizens, between the ages of 18 and 45, are to be enrolled for service in the militia. Neutrals are moreover to be enrolled as a local police. Those found physically disqualified for field service, but yet fit for garrison duty, are to be organized for local military duty. Deserters from the enemy are not to be enlisted, but are to be sent, not over the lines, but beyond the limits of Gen. CANBY's command. Persons liable to Confederate conscription are not to be permitted to go beyond the lines, and if found either directly or indirectly giving aid to the enemy, or otherwise conducting themselves as enemies of the Government, they are to be held as prisoners of war, and sent beyond the limits of this department. The families of those engaged in the rebel service are not to be permitted to be sent within these lines, but are to be turned back by the pickets, or if they arrive, are to be sent back. Refugees are to be received, and their wants supplied, but all such are to be sent to Cairo. The practice of giving passes to those wishing to go beyond the lines, and allowing them to select their own time and route, is condemned by this order as productive of evil, and is prohibited for the future. The first, section provides that this order goes into operation immediately.

abstract: Hadley, Prof, Tribute to, by C L B
snippet: Hadley, Prof, Tribute to, by C L B
lead_paragraph: To the long list of martyrs in this war of Liberty, another name beloved among scholars is now added. Prof. HADLEY was one of those men whom this country can poorly spare. He was a scholar in the highest sense; with a mind so sensitive to truth, a judgment so candid and unbiased on all questions brought before it, with such patient powers of acquisition and such rich acquirements, that all who knew him expected noble fruits in his future gatherings in the great field of knowledge. Whatever opinion he settled upon, one felt it was formed under the pure influence of truth itself, and with no possible regard to any other consideration. He was but young, and has left behind no permanent memorial of himself, except in the lessons impressed upon the minds of his pupils in the Union Theological Seminary, and the affection and admiration of his friends. His great learning and long-polished and sharpened intellect, have been laid down in the service of his country, and shall appear no more among men. He had long desired most ardently to take part in this war for human rights, and had even attempted to enlist, but was prevented by various obstacles. Since June, he has been laboring in the service of the Sanitary Commission, at the front, for the benefit of the sick and wounded soldiers. In this noble work he was stricken down, and died -- as he would have prayed to die -- at the post of duty.

abstract: Probability of
lead_paragraph: A German Confederacy, embracing Denmark, seems to be among the strange possibilities at this time, in the political future of Europe! England, who has urged her friend into a fight, and then turned the cold shoulder in the time of utmost need, may be compelled to see her old ally in fraternal unity with her enemy. It would be a wonderful instance of retribution if the German Confederacy should become a great naval Power, and hold the keys of the Baltic, and rival Great Britain, because British diplomacy had promised and threatened, and then weakly abandoned an ally. It seems too striking an instance of poetic justice to be possibly true. We fear also it is too great a change to be at once effected.

abstract: Washington National Intelligencer on Grant's Campaign
snippet: Washington National Intelligencer on Grant's Campaign
lead_paragraph: -The Washington National Intelligencer of Saturday contained an article which seems to have caused some perturbation in certain circles at the National Capital. We suppose the great length of the article was what produced the panic, for we see nothing else alarming about it but its length. It is a sketch of Gen. GRANT's campaign from the Rapidan to the James, with a catalogue of the battles fought, and a discussion of the relative merits of the various lines of advance upon Richmond. The conclusion of the whole is that GRANT's campaign has been "most unsuccessful." We supposed from what we had heard that the Intelligencer contained some most astounding revelations of a military character; but its statements of fact are perfectly familiar to every newspaper reader, and its discussion as to routes is not only stale and stereotyped, but utterly profitless. As to the unsuccessfulness of the campaign, the Intelligencer will probably revise and retract its opinion twenty years from now.

Mr. WILKS was the leading editor of the London Star, and dropped dead on the platform while words of eulogy upon our country were coming from his lips. We have received from London the following notes concerning him:

abstract: -- Mr. A. MORTON, the eminent manufacturer of Gold Pens, has at length been compelled by the continued advance in nominal values, caused by the inflation of our Currency, to advance the prices of his goods. He has stood out through many months, incurring heavy losses. In the hope that the end of the War would speedily enable him to boa[???] that he had sold his Pens throughout at Peace prices; but he gives notice to-day that he can stand out no longer, and must henceforth charge enough for his goods to cover their cost. This is termed an advance in prices, but not quite accurately. Every farmer can buy one, a dozen, or a hundred of MORTON's Pens for less Produce, every manufacturer for less Cloth, every Workman for less Labor, than in 1860. It is simply a readjustment of nominal to actual values. We hope to hear that his trade is unaffected by it; for we hold it no man's true interest to buy any more than to sell goods for less than their honest cost. -- Tribune, July 12.

abstract: An interesting discovery has just been made at Angerville, in a property belonging to M. BERRYER. A laborer in digging brought to light a stone coffin, in the form of an angel, containing the remains of a human skeleton reduced to dust, Several articles ...
lead_paragraph: An interesting discovery has just been made at Angerville, in a property belonging to M. BERRYER. A laborer in digging brought to light a stone coffin, in the form of an angel, containing the remains of a human skeleton reduced to dust. Several articles of value were likewise in the coffin. M. BERRYER, unfortunately, was not at once apprised of the discovery. But he succeeded in recovering a large bronze bowl, beautifully sculptured; the fragments of a silver basin, completely oxydised; a large chased gold ring, but wanting the stone which had been set in it (this was a work of the Lower Empire;) a very large horn comb, richly ornamented; some broken glass vessels; and a coin of the realm of the Emperor GRATIAN. This coffin, discovered hot far from a very ancient road, appears not to have been alone. M. BERRYER has given orders to dig the ground all round, to discover whether it was not a burial place at the last period of Roman dominion in Gaul.

abstract: SUPPOSED FATAL CAR ACCIDENT -- THE DRIVER ARRESTED FOR NEGLIGENCE. -- About 1 o'clock yesterday morning LEWIS HOLSTEIN, residing at the corner of Grand and Elizabeth streets, was run over by car No. 40 of the Third-avenue Railroad Line, in Printing House-square. We obtain the following statement of the affair from the report made by Capt. THORNE, of the Twenty-sixth Precinct, yesterday, at the Central Police Office: HOLSTEIN went aboard a down car at the corner of Third-avenue and Sixty-fifth-street, and rode down on the front platform. When opposite Tammany Hall he told the driver that he wished to alight, and asked him to stop the car. To this request, the driver, JOHN BAGLAN by name, paid no attention. HOLSTEIN then jumped from the platform, and in doing so fell on the track. The wheels of the car passed over his right leg, crushing and fracturing it in a horrible manner. The injured man was taken to the Station-house, and thence to the New-York Hospital, where he was pronounced to be in a very critical condition. BAGLAN, the driver, was arrested by Officer C. MURPHY, and yesterday Justice HOGAN committed him to the Tombs to await the result.

abstract: region, of
lead_paragraph: Not the least important of the advantages offered for residence by our Atlantic cities, is their proximity to the most charming natural retreats, to which we can easily escape during the intervals of business, and where we can replenish our fountains of vitality, exhausted by the feverish drain of over-effort. Ranges of mountains hover jealously near our coasts, and give prolific birth to a family of the loveliest streams and lakes. Notwithstanding the enormous physical proportions of our continent, its infinite variety is equal to its extent; and the universal presence of the railway makes it easy in a few hours to relieve any tedium of sameness in any section, by flight to another of totally different character and aspect.

abstract: DEBUT. -- Mr. Moss will not close his season at WALLACK's without making a liberal contribution to the American stage, by restoring to it the charming actress Miss OLIVE LOGAN. This lady's rentree may almost be called a debut. It is six years since Miss LOGAN appeared on any stage, the interval having been passed in Europe under circumstances that have been highly favorable to the study of society and its mirror -- the stage. Few artists can boast of the accomplishments and personal advantages of Miss LOGAN. Hence, her appearance on Mr. WALLACK's boards is looked forward to with unusual interest. The event will come off on Monday next, and the medium will be a new five-act comedy of the present time. Miss OLIVE LOGAN is a sister of the celebrated tragic actress Miss ELIDA LOGAN.

abstract: Militia, a
lead_paragraph: There are a good many valuable lessons to be learned from the great Pennsylvania "raid," but the most valuable are perhaps those which it affords as to the uses and defects of our militia system. Everybody has been convinced by it that we ought to have a large, well drilled, well organized, and well armed militia in every State, to form a sort of reserve to the regular army, and insure safety for life and property during the absence of the latter in the field. Most people are satisfied that if the exigences left behind by the convulsion through which we are now passing, should call for the maintenance of a large standing army, it will prove in the highest degree dangerous to our liberties, unless there is behind it a still larger body of citizen soldiery, to act as a counterpoise and check to it. On all these points, Copperheads and Unionists, Democrats and Republicans are pretty well agreed. Some want the militia kept up as a protection against the rebels; others as a protection against the dangerous classes at home; others against "LINCOLN's tyranny," but all think it ought to be kept up. Gov. SEYMOUR got a bill through the Legislature last session, organizing the National Guard, and we believe he is endeavoring now, with as much persistence as there is in him, to put it into execution.
headline: {'main': 'A National Militia.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A National Militia.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Attack on
lead_paragraph: Secretary STANTON appears again this morning as an official telegrapher, and has the fortune to send good news to the country. He officially transmits an official dispatch, sent to the Confederate Secretary of War by the rebel Commander at Mobile, announcing an attack upon that city by the Union fleet, under Admiral FARRAGUT. From this it appears that seventeen Union vessels passed Fort Morgan, which commands the harbor of Mobile, on Friday last, and on that day were approaching the city, which is not yet announced as in our hands. There seems to have been a very heavy fight between our vessels and the rebel forts and gunboats. Only one of our monitors is reported sunk by Fort Morgan; but terrible havoc appears to have been played among the enemy's vessels. The famous iron-clad rebel ram Tennessee, about which we have heard so much and so frequently for the last two years, surrendered after a desperate engagement. The Selma was captured. The Gaines was beached near the hospital. "The Morgan is safe, and will try to run up to-night," says he. Such is the doleful tale told by Major-Gen. MAURY to the rebel Secretary of War. Beside this, Admiral BUCHANAN, naval, Commandant-in-Chief, has lost a leg, and is a prisoner in our hands.
