abstract: We have glorious news from Mobile this morning. It announces an attack upon the defences of the city and the rebel fleet on Friday last; and comes in the shape of an official dispatch from the rebel Commander at Mobile to the rebel Secretary of War.
lead_paragraph: We have glorious news from Mobile this morning. It announces an attack upon the defences of the city and the rebel fleet on Friday last; and comes in the shape of an official dispatch from the rebel Commander at Mobile to the rebel Secretary of War. It is transmitted to the country through Secretary STANTON. It appears from Gen. MAURY's dispatch that on Friday last Admiral FARRAGUT, with seventeen vessels, (fourteen gunboats and three monitors,) steamed up the mouth of Mobile harbor to Fort Morgan, which defends it, and that an action ensued between the rebel fort and vessels, and our fleet. The rebels report that Fort Morgan sunk one of our monitors; but on the other hand admit that their great cuirassed ram, the Tennessee, surrendered after a desperate engagement, in which Admiral BUCHANAN lost a leg and was taken prisoner. Beside this, the Selma was captured; the Gaines was beached, and only the Morgan is reported safe and trying to escape. It was further reported by the rebel General that the Union fleet had approached the city, and was attacking other works; but its surrender or capture is not yet announced.
headline: {'main': 'THE REBELLION.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE REBELLION.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: There is a peculiar appropriateness in the address of the Geneva people which we publish this morning. It is the voice of Republican Europe formally expressed as to the intent and aim of the struggle in which we are engaged. It is the utterance of that voice from the seat of free thought in modern Europe.
lead_paragraph: There is a peculiar appropriateness in the address of the Geneva people which we publish this morning. It is the voice of Republican Europe formally expressed as to the intent and aim of the struggle in which we are engaged. It is the utterance of that voice from the seat of free thought in modern Europe. It is the expression of a community who have themselves endured the agonies of secession at intermittent periods which date three hundred years back. It is the soberly-recorded judgment of a people who have stuck to a federal compact founded on a pure republican basis, in the face of an endless succession of exterior and interior revolutions. It is the protest of liberalized Europe against the disruption of a Government which has been the glory of the Helvetian Republic, and the hope of oppressed nationalties throughout the world.
headline: {'main': 'The Voice of Republican Europe.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Voice of Republican Europe.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The returned veterans of this regiment are stationed at the Arsenal in Portland-avenue. They are all reenlisted men, having served faithfully for three years. The officers returned are as follows: Colonel, NELSON SHAURNAN; Adjutant, _____ Woolsey; Surgeon, Dr. Stubbs; Co. A, Capt. Stoutenbrough; Co. B. Lieut, Smith; Co. C, Lieut. Steers; Co. D, Lieut. Ward; Co. E, Capt. De La Paturelle; Co. F, Capt. Bennett; Co. G, Lieut. Kellett; Co. K. Lieut. White, The regiment was stationed at Key West for two years, and was then transferred to Louisiana, where they participated in the siege of Port Hudson and in the battle of Irish Bend. They were sent, in connection with the Nineteenth Corps, to Maryland, and thence came to Brooklyn. They number 172 men. In addition to this, 22 came on yesterday, having been furloughed by Lieut.-Gen. GRANT, of whom the men speak very highly.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing, Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will ...
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing, Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, complied from sources many of which are otherwise, inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

lead_paragraph: Local military matters for the past few days have been very dull. Recruiting progresses but slowly, still it seems to be steadily increasing. The new barracks at the Battery are doing well, though not quite as well as was expected. A number of aliens are enlisted daily, and, to the credit of the managers at the Barracks be it said, the men are protected in their rights, and they are not allowed to be swindled.

abstract: Address to United States
lead_paragraph: JAMES MAXWELL was examined before United States Commissioner OSBORN yesterday, upon a charge of perjury. It appears that MAXWELL, being called upon for the monthly return of manufactures of the firm of MAXWELL & STEWART, of which he was member, swore that in March last they only manufactured $80 worth of goods, whereas the value of goods manufactured by the firm in March was alleged to be over $1,000. Some testimony was taken, and the further hearing adjourned.

abstract: EXTENSIVE ROBBERIES OF PASSENGERS ON A HEDSON RIVER BOAT -- ONE OF THE THEIVES ARRESTED. -- On Saturday night last, during the trip of the steamboat St. John, from Albany to this City, quite a number of occupied state-rooms were entered by means of burglars' instruments, and the pockets of the passengers therein were rifled of all the money that could be found, amounting in the whole to several thousand dollars. Gold watches and other valuable property were also taken. Mr. PETER COSG[???]GVE, of No. 100 Third-avenue, being unable to obtain a room, lay down in the saloon, and when he awoke he found that $700 in Treasury notes had been taken from him. Among the victims who suffered during that night, are GEORGE WEST, of No. 263 Broome-street, a man named SULLIVAN, and several others. There was in fact quite a gang of thieves on board who, no doubt, acted in concert, and according to previous arrangement. When the boat arrived at her dock in this City a man named BARNEY MCCLOSKEY, was arrested by Officer HULL, of the 57th Precinct, on suspicion of being one of the offenders. Before he was secured he threw away a pair of burglar's nippers. When MCCLOSKEY was searched an old-fashioned gold watch, with a small chain attached, one $20 bill on the Goshen Bank, New-York, one $10 bill on the Unadilla Bank, one $10 on the Cayuga Bank, and several other bank bills of smaller denominations, were found in his possession. He was taken before Justice HAGAN and committed to the Tombs.

abstract: The Democrats everywhere are very confident of victory in the pending. Presidential canvas. Their exultation may be premature, but it is sincere. They evidently believe they are going to win. And they base their expectations of success mainly, if not entirely, on the dissensions which prevail in the Union ranks.
lead_paragraph: The Democrats everywhere are very confident of victory in the pending. Presidential canvas. Their exultation may be premature, but it is sincere. They evidently believe they are going to win. And they base their expectations of success mainly, if not entirely, on the dissensions which prevail in the Union ranks. They point to the fact that whole classes of professed Union men feel under no obligation to support the Union ticket. One denounces Mr. LINCOLN because he did not abolish Slavery soon enough -- another because he assumed to touch it at all. One refuses to vote for him because he keeps Mr. BLAIR in the Cabinet, -- another because he keeps somebody or anybody else. FREMONT runs against him because he disregards the Constitution, and WENDELL PHILLIPS speaks against him because he recognizes that instrument at all. Some censure his lenient method of treating the people of the Southern States, -- others his babarous and inhuman mode of carrying on the war. One set of politicians vilify him for not admitting the Southern States at once into the Union, and WADE and DAVIS, with equal malignity, brand him as a usurper for proposing to admit them at all. Every unsuccessful applicant for office, -- every volunteer adviser whose counsels have been rejected, -- every wiseacre who fancies he was created to conduct the Government, and who finds Mr. LINCOLN indisposed to accept his dictation, -- the whole of that countless brood of political seers who knew from the beginning how "this thing" was coming out, and who found the President incredibly and idiotically deaf to their warnings and their threats, -- are all now combined to vindicate their prescience and gratify their resentments by voting against him. And upon this concurrence of disappointed and underrated malignants, the Democrats base their hopes of a party success.
headline: {'main': 'The Presidential Election.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Presidential Election.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Banishment of Disloyal Citizens
lead_paragraph: The telegraph this morning informs us that a number of disloyal citizens of Columbus and Paducah, Ky., with their families, have arrived at Cairo on their way to Canada, having been banished by order of Gen. PAYNE.

abstract: A NEW STEAM ENGINE. -- Pacific Engine Company No. 14 received a new steam-engine last week. It was built by JOHN SMITH, New-York, and cost $5,000, toward which the City of Brooklyn appropriated $5,500, the remainder being made up by the Company. The apparatus was tried yesterday, and threw a stream over the Pierrepont House, and in all other respects proved satisfactory to the Company.

abstract: Sentinel and New-York Daily New on Peace; and Richmond Sentinel on Peace
snippet: Sentinel and New-York Daily New on Peace; and Richmond Sentinel on Peace
lead_paragraph: The Opposition press insist that the rebels are willing to treat for peace, and denounce the President for repelling their attempts to do so. The rebel press are evidently doing what little they can to strengthen their Northern allies in urging this pretence. The Daily News, which is the organ of the Peace Democracy in this State, quotes an article from the Richmond Sentinel, which it designates the "organ of Mr. DAVIS," and, therefore, a representative of the "sentiment and policy of the Confederate Administration," to prove that the South is quite willing to negotiate, and that, too, on terms which the Government and people of the United States ought to consider satisfactory. The News quotes the following paragraph as quite conclusive on that point:

abstract: Russell's, Earl, Speech on Foreign Policy; Pensions and Salaries of Officials
snippet: Russell's, Earl, Speech on Foreign Policy; Pensions and Salaries of Officials
lead_paragraph: A lately-issued Parliamentary return contains a list of pensions and salaries paid out of the Consolidated Fund. Passing over the familiar amounts of annuities to the Royal Fund, and coming to the pensions for naval and military service, we find that the Duke of WELLINGTON receives a pension of 4,000 a year; Earl NELSON, 3,500; the Countess NELSON, 1,500; Earl of MORLEY,(in trust for Earl AMHERST,) Viscount St. VINCENT and Lord HARDINGE, each £3,000; the Earl of CAMPERDOWN, £2,997 9s.: Viscount CAMBERMERK, Viscount EXMOUTH, Lord SEATON, Lord KEANE and Lord RAGLAN, each £2 000; Lord RODNEY, Dowager Lady RODNEY, Lord GOUGH, Lady RAGLAN, Sir W.F. WILLIAMS, Sir H. HAVELOCK and Lady HAVELOCK, each £1,000. The pensions for civil services include one of £4,000 to GRANVILLE JOHN PENN, which, under an act of Parliament, passed in the thirteenth year or the reign of GEORGE III., was granted to the heirs of WILLIAM PENN forever. A similar sum is awarded annually for life to Viscount EVERSLEY, late Speaker in the House of Commons. Viscount CANTERBURY and Lord COLCHESTER each receive £3,000 a year. Lord GLENEIG and Mr. DISRAELY each £3,000 the Right Hon. STEPHEN LUSHINGTON, £1,500; Sir GEORGE CLERK, £1,200. Next come the pensions for judecial services. Four ex-Lord Chancellors, Lords BROUGHAM, ST. LEONARDS, CRANWORTH and CHELMSFORD, each receive £5,000 a year. The pension of Lord LYNDHURST was paid up to the date of his death, and is entered at £3,778 14s. 8d. The two ex-Lord Chancellors of Ireland, the Right Hon. JOSEPH NAPIER and the Right Hon. FRANCIS BLACKBURN, are consoled for the loss of office by an annual £3,092 0s. 6d. There are four retiring Judges and one Vice-Chancellor, to wit, Sir THOMAS ERSKINE, Sir JOHN COLERIDGE, Sir HUGH HILL, Lord WENSLEYDALE, and Sir JAMES WIGRAM, each in the receipt of £3,500 a year. The payments to Viscount AVONMORE, principal Registrar of the Court of Chancery in Ireland, were last year £4,199 19s. The hereditary pensions include one of £4,000 to the Duke of MARLBOROUGH, £2,160 to the heirs of the Duke of SCHOMBERG, and £1,200 to the Marquis of BATH. And now as to salaries. That of the Speaker of the House of Commons is £5,000, while the Sergeant-at-Arms gets £1,200. Lord MONTEAGLE, as Comptroller-General of the Exchequer, is in receipt of an annual income of £2,000. The Lunacy Commissioners, of whom there are six, get £1,500 a year. The High Commissioner to the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland receives £2,000 per annum. The salary of the Lord Lieutenant of Ireland is £20,000; Maynooth College costs £26,360; while the annual contribution to each of the Queen's Colleges in Belfast, Cork, and Galway is £7,000. The salary of the Lord Chief, Justice of England is £8,000; the Chief Justice of the Common Pleas and the Chief Baron of the Exchequer, each £7,000; the Lord Chancellor, the Lords Justices of Appeal and the Master of the Rolls, each £6,000; the three Vice Chancellors, the Common Law Judges and the Judge Ordinary of the Divorce Court, each £5,000. The Judge of the Admiralty Court receives £4,000 a year, and the Assistant Judge of the Middlesex Sessions £1,200. The salaries of the Metropolitan Police Magistrates and the County Court Judges vary from £1,200 to £1,500 a year.

snippet: Gift of Cane from Grateful Wounded Soldier
lead_paragraph: DANGEROUS COUNTERFEIT ON THE CORN EXCHANGE BANK. -- On Monday evening an attempt was made by several persons to pass well-executed counterfeit $2 bills, on the Corn Exchange Bank. JOHN MORAN and MICHAEL JACKSON, both of whom say they reside at No. 525 Sixth-avenue, were taken into costody by Officers CAFFREY and RINN, of the Sixteeth Precinct, on the charge of having passed one of the spurious bills on Mrs. ISABELLA DONNELLY, of No. 231 Tenth-avenue also passed another of the counterfeit at the refreshment saloon of Mr. RICHARD PARREL, No. 253 West Twenty-sixth-street. Mrs. DONNLEY and Mr. PARREL appeared yesterday before Justice LEDWITH at the Jefferson Market Police Court, and made affidavits against the accused, and the Magistrate committed both in default of $1,000 bail on each complaint. There are several other complaints to be made against the prisoners forthe same offence.

abstract: Information has been received here that Gen. AVERILL, after overtaking the enemy at Moorefield, attacked and utterly routed them, capturing between five and six hundred prisoners, including Gen. JOHNSON, who subsequently escaped, and his whole staff, with their headquarters, colors, all the rebel artillery and trains, and a large quantity of small arms. Gen. McCAUSLAND himself barely escaped by flying into  the mountains.

abstract: No later intelligence than that published yesterday morning was received, up to the hour of going to press, from the scene of Admiral FARRAGUT's daring and successful initial operations against Mobile; but the utmost confidence is felt by the military authorities that the hero of New-Orleans will capture the rebel city within a short time. Confidence is expressed that the report of the sinking of the Tecumseh will prove to be unfounded, as it is believed that there were no guns in the rebel forts capable of penetrating her armor.

abstract: The United States ship-of-the-line Vermont, Commodore H.R. THATCHER, U.S.N., Commanding, arrived at this port last evening from Port Royal 2d inst. Arrived off Charleston Bar same day, at 2:30 P.M., where she received on board, for passage home, the men from the various vessels composing the blockading fleet off that city whose terms of enlistment had expired. She sailed thence the same evening, at 6 P.M., for this port. Arrived off Sandy Hook on the evening of the 8th and anchored.

abstract: The barracks which have so long disfigured the lower part of the City Hall Park are at last to be removed. For a long time they have been a perfect nuisance, and their removal will give general satisfaction to every one. Yesterday the work of destruction commenced, and the men worked with a will, and as though it was a satisfaction to them to be able to rid the Park of the miserable shanties which have so long disgraced it and the City. They will probably be entirely removed by the end of this week, and the public will again have the satisfaction of seeing the Park, if not as handsome as it once was, and as it should be, at least clear.

abstract: Presentation to
lead_paragraph: A very pleasant little affair took place at Police Headquarters yesterday morning. While Inspector JAMES LEONARD was giving the usual instructions to a class of new Policemen, Mr. WILLIAM T. BLODGETT, Chairman of the Committee of Arms and Tro phies of the Metropolitan Fair, accompanied by Mr. STEVENS, also of the Committee, President ACTON, and a number of gentlemen, stepped into the room and for a few moments interrupted the "instruction." Mr. BLODGETT, after a short and complimentary speech on behalf of the Committee of Arms and Trophies of the late Sanitary Fair, presented Mr. LEONARD with a very handsome Colt's revolver. The pistol is a splendid specimen of art. It is one of Colt's best six-inch pistols, the barrel silver-plated and beautifully chased, and the chamber gold-plated. The stock is beautifully wrought in pearl, and silver-mounted. It is contained in a beautiful rosewood case, lined with velvet, which also contains the necessary moulds, wrench, etc. The weapon bears the following inscription:

abstract: New-York vs Bronxville
lead_paragraph: A most interesting match between these clubs was played yesterday on the Bedford Cricket Ground, Brooklyn, the game being with the New-York second eleven and the first eleven of the Bronxville clubs. The play on both sides was highly creditable to either party; but the New-Yorkers proved too strong a team for their opponents, who are all "Old Countrymen," hailing from Sheffield, from whence many celebrated cricketers have sprung. The players from Westchester are a new club, and this being their maiden match in this country, were well cared for by the New-York players. The score stood as affixed:

abstract: State Quota and Recruiting in Rebel States
snippet: State Quota and Recruiting in Rebel States
lead_paragraph: The Board of Supervisors yesterday came to the conclusion, by a formal vote, not to send agents to the rebel States for the purpose of recruiting among the accessible colored population. The decision is one supported by various valid reasons, without requiring a recourse to be had to imputations on the fighting qualities of the negro. The disaster suffered by the Ninth Army Corps on the morning of Saturday, the 30th ult., is not a pertinent argument against the policy of employing black troops -- not more pertinent, at least, than the accidental success of the colored division would have been a sound argument on the other side. The majority of the Supervisors seem to think otherwise; or rather, instead of taking the simple ground that negroes are not to be had in numbers sufficient to make up more than the merest fraction of the call for reinforcements, they choose to make a party vote of it. This is unwise, to say the least. It should be sufficient, surely, for those who have the responsibility of dealing with this question, to know that dependence upon negro recruits, even in the matter of filling up the enrollment lists, would prove a delusion. Now, the simple fact is that our armies have not yet got at more than the scum of the black fighting material of the South. And, even were that material within the reach of recruiting officers -- what proportion of it could be turned to account before the 5th of September?

abstract: The late Prime Minister delivered a speech during the recent debate on the address of the new Ministry. He said he was of opinion that, serious as was the situation of Denmark at the present crisis, it could not by any means be termed "desperate." He should not even feel disposed to admit it to be desperate if the capital were occupied by the enemy and the hostile flag waved from every fort of Copenhagen. History showed that Berlin, Vienna and Paris had before now fallen into the hands of a conqueror. In one contingency alone should he consider the position of Denmark so desperate as to necessitate peace at any price, and that was in the event of the Danish fleet no longer having full command of Danish waters. He did not, however, believe in the likelihood of this taking place. Alluding to the future condition of Denmark, the speaker continued:

abstract: Wealthy Men and the Public Service
snippet: Wealthy Men and the Public Service
lead_paragraph: A correspondent, whose letter we published on Monday, commenting on what we recently said as to the unwillingness of our wealthy men to take office in the public service, ascribes much of this reluctance to the fact that those who might be disposed to do so, would find themselves so surrounded by persons so inferior in character and standing as to make their situation intolerable. In other words, that there is not much hope of getting a very large number of public offices filled by respectable men until all can be filled by them at the same time -- a consummation which, we need hardly say, we are not likely to witness. There must be a beginning. Some one of those who have made large fortunes, and have their time at their own disposal, must set the example of answering any call the country may make on them, before we shall ever see the practice become general. A wholesale rush of millionaires into the public service is not, in the nature of things, to be looked for all at once. The class has been too long excluded from it, and has lost the habits and ambition of office too thoroughly for it to be possible to recall them to the old paths in a day or even in a year. But this, so far from rendering it more excusable for those to whom a direct and personal appeal is made to do a given duty, to refuse to answer it, renders it really less so. If it were the fashion for rich men to devote their time to the service of the State, there would not be half as much merit in any one doing it, or half as much necessity for doing it as now. If a rich and honorable man takes office now, he is doubtless likely to find himself in the company of a very unsavory set, but this is part of the burden he is called on to bear. We should like to know, to recur to the contrast we drew in our former article on this subject, whether the young men who enter the army in thousands, always find their company select, of their associations agreeable; whether the camp is not, in a vast number of cases, an odious and repulsive change from refined and happy homes. When they set out to march and fight, and it may be live and die, in the society of Tom, Dick and Harry, of men of all grades, conditions and characters, it is certainly not asking too much of their well-to-do relatives, whose age or money, or lack of martial enthusiasm, saves them from the hardships and perils, of the field, to call on them to take charge of the Government offices at home, or sit in the Legislature, even at the risk of finding themselves now and then cheek by jowl with a hack, or adventurer, or jobber, to whom politics, like shoe or soap vending, is a trade, and nothing more.

abstract: A NEW MODE OF RECRUITING. -- We publish, in other columns, an account of a new mode of recruiting introduced by the inventive community of Boston. A quiet system of foreign enlistment seems to have been established by the enterprizers, and several shiploads of German and other recruits have been recently landed in Boston harbor -- promising great relief to the substitute market. The story is altogether curious.

abstract: Navy; The, and its Fortunes; Exploits of
snippet: Navy; The, and its Fortunes; Exploits of
lead_paragraph: Admiral FARRAGUT, in his present operations at Mobile, has inflicted an amount of damage upon the naval force of the rebels that is only equaled by the havoc he played with their fleet at and below New-Orleans when he captured that city. At that time, as will be remembered, beside their wooden vessels, fireships, turtles, and so on, which were all demolished, they had three iron-plated rams nearly completed at the city, which were fired and destroyed on FARRAGUT's approach. In last week's action at Mobile, though we have no idea that the rebels gave us anything like a full account of their naval losses, they acknowledge the capture by us of the iron-clad ram Tennessee, the capture of the Selma, the beaching of the Gaines, and the attempted flight of the Morgan, whose final fate they do not narrate.

abstract: CURIOUS STORY OF A PHOTOGRAPH. -- When the war broke out a young man belonging in this city enlisted, and carried to the field with him a photograph of his betrothed. He was taken prisoner, and confined for a long period in the Libby Prison at Richmond. While there, one of the rebel officers on duty, happening to have seen the photograph, appropriated it, and refused to return it to the owner. The officer seemed infatuated with the likeness of the Northern beauty; and, in order to have opportunity to talk about her, made himself the instrument of many kindness to the captive. At last the young soldier was exchanged, and in due time joined his regiment. During a resent battle he was at the front, and seeing a rebel officer very prominently engaged in directing his command, the Massachusetts soldier leveled his piece and shot the rebel Commander. Our men advanced at the same moment, and on passing the spot where the dead rebel lay, the soldier recogzized him as the officer who had appropriated his lady-love's photograph. The officer's pockets were searched, and the missing picture found. The above is no romance, but a veritable incident among the many curious ones which crowd the history of the war. --Boston Journal, Aug, 8.

abstract: A carman named WM. GALVIN, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital, from the effects of being run over by his own cart on the 8th instant. Deceased was driving rapidly, when one wheel of his cart came in contact with some obstruction, and he was thrown under the vehicle. He was a native of Ireland, aged 50 years....JAMES SAMPSON, a boy aged three years, residing with his parents at No. 118 Barrow-street, died from injuries received by reason of having been run over by one of the wheels of a large truck. He died in a few minutes after the accident. Coroner RANNEY held an inquest in both cases. The verdict in each case was accidental death.

abstract: and Davis Manifesto; National Intelligencer on
snippet: and Davis Manifesto; National Intelligencer on
lead_paragraph: The National Intelligencer finds much to commend in the manifesto of Senator WADE and H.W. DAVIS against President LINCOLN, which we published a day or two since. In styling it, however, a "Republican Manifesto," and in treating it as a Republican document, having the sanction or at least the toleration of the Republican party, that journal, it seems to us, somewhat transcends the facts of the case for the sake of giving a factitious weight to the document itself. We have seen nothing whatever to justify the assumption that either the Republican party, or the Union party, either indorse the sentiments of this extraordinary manifesto or regard the action of its authors in issuing it at the present crisis as anything but a treacherous and malignant attempt to stab a President whom they profess to support.

abstract: The demonstration in favor of making Gen. McCLELLAN the candidate of the Chicago Convention took place last evening at Union-square. It was one of the largest political meetings ever held in the City of New-York, there being fully 30,000 persons in attendance. It was characterized with the greatest enthusiasm throughout. The speeches, however, were of the most common-place character, and the speakers generally without reputation.

abstract: Invasion; Gov. Curtin's Message
lead_paragraph: Gov. CURTIN's Message to the Legislature of Pennsylvania, the essential portions of which we publish to-day, is a State paper of no little interest. And if it has been partially inspired by a feeling of resentment at the jibes of unsympathizing sister States, it is none the less readable on that account. We might be inclined mildly to protest against being supposed to have indulged (speaking for this community) in any aspersions on the spirit and energy of the border people of Pennsylvania, which are not warranted by the Governor's own admissions in the paper before us. But it is hardly worth while to further contest the debatable ground. Only, let us ask Gov. CURTIN's attention, in the best spirit and temper, to one or two salient points in his own message, and let us ask him if these do not present a warranty for some of the comments which the helpless indifference of a portion of his commonwealth seemed to invite during the heat of these raids?

abstract: INJURED MAN EXAMINED BY THE CORONER. - HENRY MILEY the horseshoer, who was badly injured on the morning of the 4th inst, by being beaten with a hammer on the head, by a fellow-workman, named JAMES BRANNIGAN, is lying in a critical condition at his residence, No. 424 West Forty-second-street. It will be remembered that MILEY refused to join the horseshoers' strike, and that BRANNIGAN, one of the leaders of the gang of strikers, followed him toward his home and beat him in a most unmerciful manner. Coroner RANNEY yesterday took the ante-mortem deposition of MILEY, who testified that BRANNIGAN struck him on the head with a hammer, knocked him down, and while prostrate, struck him twice more. The jury rendered a verdict against BRANNIGAN, and the latter was committed to the Tombs to await the result.

abstract: MOBILE. -- The news from Admiral FARRAGUT to-day continues highly favorable. He has passed or captured all the regular fortifications of Mobile Bay, and was well inside of it on Monday last. On the 5th, as the rebels informed us, his fleet passed Fort Morgan; on the same day Fort Powell was evacuated and blown up, and on Monday, Fort Gaines surrendered, after bombardment. We shall not wonder if he has been able to push up close to the city, which, however, is very strongly fortified on all sides by earthworks.

abstract: GEN. AVERILL. -- This gallant young officer is finely sustaining the splendid reputation he acquired during his long and extraordinary campaign in Southwestern Virginia, and previously in the eastern part of the same State. His operations on the line of the Potomac and in the Shenandoah Valley since the commencement of the raid have been characterized by vigor, rapidity, spirit, and, in all instances but one by a complete success. We have this morning an official dispatch from Gen. AVERILL, confirmatory of the account we had previously published of his victory over the rebel raiders under MCCAUSLAND, BRADLEY JOHNSON and GILMOR. The enemy was overtaken and attacked at Moorfield, Hardy County, Va., at daylight, on Sunday morning last; where his command was completely routed, his artillery and 420 prisoners, with their horses, captured, and MCCAUSLAND himself only escaped by flight to the mountains. This is certainly what may be styled an "effective pursuit" of the enemy; and those who read the letter we gave yesterday from AVERILL's command will understand somewhat of the great difficulties under which it was achieved. This is the second large fight AVERILL has had with the rebel cavalry within the last fortnight, beside the numerous skirmishes he has had with them, and the steady pursuit among the mountains that he has kept up. At McConnellsville, on the 30th ult., he attacked, with a thousand of his cavalrymen, three thousand of the enemy's horse, and defeated them, after which, up to this last victory, he has harassed them night and day. With such splendid officers as SHERIDAN and AVERILL operating on this line, we should hear of no more rebel raids north of the Potomac.

abstract: Rumored Resignation of
lead_paragraph: Rumors continue to reach us from Washington of actual or impending Cabinet changes. One of the latest asserts that Secretary STANTON has resigned, and that his resignation has been, or will be, accepted. Upon what ground, or for what reason, this alleged action is taken, we are not aware. Possibly something may have happened to make it necessary, or at least expedient. But lacking knowledge of any such cause, we venture to hope that the rumor is without foundation. We may be entirely mistaken in our estimate of the practical working force and vigor of the President's Cabinet, but, in our judgment, that body cannot afford just how to lose, the ability, industry and indomitable energy which Mr. STANTON brings to the administration of the War Department.

abstract: Gen. Logan's Statement of Losses, July 22
snippet: Gen. Logan's Statement of Losses, July 22
lead_paragraph: THE GREAT BATTLE BEFORE ATLANTA. -- We have at last Gen. LOGAN's official statement of the actual losses on our side, and of the computed losses on the enemy's side, in the great battle fought before Atlanta on the 22d of July, in which HOOD made his first great essay as Commander of the rebel army of the West. The desperateness with which HOOD went into the conflict has its illustration in divers ways. He made no less than seven attacks upon our lines during the day, each recoil being succeeded by a new effort, until his shattered columns could no longer be brought to time. Eighteen stand of colors were captured from him. He left 5,000 stand of arms in the field. We buried of his dead, or delivered up of his wounded, 3,220, and made prisoners of 1,017 more, including 33 officers of high rank. What proportion of the rebel wounded were taken care of by their own men can only be matter of imperfect estimate. Gen. LOGAN, however, says that it cannot be less than ten thousand in all. The total loss on our side was 3,521. The journals here which echo the Richmond press, in describing this as a victory for HOOD, might study Gen. LOGAN's official returns with profit. They will find that a few more such victories will reduce HOOD's responsibilities considerably. He will have few to look after but himself.

abstract: -- A very serious accident, resulting from the careless use of firearms, occurred yesterday, in the pawnbroker's office of Mrs. WOOD, in Grand-street. Two boys, named HENRY CRAWFORD and HUGO HIRSCH, were playing with a pistol, which it was supposed was not loaded. Unfortunately, however, for one of the lads, the weapon was charged with powder and ball. During the sport, young CRAWFORD pointed the pistol at the head of his companion, and discharged it. The ball entered the face of HIRSCH, causing a compound fracture of the jaw, and passing inward, lodged under the root of the tongue, beyond the reach of a probe. The injured lad was conveyed to the New-York Hospital, where he now lies in a critical condition.

lead_paragraph: FATAL ACCIDENT. -- Coroner FARREL, of Jersey City, held an inquest yesterday on the body of a colored man, named JOHN RUMLEY, who was killed the evening previous. Deceased attempted to jump on one of the New-Jersey Railroad cars, but, missing, fell to the ground, and had one of his legs crushed by the wheel passing over it. The injured man was conveyed to the Alms-house Hospital, where he died during the night. A verdict of accidental death was rendered. RUMLEY resided at No. 100 West Fifty-ninth-street, New-York.
headline: {'main': "NEW-JERSEY.; Arrivals in the City. Pennsylvania. GOV. OURTIN'S MESSAGE TO THE LEGISLATURE IN-SPECIAL SESSION. A Naval Mystery. THE CALORIC ENGINE TO PROPEL THE DICTATOR It is quite useless to conceal the fact that no steam power will propel the great ocean iron-clad Dictator on her forthcoming European voyage. The Ericsson caloric engine will be the motive power, and the manner in which its progress at the Delamater Iron Works has been effected, without the slightest intimation on the part of the press that anything mysterious was going on, shows that the contractor attaches undue importance to secrecy. If the engine fails as fail we are assured it cannot the country must know the fact some time or other; if it succeeds, premature announcements cannot impair, but must necessarily enhance, the triumph of genius. abstract: Later intelligence from Mobile, received through rebel sources, confirms the most sanguine expectations respecting the success of Admiral FARRAGUT in his attack upon the fortifications of that city. Forts Gaines and Powell surrendered on the 8th; apparently without further attempts at defence, and, with the exception of one vessel, the entire rebel fleet, in which such unbounded confidence was placed by the rebels, had been destroyed, captured or beached. With a very faint attempt at the old style of bluster, Gen. MAURY declares that the citizens of Mobile are determined to defend that city to the last. But we are inclined to think that this will depend a great deal more upon Admiral FARRAGUT than Gen. MAURY.
lead_paragraph: Later intelligence from Mobile, received through rebel sources, confirms the most sanguine expectations respecting the success of Admiral FARRAGUT in his attack upon the fortifications of that city. snippet: at McClellan Meeting, New-York; Speech at McClellan Meeting, New-York; at McClellan Meeting, New-York; at McClellan Meeting, N Y.; at McClellan Meeting, New-York; Speech at McClellan Meeting, New-York; at McClellan Meeting, N Y; at McClellan Meeti...
lead_paragraph: Last night the unterrified Democracy of the City Of New-York made their grand initial demonstration in favor of Gen. GEORGE B. MCCLELLAN for the nomination as the candidate of the Chicago Convention for the Presidency of the United States. It was held at Union-square. The purpose being so important in its nature, no pains or expense were spared to make the meeting imposing both in numbers and spirit. Four platforms for speakers were erected, each of which was decorated with the American colors, Chinese lanterns, and canvasses inscribed with mottoes and the names of battles in which Gen. MCCLELLAN had participated. The music of abrass band, the firing of cannon, the appearance of firework erections which gave promise of pyrotechnic displays, the efforts made in the Wards to bring out the boys, all tended to bring together a meeting of large magnitude, amounting in the aggregate to about thirty thousand. But, however the meeting may have been successful in numbers and spirit, it was an utter failure so far as ability was concerned.

abstract: Statements of Union Failures
lead_paragraph: It must be remembered that the statements being put forth by the Copperheads as to the general failure of the Union arms in all our campaigns, and as to the total lack of anything like success in the conduct of the war, are simply bits of political electioneering trickery. These statements of theirs are preposterously absurd on their face; but by constant iteration of them, by holding up only the dark side of everything, they hope to make them believed by the thoughtless, and to produce universal discontent and gloom throughout the country, while trying to make it credited that they are the shining lights who will yet bring salvation.

abstract: Emigrant Hospital, Ward's Island; Corner-stone Laid
snippet: Emigrant Hospital, Ward's Island; Corner-stone Laid
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon the foundation stone of the new State Emigrant Hospital on, Ward's Island was laid with appropriate ceremonies. At 2 o'clock P.M. the steamer left Castle Garden, having on board the Commissioners and a large number of distinguished guests, specially invited to be present on the important occasion. Among the gentlemen on board were, THURLOW WEED, Senator MANGER, Monroe County; Senator STRONG, Brooklyn; Senator LAMBIER, of Albany; J.V.L. PRUYN, of Albany; Mayor WOOD, Brooklyn; Ex-Mayor KALBFLEISCH, Brooklyn; Commissioners of Police, Messrs. ACTON and BERGEN, Superintendent KENNEDY, Collector BARNEY, Dr. GARISH, &c., &c.

abstract: Meeting in New-York
lead_paragraph: The McClellan meeting last night in Union-square was very large -- one of the largest political gatherings ever held in this City. As a demonstration of numbers it was entitled to all the importance that the Opposition press will claim for it, -- and was certainly quite as formidable as the most zealous advocates of MCCLELLAN's nomination for the Presidency could have hoped. But this is all there was of it. The speaking amounted to nothing at all. Hon. JOHN B. HASKIN was the most distinguished and the most eloquent person who attempted to address the gathering, -- and no one of the thousands present deemed it worth while to listen to what he said.
headline: {'main': 'The McClellan Meeting.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The McClellan Meeting.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: At a meeting of the official Board of the old John-street Methodist Episcopal Church, recently held, a series of resolutions were offered and adopted, in substance, that the existing debt of the society -- $13,000 -- be raised by subscription, and that the "time-honored temple" be preserved, "not only on account of its antiquity, but because it is needed to accommodate the inhabitants in the lower part of the City," and that an effort be made to pay the debt by the 30th of October, that the society may be able to celebrate their ninety-sixth anniversary unembarrassed.

abstract: While journeying on the cars, my stomach became badly deranged, causing severe pain in my head. Had it been on the water it would have been called sea-sickness. A lady sitting by me, knowing my condition, reached out a bottle saying, "take a swallow." I did so, and in less than five minutes my trouble was ended The medicine was "Coe's Dyspepsia Cure," and from the effect it had upon the stomach, and what I have learned of it since, I think it must be an excellent remedy for sea-sicknessand dyspepsia. MRS. SAMUEL FIELD.

abstract: Ireland; Emigration to United States; Debate in Parliament on
snippet: Ireland; Emigration to United States; Debate in Parliament on
lead_paragraph: In the House of Commons, July 28, Lord E. HOWARD rose to call attention to the subject of emigration to the United States of America, in reference to the prolongation of the war now raging in that country; and moved an address for papers. The noble lord said that the gravity of the subject should be his justification for bringing it forward at that late period of the session. In consequence of his position as a member of the Distress Relief Committee at Glossop, one of the towns most affected by the cotton distress, he found it became necessary to have a census made of the population in that district, and one of the the elements of the census was the question of emigration. He found that a large emigration had prevailed from that district, and in the course of inquiries he found that it was also large from the cotton districts in general. In 22 towns taken promiscuously, from the cotton districs -- and he did not know that they were the largest towns -- within a few months, setting aside single men, of married men alone not fewer than 1,400 had left this country for the United States of America, of whom 780 had deserted their wives and families, leaving 2,160 persons chargeable upon the rates. Besides that, he had the names of 14 persons who had emigrated from one locality in Manchester within three months and of these, no less than twelve had also deserted their wives and families, and probably, most of these were young and newly married men. These circumstances tended to show that there must be some deep cause at work. It would not meet the argument to say that they had emigrated, intending afterward to send for their wives and families; because he knew that there had been instances in which the manufacturers of America had sent for manufacturing hands to England, paying the expenses of the voyage for themselves and their families, the agreement being that the amount so paid should be afterward deducted from their wages. He had further to say that great caution was exercised by the agents who were instrumental in taking these people out of the country, for they did not give written documents or money until the emigrants were sale on board the vessels which were to convey them to America. He would instance another case which showed how the emigrants were disposed of. He held in his hand a letter relating to the case of a man who was a private in the Manchester Volunteers. The letter was written by an officer of the corps, who stated that a young man in his company had been decoyed off to New-York. A companion of his had seen an advertisement in a newspaper stating that they would have permanent employment at the rate of 35[???]. per week. An interview was held between the young men (the volunteer) and the agent, and the former agreed to go to Canada. The statement made was that on their arrival in Canada employment would be obtained immediately. On this understanding six people were induced to emigrate. On arriving at Liverpool conveyances were waiting so carry them to the ship, and on being taken on board the Virginia they found that that vessel was bound to New-York, but they were told that on arriving there they would be reshipped for Canada. When they arrived at New-York they were provided with refreshment, and they were informed that they would be conveyed to Long Island. Before they were taken to Long Island the agent disappeared, and on arriving at the island two of the men enlisted. The young man in question made his escape, and hid himself in the hold of a Canadian steamer and returned to England, where he described himself as a "miserable victim of Yankee rascality." [Hear.] Nor was that a solitary instance. There was a case now before the Foreign Office, in New-York, with a letter or credit for £. He was drugged, robbed, and while in a state of stupefaction was enlisted into the Federal Navy. He believed that in all the large passenger ships sailing from Liverpool agents of the Federal Government were on board with a view of recruiting young men. He was told of such a case two days ago in which an emigrant was treated by a person on board an American passenger ship and invited to a house in New-York. He accepted the invitation, he was drugged with whisky, and the next thing of which he became conscious, was that he was a Federal soldier. He deserted, but was captured and placed in jail. If they opened any newspaper and referred to the police intelligence similar cases would be found. He had seen the case of a man from Hull who had been taken by force to an island near New-York -- no doubt Long Island -where he met with several other Englishmen who had been impressed info the Federal service, and it was complained that these outrages were constantly committed. There was another case in which a man received a check for £40, which sum he received from the Federal Government, and he was now in GRANT's army before Richmond. Mr. Justice FITZGERALD, in a charge he delivered the other day, referred to the terrible frequency with which such acts are committed. He had also in his possession a proclamation issued by the Lord-Lieutenant of Ireland adverting to the subject. All these facts showed how patent the matter was. Many of these unfortunate men who had been enlisted in the Federal army would never return, for they had become food for powder. He thought it a great mistake to urge on emigration from this country, and he understood from a good authority that labor was becoming so scarce in England that if manufacturing should become active in Lancashire, the employers of labor would be embarrassed for want of laborers -- [hear, hear] -- and therefore if the manufacturers could find it possible to work their mills only to a small extent, it would be wise and prudent to do so. In addition to the large emigration which had been going on from this country, he found from the papers that about ten thousand persons had left Switzerland to join the Federal army. But to show what folly it was to emigrate at present, he would refer to a letter from a young man who was settled in Massachusetts, and he said that his wages of $9 a week were only equal to 16s., and that he was doing much worse than if he remained in England. He added that provisions and clothing were at enormous prices, and that his wages were not worth half as much as when he first went out to that country. Within the last few days papers had been presented to Parliament, and what was there stated was very much like a melo-drama, excepting that the jocose part was very little indeed. The scene opened with the conduct of two rascals who were acting with another, whom he might describe as an imp of the devil, in inducing people to emigrate to America from Ireland for the purpose of undertaking railway work. Not long ago, a cargo of these people, he might call them slaves, went out to America for the purpose of being employed on a railway, but on the voyage it was discovered that he had only one eye, and that although he would make a very good "navy," he would not make a good soldier, and he was charged by the person in charge of the emigrants with having deceived him, so that it was evident that the men were required for soldiers. These people, upon arrival in America, were drugged with whisky, and then placed in the police cells, and they afterward found themselves in the Federal army. Many of them appealed to the British minister and to the consuls, and the end of it all was a large printed correspondence between the Government of America and the Foreign Office. It was said the premium was $700 for a recruit, but the wretches who enlisted these men managed to pocket as much as $500 of that sum themselves. In stating these facts to the House of Commons, he might add that he did not wish to make any charge against the American Government, but that he only desired to warn his fellow-countrymen against going to America at the present time, and he thought the only way to prevent them from being deluded, was to state these facts in that House. Lord LYONS, in one of his dispatches, stated that the number of British subjects who were serving in the United States army and navy was very considerable, and that complaints were constantly being received of the way in which those enlistments had been made. It seemed that no pains had been spared in investigating the cases brought to the knowledge of Lord LYONS, and every effort had been made to recover the men; but in few instances had the inquiries ended satisfactorily. [Hear, hear.] These men, who were kidnapped into the army of the United States, were both ignorant of and indifferent to the objects of the war, and yet if, under such circumstances they deserted, they were shot or otherwise punished. He wished to be fair to all parties, and, therefore, he must state that Major-Gen. DIX had taken steps to prevent, as far as he possibly could, this system of kidnapping from occurring again, but he feared that justice would not be done to those persons who had already been entrapped. He thought the persons who were engaged in obtaining these men for such a war were parties to the committal of murder. [Hear, hear.] Though he did not mean to say one word against the United States Government or their army -- for he cared not what form of Government the United States might have, whether it were monarchical, constitutional or republican, so that it protected industry and international right, and so that it did justice, and gave proper means for the employment of the energies of mankind, and was one under which human beings could with happiness live -- yet he hoped Her Majesty's Government would do all in their power to prevent these evils which were connected with emigration from going on. But what had become of the relatives of these people? There must be many in America whose earnest wish, he would venture to express was for peace. [Hear, hear.] What was the opinion of the man who was most competent to give an opinion? Earl RUSSELL, in his dispatch of 27th May, 1864, referred to the case of Irishmen enlisted at Portland and Boston, and gave the opinion, founded on the letters of Her Britannic Majesty's consuls, that these enlistments had been effected by the most fraudulent means, and in gross disregard of the neutral rights of this country. It appeared that the unfortunate emigrants when they landed at Portland, were plied with drink, and so induced to listen to the inducements which were held out to them. The recruiting sergeants gained access to them through the agency of the police authorities. These and other circumstances had induced him (Lord E. HOWARD) to bring the matter before the House. He had applied to the agents at Liverpool, but they had professed themselves unable to give any assistance in the matter. He hoped that Her Majesty's Government would use every exertion to distribute useful information on this subject throughout the country, so as to prevent our poorer fellow-subjects from being inveigled by American agents.

abstract: The official dispatches of the Secretary of War announce that the captare of Mobile is reported by rebel deserters. While implicit reliance is not to be placed in this report, there is nothing improbable in it. It is well known that an opening large enough for the passage of blockade-runners was left in the ...
lead_paragraph: The official dispatches of the Secretary of War announce that the captare of Mobile is reported by rebel deserters. While implicit reliance is not to be placed in this report, there is nothing improbable in it. It is well known that an opening large enough for the passage of blockade-runners was left in the harbor obstructions placed below Mobile, and it Is not at all unlikely that Admiral FARRAGUT, who always goes in to win, and who was probably thoroughly posted in respect to its position, after destroying the rebel fleet, immediately forced his way through to the city, and brought it under the domination of his guns. The official report of the gallant Admiral, which, is now expected every hour, will clear up all suspense.

abstract: Parliament on the United States, Mexico, >amp;c.
snippet: Parliament on the United States, Mexico, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: If the legislation of the British Parliament concerned us as much as do its debates, we might have the satisfaction of finding that our affairs could be managed for us by a foreign legislative body quite as well as by a Congress at home. We do not, it will be seen, come in for any unnecessary mention in the prorogation speech from the Throne; but it is satisfactory to find that the Queen, having first announced her friendly relations with the Emperor of China, declares her firm purpose to maintain a strict neutrality between the belligerents in this country. This, taken by itself, must be held to be pleasing intelligence, and we do not know that it is rendered less so by the discussions relating to this country, and to the American Continent generally, which immediately preceded it. We give prominence to two of these discussions in our news columns to-day; one brought up by an easy-tempered Catholic member of the House, Lord EDWARD HOWARD, bearing upon subsidized emigration to the United States, and the other by Mr. KINGLAKE, on the subject of the recognition of the Archduke MAXIMILIAN as Emperor of Mexico.

abstract: THEFT OF A PHYSICIAN's HORSE AND GIG. -- At a late hour on Wednesday night, Dr. EMIL VON SCHOENING, left his horse and wagon standing in front of a house in Ninth-avenue, near Fortieth-street, while he went in to visit a patient. In a few minutes he returned to the street to find his horse and vehicle missing. The Dr. immediately went to the Twentieth Precinct Station-house, where he stated his case to the Sergeant in charge, at the same time describing his lost property. Officer ANDREWS was at once dispatched in pursuit of the horse-thief, and in about an hour after, that official saw a man driving at a furious rate in the upper part of Ninth-avenue. The horse and wagon which the man was driving answered the description that the Doctor had given, and ANDREWS, after much difficulty, succeeded in securing the driver, and also the property with which he was trying to make his escape. They were all taken to the Station-house, where, at a late hour, Dr. Von SCHOENING identified the horse and wagon as his. They are valued at $300. Yesterday the thief was taken before Justice LEDWITH, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, where the prisoner gave his name as HENRY DUFFY, 21 years of age, and his residence in Forty-second street, between Eleventh and Twelfth avenues. He was committed to answer in default of $1,000 bail.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington, news. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current, topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: A CHOWDER PARTY ON A SPREE. -- A chowder party, composed of the Emmet Social Club, of New-York, stopped at Tunison's Hotel, on the Coney Island road, yesterday afternoon, and several of the members being rather elevated, got to quarreling. One of the men drew a pistol, intending to fire upon some person of his own club with which he was quarreling, but instead of hitting him, struck two other men in no way connected with the party. The men injured are WM. H. GOODRICH, connected with the Provost-Marshal's office of the Third Congressional District of Brooklyn, who was shot through the foot, the ball lodging in the ankle. The other man, named JOHN COUGH, is a hostler, employed by TUNISON, who was shot in the thigh. The wound is not serious. Mr. T.B. PRENDERGAST narrowly escaped. The ball which struck GOODRICH went through his fingers and caused a slight flesh wound. The party had been to Sheep's Head Bay, and were quite noisy on the return. The proprietor, Mr. TUNISON, closed his house as soon as he ascertained that the party were in the state they showed themselves to be in. The row occurred on the front porch. The hostler was attending to the horses of a party of gentlemen at the time he was shot. Last evening, as the chowder-party returned, the stages which contained them were stopped by the police of the Forty-first Precinct, and a man named WILLIAM RILEY, who was identified as the one who fired the pistol, was arrested, and locked up to await examination.

abstract: The Street-Cleaning Commission, consisting of the Mayor, Comptroller and City Inspector, held a meeting at the Mayor's Office yesterday, when they discussed Mr. D.D. BADGER'S proposal to clean the streets for $300,000 per year, providing he can have free use of the Croton water, free dumping grounds, and also have the manure.
lead_paragraph: The Street-Cleaning Commission, consisting of the Mayor, Comptroller and City Inspector, held a meeting at the Mayor's Office yesterday, when they discussed Mr. D.D. BADGER's proposal to clean the streets for $300,000 per year, providing he can have free use of the Croton water, free dumping grounds, and also have the manure. The Comptroller and City Inspector said the proviso debarred the commission from contracting with Mr. BADGER, because the special privileges would make an addition to the compensation, and, therefore, make it exceed the limit fixed by the Legislature. The City Inspector added that the use of the Croton could not be guaranteed by the commission, for he himself was not allowed to use it now, even in Broadway. The Mayor was in favor of entertaining Mr. BADGER'S proposal, believing that the street manure properly belonged to the contractor who gathered it up, and that the expense limited by the Legislature relates only to moneyed compensation. The Commission unanimously agreed that it would be fruitless to invite proposals again on the specifications which have twice failed to induce a bid of $300,000 or less per year for a five years' contract. The Commission then adjourned.

abstract: Government Loans and Rhapsodists on Finance
snippet: Government Loans and Rhapsodists on Finance
lead_paragraph: There is a class of journalists among us who consider it essential to their standing as loyal supporters of the Government to assail private capitalists and banking associations that fail, as is alleged, to come up to the mark in the matter of investing in Government stocks. "In this city," says one of these ardent theorists, "there is a large class of financiers whose patriotism commenced and ended with lending the Treasury fifty millions of dollars." What class other than the public and private bankers of New-York can be thus indicated we are at a loss to know. And the charge so applied is sufficiently absurd on its face to need no refutation. But it is not with the mere incorrectness of the statement that we care to trouble ourselves. It is rather the singular confusion of ideas that underlies this rhapsodizing method of dealing with the stern, unbending laws which regulate financial science.
headline: {'main': 'The Rhapsodists on Finance.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Rhapsodists on Finance.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- As we anticipated,the Farini hoax at the Falls came to an and yesterday. As a speculation, it was a lamentable failure -- the whole thing having been bunglingly managed. The island on which he was "discovered" is called "Robinson's Island," and is about 150 feet across by 200 feet in length, thickly wooded with [???]ines, the lower end being about 100 feet from the [???]erge of the cataract. The story that FARINI "waded from the American side" is a most preposterous one. He might as well attempt to walk up the Horse Shoe Fall. A venturesome man could reach the island without much difficulty,  however, by following the ledge of rocks on the opposite side, and swimming a short distance.

abstract: SUN STROKE. -- About 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon a loboring man named GEOFFREY O'CONNELL was prostrated by the heat in Union-avenue, Eastern District. He was conveyed to the Forty-fifth Precinct Station-house and received medical attendance, without beneficial effect, and he died in about an hour thereafter. Policeman NICHOLSON, of the Forty-fifth Precinct, was overcome by the heat in Fourth-street. He was conveyed home and properly cared for, and will undoubtedly recover.

abstract: It will be remembered that at the late supplemental draft, held in the Fourth District Capt MILLS, Provost-Marshal of the Fifth District, was drafted from the township of Bloomfield, and that the Board of Enrollment decided that he was liable to be held, notwithstanding his office. The matter was also submitted to Col. BUCHANAN, Acting Assistant Provost-Marshal-General, for his opinion, which has brought out the decision that Capt. MILLS must be held, and that the ruling of Capt. BROWN was correct -- Provost-Marshals not being considered in the military service of the United States. -- Newark Advertiser, Aug. 11.

abstract: Yelverton Case; Mrs. Yelverton's Letter and House of Lords' Decision
snippet: Yelverton Case; Mrs. Yelverton's Letter and House of Lords' Decision
lead_paragraph: The romantic YELVERTON marriage case was finally disposed of by the House of Lords on the 28th ult. It will be remembered that the Court below decided in favor of the validity of the marriage of the Hon. Maj. YELVERTON with Miss LONGWORTH, and that the former appealed to the House of Lords against this decision. Lords WENSLEYDALE, CHELMSFORD and KINGSDOWN gave judgment that the validity of the marriage was not proved and that the decision of the Court below should be reversed. The Lord Chancellor dissented from this view and gave it as his opinion that the marriage was a valid one. Of course the decision of the majority prevailed and the judgment of the Court below was reversed. Steps were taken to prevent this judgment being made final in Scotland. Considerable sympathy was evinced for the lady, who, in a letter to the Times, announces her intention to carry the case on in Scotland to a final issue.

abstract: The Paris correspondent of the Times, writing on the 28th save: "A poor victim of the American war was brought up to the correctional Police-court yesterday; he was a poor lad, 16 years of age, whom all human miseries seemed to have stricken. Puny and stinted in growth, his cadaverous and pinched features looked smaller still under a mass of long woolly hair. He stated his name to be HENRY MULLER. He had been placed by somebody in the hands of the police, and, as he had neither dwelling nor means of existence, had been detained as a vagrant without any place of abode. When interrogated, he said:

abstract: Queen's Speech on Proroguing Parliament; Debate in British Parliament on Recognition; Mexico; Debate in Parliament; Recognition of
snippet: Queen's Speech on Proroguing Parliament; Debate in British Parliament on Recognition; Mexico; Debate in Parliament; Recognition of
lead_paragraph: In the House of Commons on the 28th of July, Mr. KINGLAKE asked the Under Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs what portion of the States and Territories of Mexico had been hitherto subjugated by the invading army of the French; and by what means, and in what districts, the authority of the Mexican Republic had been de facto superseded by the so-styled "empire" of the Archduke FERDINAND MAXIMILIAN; and whether the First Lord of the Treasury or the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs had given the French Government any reason to expect that Her Majesty would be advised to recognize the Archduke as Emperor of Mexico, before his authority would be de facto established in the main portion of the States and Territories now held under the sway of the President JUAREZ.

abstract: -- The steamer Francis Skiddy, which reached here at an early this morning from New-York, reports that it met its consort, the Vanderbilt, going down the Hudson, opposite Crumb Elbow, about 12 o'clock. The Vanderbilt was proceeding under its own motive power, and making good "time." Capt. GEO. O. TUPPER had previously gone to New-York, and prepared a dry dock for the reception of the "wounded" boat. Its repairs will be completed with all possible dispatch, and this popular Troy favorite will be "in line" again by Saturday or Tuesday next. Meanwhile the Commodore will take the place of the Vanderbilt, and be here to-morrow morning. The Commodore is a familiar craft to river travelers and will look "as natural as life" during its brief occupancy of the routes. -- Troy Times, Aug. 10.

abstract: -- A dispatch from Washington concerning the late accidental explosion at City Point, made it appear that the "boat Lewis had caught fire, but the flames were put out by a wrecking tug." This was an error of the telegraph. The fact was that the boat Lewis, a fire and wrecking tug, commanded by Capt. JAMES CROSSLEY, ran to the shore, and extending her hose threw six streams on the fire, putting out the flames, and thus saving the entire ammunition in the building.
lead_paragraph: -- A dispatch from Washington concerning the late accidental explosion at City Point, made it appear that the "boat Lewis had caught fire, but the flames were put out by a wrecking tug." abstract: -- The death at Key West of WALDO ABBOTT, Esq., formerly of this City, has just been announced, Mr. ABBOTT was a man of rare purity of character, and was endeared to a large circle of friends, here and in New-Haven, by his many social and Christian virtues. The influence of his labors in behalf of Mission and Sabbath Schools will long be felt in New-Haven and throughout New-England. His papers on Sunday Schools, contributed through the columns of the Independent, and subsequently collected in book form, are recognized as one of the most valuable and popular books ever published on the subject. Self-sacrificing to the last, among the sick and dying at Key West, be finally himself succumbed to the power of the epidemic. He leaves a wife and two children.
lead_paragraph: -- The death at Key West of WALDO ABBOTT, Esq., formerly of this City, has just been announced, Mr. ABBOTT was a man of rare purity of character, and was endeared to a large circle of friends, here and in New-Haven, by his many social and Christian virtues. abstract: and Davis Manifesto, the
lead_paragraph: We copy in another column a very excellent article from the National Anti-Slavery Standard, upon the dangers to which the cause of the country and of Freedom is exposed, from the overweening impatience of its over-zealous friends. The article has special reference to the manifesto recently issued by Messrs. WADE and DAVIS, which is certainly the most extraordinary political paper of the day. It is by far the most effective Copperhead campaign document thus far issued, and we are not in the least surprised to find that it is to be issued in that form, and widely circulated by that party, for the purpose of aiding in the defeat of President LINCOLN. It seems difficult to believe that the authors of this paper could have deliberately aimed at such a result. For years they have been among the most prominent and effective advocates of, Republican principles. They have taken a leading part in all the acts and measures of the Republican party. They have sustained its doctrines, defended its action and sustained its candidates. The party has given them its confidence, covered them with honors, and placed in their hands ample power and influence.

abstract: FOUR HUNDRED DOLLARS FOR ONE YEAR MEN. -- At the meeting of the Chosen Freeholders of Hudson County, a month since, a resolution was adopted to pay the sum of $400 to every volunteer or substitute credited to the County, in anticipation of a call for more troops by the President. In order to compete with localities that are offering much higher bounties, the Board were petitioned on Thursday to increase the amount. They, however, decided that as there was no specified term of service for the bounty offered, the sum of $400 could be paid to men enlisting or going as substitutes for one year. It is presumed that this liberal offer will very materially increase the enlistment business.

abstract: Sketch of Life and Achievements
lead_paragraph: WILLIAM T. SHERMAN was born in Lancaster, Ohio, on the 8th day of February, 1820. His father was the Hon. CHARLES R. SHERMAN, one of the Judges of the Supreme Court of that State. In 1836, at the age of sixteen, he entered West Point as a cadet, and was graduated on the 30th of June, 1840, sixth in his class. Young SHERMAN at once entered the service on graduation, as Second Lieutenant in the Third Artillery, and served in Florida through the Winters of 1840 and 1841. In November, 1841, he was promoted to a first lieutenancy. He was afterward stationed at Fort Moultrie, South Carolina. In 1845, he was sent to California, and remained there in service all through the Mexican war, having reached the grade of Captain.

abstract: RECRUITING IN BROOKLYN.--Recruiting is be- ginning to be dull in this city. The bounties paid by other corporations are higher than here, and the sub stitutes--of which there are plenty--are taken off.
lead_paragraph: RECRUITING IN BROOKLYN. -- Recruiting is beginning to be dull in this city. The bounties paid by other corporations are higher than here, and the sub stitutes -- of which there are plenty -- are taken off. In Tarrytown, N.Y., it appears they pay as high as $900, while here the highest price, thus far, has been $700. The brokers run the men off to the place they can get the highest price. Only a few men here enlisted yesterday, and there is very little prospect now that the quota will be filled without a draft.

snippet: Union of Morrisania vs Empire New-York; Atlantic vs Athletic of Pennsylvania; Continental and Continental Bank Note Company
lead_paragraph: The above match (the last of the series) took place yesterday, and resulted in another victory for the Atlantics, by 43 to 16 -- being a total in the four matches of 230, against 47 for our clubs. There was a large number of persons present yesterday to witness the match -- probably two thousand -- among whom was a fair proportion of ladies, and the whole was conducted in the most respectable manner. The Athletic players made a fine display, both at the bat and in the field; but it was the current opinion that they would be beaten two to one. Mr. MCBRIDE's pitching and Mr. KLEINF[???]ELDER's catching were very good; and, in fact, the only soft spots in the field were MALONE, at second base, and GEATZ, at third base -- the latter being hurt -- both well known as good ones, but unaccountably failing in catching and stopping many balls in this match, by which a large number of runs were obtained by the Atlantics.

abstract: FIELDING was of opinion that one might discuss a given question all the better from knowing something about it. But this is an extravagant view which the thoroughly inde pendent critic naturally discards.
lead_paragraph: FIELDING was of opinion that one might discuss a given question all the better from knowing something about it. But this is an extravagant view which the thoroughly inde pendent critic naturally discards. Here we have a wordy writer in the London Times, and a host of newspaper writers among ourselves who take their cue from that journal, conjuring up without any rhyme or reason a series of imaginary difficulties in the way of a federative system for the neighboring British provinces, from the fact that the question is one altogether Imperial in its nature, and that its settlement must be regulated mainly by considerations of Imperial policy. The colonies, it is alleged, cannot amend their own Constitutions, and there is a great probability, it is hinted, of a collision being the result of the proposed political enterprize.

abstract: THE TRADES AND CITY REFORM.--The warm weather has prevented the meetings of the different trades favorable to the Citizens' Association. It is understood, however, that next week the work will ...
lead_paragraph: THE TRADES AND CITY REFORM. -- The warm weather has prevented the meetings of the different trades favorable to the Citizens' Association. It is understood, however, that next week the work will commence again, and that the different trades will re-commence the agitation of the many questions relative to the interests of the City. The large meeting of the Iron Trade has excited a spirit of emulation among others, which will be evinced between this and the time of election in mass meetings, whereat politicians are ignored and practical intelligent men will be the leading spirits.

By her we receive a brief but satisfactory confirmation of the great success achieved at Mobile by Admiral FARRAGUT. It comes in the shape of a telegram from Gen. abstract: HEWETT has been intrusted with the construction of the fortifications for the defence of Louisville. He has now some two hundred laborers at work, and accessions are daily being made to his fatigue corps. We are assured that the work will be pushed to rapid completion. The plan is very extensive, and, when finished, the works will prove quite formidable. We understand that a force of two thousand contrabands will shortly be employed upon the defences. A large amount of labor is to be performed, and it will require several months to do it. When the work is completed, we will have the satisfaction of knowing that Louisville will be one of the best fortified cities in the Union. We will then no longer start with alarm and tremble at the rumors of rebel raids into our State; but, safe behind our defences, an air of security will pervade the city, and we will mock at all hostile demonstrations made against the emporium of Kentucky. -- Louisville Journal, Aug. 10.

When the work is completed, we will have the satisfaction of knowing that Louisville will be one of the best fortified cities in the Union. We will then no longer start with alarm and tremble at the rumors of rebel raids into our State; but, safe behind our defences, an air of security will pervade the city, and we will mock at all hostile demonstrations made against the emporium of Kentucky. -- Louisville Journal, Aug. 10.
