abstract: The most genial tribute yet paid to the mem ory of NATHANIEL HAWTHORNE is undoubtedly a paper  by MR.EDWARD DICEY, in the July number of Mac-  millan's Magazine, of which periodical Mr.DICEY  was for some time the American correspondent.
lead_paragraph: -- The most genial tribute yet paid to the memory of NATHANIEL HAWTHORNE is undoubtedly a paper by MR. EDWARD DICEY, in the July number of Macmillan's Magazine, of which periodical Mr. DICEY was for some time the American correspondent. His letters were collected in two volumes, entitled Six Months in America, and are distinguished for fairness and impartiality. His acquaintance with HAWTHORNE commenced at Washington in the Winter of 1861, and extended to the limit of Mr. DICEY's stay in this country, including some time spent under HAWTHORNE's roof, at Concord. Mr. DICEY explains how, at Washington, circumstances threw them much together, leading to an intimacy that revealed an interior as different as possible from the icy chill of manner that shrouded to strangers the noivete and child-like simplicity really characteristic of the novelist. The paper is written with intelligence and good feeling, and deserves tranferrence to our journals, as, in the strife of war and other absorbing interests, scarcely justice has been done hitherto to HAWTHORNE in his own country.

abstract: PROVOST-MARSHAL FOR THE SECOND CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICT, BROOKLYN. -- Capt. S.W. WALDRON has been appointed and will enter upon the duties of the office on Monday. Capt. WALDRON entered the service at the beginning of the war, and served upon the staff of Gen. NEWTON, through the Peninsular campaign, under MCCLELLAN. He was promoted to the position of Assistant-Adjutant-General to Brig.-Gen. PRINCE, and also did duty for several months on the staff of Gen. WADSWORTH, Military Governor of Washington. Capt. WALDRON has a fine record while in the service, and will make a good and efficient officer.

abstract: Guiding Star, Havana S S, Launch of
snippet: Guiding Star, Havana S S, Launch of
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon the launch of the new mail steamship Guiding Star took place at the foot of Houston-street, East River, and was most successfully accomplished, at the extensive ship building yards of Messrs. ROSEVELT, JOYCE & WATERBURY. Prior to the hour of 4:30 o'clock in the afternoon, thousands had congregated to witness the event, among whom were the builders above named, and JAMES A. RAYNOR, Esq., President of the New-York Mail Steamship Company, who seemed to take the deepest interest in the whole proceedings. The Guiding Star is a noble vessel, and shows plainly the perfection to which ship-building has been brought in the great Commercial City of New-York. She is Intended for the Havana and New-Orleans mail route, same as the Morning and Evening Star. Her upper decks were crowded, with spectators, The workmen commenced the operations at 4:30, and in ten minutes afterward the Guiding Star slided from her slocks amid the rapturous cheers of the vast crowds assembled. She glided beautifully into her new element, without any obstruction, and not the slightest accident happened to any one.
headline: {'main': 'Successful Launch of Another New Mail Steamship.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Successful Launch of Another New Mail Steamship.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The action of the Supervisors, in deciding to give $100 hand-money to any person bringing a recruit, has already had a good effect in this City, and recruiting has in consequence greatly increased. Brokers find it is a very easy way to make money, and some of them bring in as many as three and four a day. Some of the recruiting officers think that they will now be able to furnish nearly all the men needed, so that if we do have a draft, it will be a very light one.

abstract: Citizen, the Newspaper; First Number of; Citizen, the, Establishment of
snippet: Citizen, the Newspaper; First Number of; Citizen, the, Establishment of
lead_paragraph: THE "CITIZEN." -- The first number of a new weekly journal, published by the Citizens' Association, and entitled the Citizen, appeared yesterday. It is devoted to the many Municipal reforms which the association advocates, and goes vigorously to the work. The objects of the association are thus announced: "Honest, economical and public-spirited City Government;" its motto, "Is he honest? Is he capable?" The paper promises to be an ably conducted and interesting one, and the prospectus states that its columns will exhibit the resources of the country, the progress of arts, manufactures, mining, agriculture, and the triumphs of industry, science and genius. The records of immigration, the development of new territories and the growth of population will be noted. Mechanical inventions and improvements, with occasional engraved illustrations, together with a careful synopsis of City intelligence and general news, will occupy a portion of each issue, so that the reader who sees no other paper may have every week a clear bird's-eye view of the condition and progress of the City, the country and the world.

abstract: The enemy has not yet evacuated Atlanta, though some such movement has been looked upon as probable, for the last ten days. Our army has shifted from the east and north of Atlanta to the west, the extreme left covering the city on the north, while the extreme right now is southwest of the city, running parallel with the Atlanta and Macon Railroad, and near enough, were the country favorable, to command it with artillery.
lead_paragraph: WITHIN TWO MILES OF ATLANTA. GA., August 5, 1864.

abstract: A party of refugees and deserters, not the most trustworthy sources of information, arrived yesterday at Washington, and report that heavy reinforcements have been sent to Gen. EARLY from Richmond. They also bring a report of a serious state of disaffection, amounting almost to mutiny, among portions of the rebel troops, who are said to be restrained with difficulty from deserting and returning home. It would be pleasant to believe these stories.

abstract: London Star on Mexico and Southern Recognition; Empire and Recognition of South
snippet: London Star on Mexico and Southern Recognition; Empire and Recognition of South
lead_paragraph: Viewed in the light of the fact that Gen. URAGA has formally given in his adhesion to the cause of the Archduke MAXIMILIAN, and of the cotemporaneous report that a large portion of the French military force is being withdrawn from Mexico, Lord PALMERSTON's words at the close of Parliament on the question of recognizing the new Government have a bitterly tantalizing meaning. Even the conservative tone of the British Minister, wherein he deprecates the necessity which has compelled the leading European Powers even to entertain the question of recognition, becomes more stinging in view of accomplished facts than if the speech had been one of exultation over the downfall of the republic.
headline: {'main': 'The Mexican Empire and Recognition.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Mexican Empire and Recognition.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: And Vienna Conference on Danish Question
snippet: And Vienna Conference on Danish Question
lead_paragraph: The Vienna Conference has undertaken to effect what the London Conference failed to accomplish -- The solution of the Dano-German difficulty. That is, Prussia, Austria and King CHIRSTIAN have taken the matter out of the hands of the Western Powers, and have set about settling the question in their own way. But though they, as the actual parties to the squabble, have the best right to determine the grounds of compromise, it is not by any means certain that they will be permitted to do so. The conferring diplomats may decide indeed whether the Duchies are to be united in a single State, and whether the Danish sovereign or the Prince of AUGUSTENBURG, or his Russian rival, is to wield its sceptre; but beyond this, they will hardly be privileged to go. England doubtless, taught by past experience, will intermeddle no more in the business Such, however, is not the intention of France The rumor touching the contemplated annexation of the Danish Kingdom to the Germanic Confederation has evidently alarmed NAPOLEON, and aroused him from his apathy. The idea of a Germany with an extensive seaboard and a formidable navy, was not calculated to promote the tranquillity of the Imperial mind, and his Majesty determined to thwart, if possible, the consummation of this scheme. M. DROUYN DE LHUYS was accordingly instructed to address dispatches to the representatives of France at the Courts of Copenhagen, Vienna and Berlin, touching the negotiations in progress at the Austrian capital. These missives convey at once a warning and a menace to the belligerent Powers. The conferring Powers, says the French Minister, must not suppose they are free to act as they think proper because England declines to take part in the negotiations. If the arrangements entered into are contrary to equity and right, the hour of expiation will assuredly come. Should CHRISTIAN the Ninth manifest a greater regard for his personal interests than for the interests of the nation over which he was placed. by the Treaty of 1852 -- should he violate said treaty by ceding to Germany that portion of Schleswig the inhabitants of which are exclusively of Danish origin and character -- on what basis would rest his title to the Danish crown? Germany, of course, may sanction the annexation of a fragment of the Scandinavian race to her Confederation -- but, if she does, that Confederation ceases to be Teutonic, and she tramples on the Treaties of 1815. Now, the French would be the last of European Governments to find fault with Austria and Prussia for disregarding the acts of the Congress of Vienna. France, however, cannot, without protest, permit the desecration of an old right, merely that the pleasure of those Powers may be adopted as a substitute. If the old and written law, which fixes the limits of the Confederation, be cast to the winds, it must be only, on condition that it shall be replaced by the new law of the right of nationalities.
headline: {'main': 'France and the Vienna Conference.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'France and the Vienna Conference.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Gillespie and Vanderwaker, Scull Match at Harlem
snippet: Gillespie and Vanderwaker, Scull Match at Harlem
lead_paragraph: A scull race between GEORGE GILLESPIE and AARON VANDERWERKER, for $50 a side, distance three miles, took place at Harlem on Saturday afternoon. The race was won in twenty-one minutes by VANDERWERKER, who beat his competitor about a quarter of a mile. A challenge for another race was immediately given by GILLESPIE, and accepted by VANDERWERKER, for the same stakes, the race to take place in two months.

abstract: Six refugees and twenty-one deserters from the rebel army arrived here to-day from City Point.  The former left Richmond by stealth on Thursday night and came into our lines. They tell a long story, representing that on Saturday last four trains of twenty cars each arrived in Richmond, bringing a body of troops from Petersburg, said to be a division, and they left immediately on the Central road, to reinforce Gen. EARLY.

abstract: -- There are at the present time in Germany 165 theatres. Of these 19 are really "court theatres," or theatres supported by reigning princes; 12 town theatres of the first class; 28 theatres of the second class; 30 town theatres of the third class, and 67 strolling companies, 20 of which enjoy a very good reputation and are in a satisfactory financial condition. The number of actors, singers and dancers living in Germany is 6,000, and that of the choristers and officials about 8,000.

abstract: Mobile, the principal city and only seaport of Alabama, situated on the west side of Mobile River, immediately above its entrance into the bay of the same name, in lat. 30° 41' 26" N., lon. 88° 1' 29" W.; population in 1850, 20,515; in 1660, about 30,000. The corporate limits extend six miles north and south, and two for three miles west from the river. The thickly inhabited part of the city, however, extends for about a mile along the river, and nearly the same distance back to the westward. The site of the city is a sandy plain,gradually rising as it recedes from the water. The streets are generally regular, well paved and shaded, There are several fine public buildings, among which is a handsome market-house, with rooms for the municipal officers in the upper story. The Customhousehas also accommodations for the Post-office and United States Courts. Among the other noticeable buildings are the theatre, Odd Fellows' and Temperance Halls, Guard-house and tower, and the Barton Academy, occupied by the Public Schools, There are two banks, a savings bank, twenty-three churches, (three Baptist, one Bethel, four Episcopal, eight Methodist, four Presbyterian, and three Roman Catholic, including a fine cathedral, now [1860] nearly completed.) a Jewish synagogue, three orphan asylums, an infirmary conducted by the Sisters of Charity, a city and a marine hospital, several other benevolent institutions, and a literary society with a good library. A medical college was founded in 1859, and has a spacious edifice in course of erection. The suburban villages of Turnerville, Toulminville. Jacksonville, Summerville, Spring Hill, Cottage Hill, &c. near the city, are well supplied with churches and schools. St. Joseph's College, at Spring Hill, and the Academy of the Visitation, (for girls,) in Summerville, are flourishing institutions, under Roman Catholic control. There are many handsome villas and cottages in the suburbs and environs. Mobile is lighted with gas, and supplied with water of unusual purity and excellence, which is brought a little more than five miles, from the foot of Spring Hill. The construction of the Mobile and Ohio Railroad, which is to connect Mobile with Cairo, at the mouth of the Ohio River, and is now (1860) approaching completion, promises to give fresh impetus to its trade. The Mobile and great Northern Road, also inactive progress, will connect it with Montgomery and the roads leading thence to all Darts of the Eastern States. Several city and neighborhood railroads are about to be constructed. Among the industrial establishments are two iron founderies, a resin-oil factory, several ship-yards, a dry-dock, and a great number of cotton presses. The exports of cotton from the port of Mobile for a period of five years, each ending Aug. 31, have been as follows: 1855-'6, 680, 657; 1856-'7, 495, 360; 1857-'8, 515,371; 1858-'9, 681,094; 1859-'60, 789, 057; average of the five years, 632,308 bales. The other exports consist only of lumber, turpentine, resin-oil, &c., and are small in comparison with the amount and value of the cotton. The whole value of exports and imports for five years, ending Dec. 31, was as follows :

The exports of cotton from the port of Mobile for a period of five years, each ending Aug. 31, have been as follows: 1855-'6, 680, 657; 1856-'7, 495, 360; 1857-'8, 515,371; 1858-'9, 681,094; 1859-'60, 789, 057; average of the five years, 632,308 bales. The other exports consist only of lumber, turpentine, resin-oil, &c., and are small in comparison with the amount and value of the cotton. The whole value of exports and imports for five years, ending Dec. 31, was as follows :

abstract: -- On Thursday last, a schooner lying at Green-street wharf, having on board two locomotives, was seized by order of the Government by Quartermaster-General CROSSMAN, and held to await the further action of the authorities. These locomotives are from the manufactry of NORRIS & CO., who have been building locomotives for the use of the Government, and were of five feet gauge in order to meet the requirements of our armies as they advance, the railroads of rebeldom being all of that gauge. It is said that an agent bought these locomotives ostensibly for an English purchaser, and ordered them to be shipped to Halifax, but that they were supposed to be intended to run the blockade and enter some Southern port for the use of the rebels, hence the seizure and detention of the vessel. -- Philadelphia Ledger, Aug. 13.
lead_paragraph: -- On Thursday last, a schooner lying at Green-street wharf, having on board two locomotives, was seized by order of the Government by Quartermaster-General CROSSMAN, and held to await the further action of the authorities. abstract: LARCENY FROM THE PERSON. Officers REIM and LYNCH, of the Sixteenth Precinct, made the arrest on Saturday night of two men who both state their names to be DANIEL McCORMICK.
lead_paragraph: LARCENY FROM THE PERSON. -- Officers REIM and LYNCH, of the Sixteenth Precinct, made the arrest on Saturday night of two men who both state their names to be DANIEL MCCORMICK. The prisoners are charged with having relieved the pocket of Mr. WILLIAM HALLIGAN of $40 in money, while he was lying on his door stoop No. 321 West Twenty-seventh-street, in the evening. The complainant said he felt one of the MCCORMICK's extract his wallet from his pocket and run away, and that he chased him up and succeeded in catching him, and gave him and the other to the officers. Justice SEDWITH held them in default of $1,000 each. They are respectively 18 and 20 years of age, reside at No. 203 West Twenty-eighth-street, and at Forty-second-street, between Eighth-avenue and Broadway, and say they are bombshell makers. They deny the charge.

abstract: Harpers' Handbook of Europe and the East; Ladder of Life; Headley's, J T, Adirondack; American Annual Cyclopedia
snippet: Harpers' Handbook of Europe and the East; Ladder of Life; Headley's, J T, Adirondack; American Annual Cyclopedia
lead_paragraph: Though the prompt appearance of this handsome volume is an earnest of the success it so well merits, we think the importance of Messrs. APPLETON & CO.'s enterprise is, even yet, not so generally understood as it deserves to be, or there is scarcely an individual or family of ordinary intelligence who would be without it. It is within the daily experience of us all that the information most difficult to collect, and most commonly wanted, is that relating to the occurrences of recent years, too little removed from the present to come within the cognizance of "standard" works of reference, and too distant to allow the overtasked memory alone to be a safe guidance. Here APPLETON'S "Annual Cyclopaedia" at once comes in, and whatever the occurrence sought for -- if at all likely to interest futurity, or have any bearing upon the great social and political interests that govern the world -- will be found to furnish an account of it, under the year in which it happened, sufficiently full and minute for all general purposes. The significance of a work of this kind is so great, that no nation can be said to understand its own history and career, or entertain a proper sense of its responsibilities in the eyes of history, which does not possess such a record, where the chief prominence is given to national events, and where the lessons of the past may at once be read, and the springs of events now transpiring around us, carefully observed. England and France have long ago felt the necessity of a work of this kind, and the great name of EDMUND BURKE is associated with the youth of the "Annual Register." now venerable in its career of one hundred and six years. During this long interval of time the original form and arrangement of the volume was adhered to until the present year, when important changes were introduced assimilating the work in many respects to its foreign juvenile rivals. Without sets of the "Annual Register," and the French "Annuaire des deux Mondes," no library can pretend to passable completeness, and the "Annual Cyclopaedia" is even already effectually claiming for itself a similar position. To assimilate the work to the "New American Cyclopaedia," an alphabetical arrangement of the matter is adopted; this, though open to some objections, is not carried out to a fatiguing extent, -- two hundred and twenty titles are made to include the entire extent of incidents, &c.; and of these, seventy are separate biographical notices of deceased persons considered too renowned to be consigned to the general "obituary" head, where the dead of less celebrity are massed together. The editor is perhaps right in calling 1863 "the most turbulent year which the country has witnessed;" at all events, it was one both at home and abroad, full of movement and progress, when principles adopted in previous years were now daily going into effect and manifesting their results. It was not a year that settled any great questions, but rather one that afforded free play for the strife and clash of opposing views and theories as well as for that of the more material forces to which mankind has yet to confide for the attainment and propagation of ultimate reason. For every American, the two organizations where the greatest, amount of interest centres, either as a man or a citizen, are those represented in the "Annual Cyclopaedia" by the heads,Army of the United States and Army Operations," and "Congress U.S."; and in both departments the information furnished will be found of the fullest and amplest description. The difficulty of furnishing a clear and comprehensive record of a series of operations so vast in their nature, and carried on over a territory of such immense extent as those which have engaged the national armies during the past year, is very great; but it has been ably overcome, and the narrative is everywhere supported by the authentication of official documents and illustrated by excellent topographical maps and military plans of every important region. The new and engrossing questions that during the same period came under the discussion of Congress will give permanent value to the copious summary of its debates here preserved in an accessible form. Among those most prominent are: Confiscation, Emancipation, Indemnity, official and pecuniary; the Relation of the Insurrectionary States to the Union; Personal Liberty; Martial Law; Prize; the Liability of Great Britain for Damage done by Privateers, &c., &c. "Finance" also forms a division second to none in interest. Here will be found ably collected and condensed all the material for estimating the extent of the strains made upon the national resources by the demands of the war, and the generous confidence or the people by which it has been satisfactorily met. European History -- Industrial Interests -- Scientific Researches -- Geographical Explorations -- The Progress of Literature and Publication -- Ecclesiastical Movements -- &c., all meet with their due portion of attention, and offer something attractive to everyone who is desirous of keeping up with the progress of the race. It may be proper to observe that, as in a former volume, a lynx-eyed scrutiny was supposed to have discovered some leanings to a particular system of polity, the publishers assure us that the greatest efforts have been made to preserve the Annual Cyclopedia "free from every mark of partisanship."

abstract: Farragut's Victory; Particulars of; Rebel account, >amp;c.
snippet: Farragut's Victory; Particulars of; Rebel account, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: Our New-Orleans files received yesterday by the steamship Creole contain ample and most interesting particulars of the victory of the gallant FARRAGUT and his fleet in Mobile Bay. The accounts of eye-witnesses, as they appear in the New-Orleans Times, Era and Picayune, are given with admirable clearness.
headline: {'main': "MOBILE.; FARRAGUT'S VICTORY Full Particulars From Eye-Witnesses. PASSING THE FORTS. The Capture of the Confederate Gunboats. THE SURRENDER OF FORT GAINES. abstract: The play of "East Lynne" -- a long and strong decoction of Mrs. HARRY WOODS' famous novel -- continues to fill Niblo's Garden to overflowing. The principal part is played by Miss LUCILLE WESTERN, who, having softened some of the harsher features of the portraiture, is now seen to greater advantage than heretofore. The play is poorly put on the state and is "gagged" unmercifully by nearly all the people engaged in its presentation. It will be repeated every evening until further notice. The "Colleen Bawn" is still the attraction at Wallack's. Mr. DAN BRYANT will play until Saturday. On the following Monday Miss OLIVE LOGAN will commence a short engagement, producing for the occasion an entirely new five-act drama. At Barnum's Museum the "Mystic Cave, or the Enchanted Horn" will be given in the afternoon and evening.

abstract: The annual statement of the receipts and ex- penditures of the City of Charlestown for the financial year ending Feb. 29, 1864 has just been issued. It contains matter of much interest. The total expenses of the year amount to $891,- 492 02. The State tax paid by the city was $41,563.
lead_paragraph: The annual statement of the receipts and expenditures of the City of Charlestown for the financial year ending Feb. 29, 1864 has just been issued. It contains matter of much interest. The total expenses of the year amount to $891,492 02. The State tax paid by the city was $41,563. The aid dispensed to soldiers' families amounts to $50,176 40. $329,964 95 have been expended on the water works. Two temporary loans have been made -- one of $100,000, from the Monument Bank, and one of $65,000, from the Bunker Hill Bank. The cost of the Public Library for the year was $2,411 98. The expense of the Police Department was $11,640 80; of the Fire Department, $6,817. The salaries of the city officers amount to $8,475, and of the School Teachers $39,163 10. The property owned by the city is valued at $360,381 08. The report of DAVID S. TUCKER, Chief Engineer of the Fire Department, is appended. The recapitulation shows that during the year there were 25 fires and 22 false alarms. The total loss was $57,905, the insurance on which amounted to $13,100. The city has now seven engines and one hook and ladder carriage.

abstract: The Brooklyn Navy-Yard, during the hot weather, presents the same unvaried scene of confusion and activity. The full complement of men are working in the various departments, amounting in all to about seven thousand. The yard is gradually being enlarged and new edifices being constructed; new ground is constantly being made, and where mud and shallow water used to be is now a quay covered with marine buildings. The Ordnance Department has a new machine shop almost completed -- a brick building two hundred and fifty feet long, sixty feet wide, and three stories high. Another edifice is going up at the foundry. A strike for an increase of a half dollar on the ordinary wages was attempted by the,ship carpenters on last Saturday; the carpenters failed, however, and went to work on their old wages. Mails for the Various blockading squadrons are received at the Lyceum of the Navy-yard daily, and one vessel sails to and arrives from the various naval stations about once a week. Courts-martial are held every day at the yard to adjudicate upon minor cases under Judge Advocate PERKINS. The officers of the United States steamer Iononia, recently arrived, will be on board of their vessel to-day, at 10 A.M., to receive their crew, when the vessel will be ready for service.

abstract: As the 5th of September approaches, the date fixed for the draft, much anxiety is felt by many, and the question is continually raised as to whether or no the draft will then be enforced. The positive and definite answer to that question cannot be given at present. Many recruiting officers and others who ...
lead_paragraph: As the 5th of September approaches, the date fixed for the draft, much anxiety is felt by many, and the question is continually raised as to whether or no the draft will then be enforced. The positive and definite answer to that question cannot be given at present. Many recruiting officers and others who are in positions to know, state that there will be no postponement, and that the draft will certainly be carried out as ordered in the President's proclamation. The workingmen of this City have prepared and put in circulation a petition addressed to the President, asking for a postponement, a number of signatures have already been obtained, and as soon as they have secured the full number they wish, a committee of workingmen will be appointed to proceed to Washington and present the petition to the President, personally. A similar movement is talked of by the firemen, and is said to be favored by Chief Engineer DECKER, and a number of prominent members of the department. Whether these petitions will have any effect we are yet to learn, but the general impression is that they will not.

abstract: CHARGED WITH RECEIVING STOLEN HORSES. --The examination of JOHN CROW, Pound-keeper in the Sixth Ward, Jersey City, charged with being implicated with C.V. ELLIS, alias MILLER, in stealing horses, took place yesterday before Justice BEDFORD, Acting Recorder. The accused admitted to the Chief of Police and Detective KILCUALEY, that he had purchased six horses from ELLIS, one of which, belonging to LYMAN SEELEY, of Yonkers, was recovered by the officers on Sunday evening. The accused was held in $500 bonds for trial. ELLIS, who travels under various aliases, and has been encovered in horse-stealing the past twelve years, is now in prison in Connecticut. It is believed that other parties belonging to the gang will be arrested.

abstract: ARREST OF AN ALLEGED BOY MURDERER--Coroner RANNEY held an inquest yesterday upon the body of JAMES CLEARY, a lad who was drowned on  the 4th inst. It was supposed at the time that the  drowning was accidental; but yesterday some facts were developed that led to the supposition that young CLEARY had met with foul play.
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF AN ALLEGED BOY MURDERER. -- Coroner RANNEY held an inquest yesterday upon the body of JAMES CLEARY, a lad who was drowned on the 4th inst. It was supposed at the time that the drowning was accidental; but yesterday some facts were developed that led to the supposition that young CLEARY had met with foul play. It appears that deceased and two other boye, named MICHAEL, AYRESand JOHN WOODS, were about going into the water to bathe, when, as is stated, AYRES watched a favorable opportunity to push CLEARY overboard, and into water so deep that he was drowned. It is also stated that AYRES took no steps to save CLEARY, although he could easily have done so. After deceased was drowned, the boys AYRES and WOODS left the dock. WOODS was induced to keep quiet until Saturday, but at that time stated the facts to Capt. WALLING, of the Twentieth Precinct. AYRES was taken into custody, and brought before Coroner RANNEY, who examined him at some length, and then committed him to the Tombs. He is stated by the police to be a very bad boy, and guilty of thieving.

abstract: FELL FROM A WINDOW. -- Between 9 and 10 o'olock on Sunday. Mrs. WM.P. WILLIAMS, of No. 181 Kent-avenue, E.D., had a difficulty with her husband, when she either jumped or was thrown out of a third-story window, injuring her in a very serious manner. Yesterday Coroner BARRETT committed WILLIAMS to prison to await the result of the injuries.

lead_paragraph: Gen. GRANT has commenced a new, formidable, and thus far successful movement against the rebel capital. On Saturday last a powerful force, under Gen. HANCOCK, was thrown across the river at Deep Bottom. The Second Corps had been previously embarked in transports, at City Point, to sail under sealed orders for some point unknown. Instead of dropping down the river, the fleet on Saturday passed up, and landed the troops at Deep Bottom, near Dutch Gap. On the same night TURNER's and TERRY's divisions of the Tenth Corps also crossed over to Deep Bottom. A little after sunrise on Sunday, Gen. FOSTER's division was advanced by Gen. BIRNEY, pushing the rebel line of skirmishers before them for some distance. As the result of this movement Gen. HANCOCK secured a strong position about ten miles from Richmond. By a gallant assault on the rebel works in his front, Gen. BIRNEY captured six pieces of cannon and two mortars. The total number of prisoners captured is estimated at 500. Our forces are said to have gained an important position within the defences of Fort Darling.

abstract: This great ram and iron-clad, which was expected to be launched months ago, is lying on the stocks at the foot of Sixth-street, in statu quo. Her side armor is up, and the internal arrangements completed. No workman has been employed upon her for over three months, nor will there be any for two or three months to come. This is on account of the backward state of her machinery, which is being constructed at the Etna Iron Works, in about two months it is expected that the machinery will be finished, when the vessel will be launched.

abstract: Lord PALMERSTON, Lord RUSSELL, and other, members of the Government, were the guests of the Fishmongers' Company on Monday night, August 1. Lord PALMKRSTON, in responding to the toast of "Her Majesty's Ministers," said: "In guiding this country through difficulties of the greatest magnitude, we have been influenced by...
lead_paragraph: Lord PALMERSTON, Lord RUSSELL, and other, members of the Government, were the guests of the Fishmongers' Company on Monday night, August 1. Lord PALMKRSTON, in responding to the toast of "Her Majesty's Ministers," said: "In guiding this country through difficulties of the greatest magnitude, we have been influenced by the combined consideration, on the one hand, to maintain the honor and the dignity, and to defend the interests of the country; and, on the other hand, not precipitately, or without due and great and overpowering cause, to involve this country in the calamities of war. [Cheers.] We trust we have succeeded in maintaining the position of England among the nations of the world, while at the same time we have secured to the people of this country the blessings and the advantages of peace." Lord RUSSELL, in returning thanks for the House of Lords, dealt with a different subject. "You have recalled," he said, "a time now long passed, when questions of civil and religious liberty were discussed throughout the country; and you have, Sir, very fairly made some just reflections upon the character and general conduct of the House of Lords. It is quite true that the House of Lords have sometimes thought that the opinion of the people was an opinion hastily taken up, and that it was not founded upon that due consideration of the various parts of the Constitution which it was desirable to preserve, and that further time ought to be given for the consideration of those opinions; but I think you have always seen that when the House of Lords considered that the public, upon due reflection and further consideration, thought any particular measure was useful to the country, and that it would not weaken the British Constitution, the House of Lords has never interposed its own special opinion as a veto to that well-considered opinion of the people. [Cheers.] That was the case in respect to the Reform Bill." His Lordship then referred to the Reform Bill and proceeded: "May I be permitted to hope that 33 years hence, when the discussions which have been so well and so ably conducted during the present year shall have passed partly into oblivion, that then those who live at that time will acknowledge that the Ministers of 1864 had not ill-consulted the honor of their country, did not ill-consider the interest of the country in the course which they pursued during the year, entangled as their path was with difficulty, and objected to as their course was at that time by some persons -- I trust that at that time the course which the Government have pursued will be confirmed and sanctioned by calm and deliberate opinion, and that they will receive credit for being guided by honest intentions and patriotic wishes to serve the country in the course which they had determined to pursue. Nations on the Continent which have forgotten or overlooked the duties of improvement and reform have encountered the evil of violent tumult and revolution. They have gone on tumultuously and rapidly in the way of change. I trust that in this country there will always be found a desire carefully to study its institutions, and a resolution to destroy abuses where they exist and to reform those institutions where they can be usefully reformed. I trust that the people and Government will always continue that determination with a fixed resolve to respect the great framework of our Constitution; because I am persuaded that, imperfect as all human institutions are, still, never did man frame a constitution which more happily combined respect for religion, regard for liberty, respect and loyalty for the throne, together with the preservation of the rights of every individual who lives under the sceptre of the throne. I am convinced that no people ever did combine these great and essential elements of prosperity and happiness so completely as the English people now do." [Cheers.] In conclusion, the noble Earl stated that, in regard to foreign, as well as to the domestic affairs of the country, he trusted that the Administration, of which he had the honor to form a part, would not be considered unworthy of the approbation of the country. [Cheers.]

abstract: Nothing of importance transpired yesterday relative to local military affairs. The different Provost-Marshals say they will be quite ready to proceed with the draft on the 5th of September, as ordered in the President's proclamation, and think there is no doubt of its being then enforced. A number of clerks are now busily engaged in transferring the names of citizens taken at their places of business, to the districts where they reside, and when this is completed the ballots will be written up. It is said that a great many young men who have been enrolled have left the City in order to escape the draft. If any of these young heroes should happen to draw a "prize," the lucky individuals will probably discover that leaving the City did them very little good.

abstract: Notwithstanding the many robberies which have been committed during the past few months by confidence men, and the warnings which have been given in the newspapers, there seems to be some few men left, who, either from want of caution, or from excessive carelessness, still trust their property in the hands of boys not old enough to take proper care of it, and thus give these men a chance to operate still further.
lead_paragraph: Notwithstanding the many robberies which have been committed during the past few months by confidence men, and the warnings which have been given in the newspapers, there seems to be some few men left, who, either from want of caution, or from excessive carelessness, still trust their property in the hands of boys not old enough to take proper care of it, and thus give these men a chance to operate still further. Yesterday, as is the imprudent custom of many of our down town merchants, a small boy was sent by his employer with a bag containing $5,000 in gold, intended for a broker in Wall-sheet. Arriving at the office of the broker the boy placed the gold on the counter, but was told by a person behind it that the principal was not in, and that he (the speaker,) had nothing to do with the office business. A man who was standing outside of the counter, and who probably heard this reply, approached the boy, saying, "All right, senny, leave the bag; they all know me; I'll 'tend to it for you, and see it's all right." The unsuspecting boy, glad to be relieved of his charge, and also of the necessity of waiting, left the office, thinking of course that everything was all right, and that the stranger was every gentlemanly man. A few moments after the stranger also left, and the bag of gold went with him. Neither man nor money have been heard of since.
headline: {'main': 'LOCAL INTELLIGENCE.; Another Robbery of Gold. A CONFIDENCE MAN STEALS $5,000. A Desperate Attempt to Commit Murder.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'LOCAL INTELLIGENCE.; Another Robbery of Gold. A CONFIDENCE MAN STEALS $5,000. abstract: The funeral obsequies of Capt. SAMUEL H. SIMS, of the Shepard Rifles, Fifty-first Regiment New-York, Veteran Volunteers, will take place from the church of Rev. WM. ALVIN BARLETT, in Elmplace, Brooklyn, to-day, the 17th, at 2 o'clock. The escort will be the Thirteenth Regiment National guard. The procession will be joined in by the Free Masons. Let all who can, combine to pay the last tribute to Capt. SIMS, who has never been censured, but often commended in the past three years of his service, and who was one of the wisest, most courageous and best of men and officers.

abstract: A WARNING TO THOSE WHO FIGHT ON THE PIER -- On Saturday night last a man whose residence and business is unknown, but whose name is believed to be P. COLLINS, from certain marks on his person, went to Pier No. 31, East River, where, pursuant to a previous arrangement, he had a regular pitched battle with another man of about his size, but whose name the authorities have been unable to ascertain, They fought exclusively with the weapons that nature had furnished them, namely, their fists, and for a time the combat on each side seemed about equal. A large crowd had meantime congregated to witness the scene. At length they came up very close to the edge of the pier, and COLLIN having his back to the water and facing his antagonist, the latter realizing doubtless the advantage that he had, gave COLLIN a severe blow in the chest which sent him overboard. Efforts were made to save COLLIN, but without success. His body was yesterday recovered, and Coroner COLLIN held an inquest on the body. A verdict was rendered in accordance with the above facts.
lead_paragraph: A WARNING TO THOSE WHO FIGHT ON THE PIER -- On Saturday night last a man whose residence and business is unknown, but whose name is believed to be P. abstract: The dejection Of spirits among thinking and feeling Danes is something awful to look upon. abstract: Harry Hill and Uzile Prickett
lead_paragraph: UZILI PRICKETT, the Jersey wrestler, was born in the village of Cold Run, Burlington County, N.J., on the 5th of August, 1840, and was therefore 24 years of age on the 5th inst. His father was a farmer, who died some years ago, and the mother of UZILE lives on the old homestead, where the young wrestler was brought up, and has spent most of his youthful days, and also the last four years of his early manhood. When about 15 years old he was taken to Philadelphia by ANDY HIKES, who had discovered his early wrestling qualities.

abstract: We publish this morning a full narrative of the visit of two loyal citizens to Richmond, made with the hope of converting JEFF. DAVIS to the doctrines of peace. The attempt was unsuccessful, but the visit was curious and the narrative is interesting.
lead_paragraph: -- We publish this morning a full narrative of the visit of two loyal citizens to Richmond, made with the hope of converting JEFF. DAVIS to the doctrines of peace. The attempt was unsuccessful, but the visit was curious and the narrative is interesting. These gentlemen went without the slightest official authority, but the fact that they had President LINCOLN's permission to go proves that he does not in the least object to having people who have leisure for such matters, talk with JEFF. DAVIS about peace. When he can see any good result likely to be attained by it, he will unquestionably talk about it himself; but for the present he thinks the only way to get a peace is to conquer it.

abstract: Erie; Collision at Bergen Tunnel
lead_paragraph: -- A freight train on the Erie Railway, going westward through the Bargen tunnel, Tuesday forenoon, was overtaken by a passenger train of the Morris & Essex Road, going at a much more rapid speed, and the result was a crash between the locomotive and rear freight cars, which were badly broken up, and the engine was badly damaged. Reports were in circulation that a number of persons were injured, but from all the information that could be obtained, only one man, the brakesman, was injured, and he but slightly. Considerable delay was caused to other trains until [???] debts was cleared from the truck.

abstract: Intelligencer and Wade Manifesto; and Peace--Wade Manifesto
snippet: Intelligencer and Wade Manifesto; and Peace--Wade Manifesto
lead_paragraph: The National Intelligencer notices our strictures upon the recent manifesto, and the general political temper, of Messrs. WADE and DAVIS not to controvert them, but to claim that they apply with equal force to the Administration in its conduct of the war. We denounced what we deem the ultra radicalism and barbarism which have characterized the action of these gentlemen ever since the war began. The Intelligencer says that inasmuch "as they have previously uttered no complaint against the Administration," their theory of the war must be presumed to be that of the Administration itself. This is a non sequitur. Even if the fact alleged were true, the inference of the Intelligencer would not follow. They may have been restrained from complaining of the Administration at an earlier day, by many other motives than a full concurrence in its policy. They may have expected or desired office under it, and therefore kept silent. They may have lived and labored in the hope of inducing or forcing the President, sooner or later, to accept their dictation, and therefore have forborne earlier denunciation. Or, their sense of duty and responsibility to the country -- their desire to quell the rebellion and save the Union -- may have restrained them from openly assailing the Government by which alone that vast and imperative work can be accomplished. These motives might possibly have kept them still -if they had kept to themselves the discontent which has at last broken out in the fierce and intemperate manifesto with which they have lately delighted the breast of every rebel and Copperhead in the land.

abstract: Erie; Accident at Staatsburgh--7 Killed
lead_paragraph: FEARFUL ACCIDENT ON THE ERIE RAILWAY -- SEVEN PERSONS KILLED. -- Between 10 and 11 o'clock, on Tuesday night, an accident occurred on the Erie Railway, west of Staatsburgh, near Augusta Bridge, resulting in the killing of seven men. The following are the facts: The emigrant-train left Jersey City at 18:15 P.M., and upon arriving near Augusta Bridge, about forty miles out, had slackened speed to about twelve miles an hour, being near the point at which the milk-train passes. Following was an extra freight-train, which must have been running at a fast speed, as it overtook and ran into the emigrant-train. The concussion was so great that the platforms were crushed instantly, killing six-emigrants, who were riding on the platforms, but no person inside was seriously injured. The conductor, MATTHEW FINN, who was in the rear car, saw the head-light of the approaching train, and running out on the platform, was also killed. Two of the freight cars jumped the track, and in less than half a minute after, came down and ran into the freight cars, demolishing one of them and damaging the engine. The accident caused a delay of several hours before the track was cleared.

abstract: Stores in Maryland; Sheridan Explodes Theory of
snippet: Stores in Maryland; Sheridan Explodes Theory of
lead_paragraph: Gen. SHERIDAN long ago proved himself a brave soldier, and yesterday proved himself a sensible man, by exploding the commonly believed theory that the rebels had procured from Maryland an immense amount of supplies. Gen. SHERIDAN, in his dispatch to the War Department published yesterday, indicates that the rebels obtained fromMaryland only sufficient to last them while they were in transitu, and that EARLY's train does not exceed 250 wagons. Gen. SHERIDAN knows that it is simply impossible for a force of 15,000 or 20,000 men to invade a State, as rich even as Maryland, in the face of an active enemy, and gather and send off supplies to any extent, at the same time subsisting itself. When the rebels crossed the Potomac, they, of course, brought little or nothing. Whatever supplies they had were left behind. To subsist 20,000 men in an enemy's country requires that at least one-fourth of that force be employed in collecting the supplies for daily subsistence, and the whole force must be kept in motion daily, for it will completely exhaust everything for miles around its encampment and along its line of march. Without resistance, it might accumulate supplies to some extent, but even then it must have time, and must use its whole force in the work. Gen. SHERIDAN is right when he says, "the stories about accumulated plunder from Maryland are untrue." He also puts EARLY's train at 250 wagons. During the late raid, we were daily amused by the report that "EARLY's train numbered at least 1,200 wagons." This would make a wagon-train twelve miles long, and of greater proportions than is possessed by even the Army of the Potomac at this date.

abstract: The latest intelligence from GRANT'S army represents the development of the new movement on the north bank of the James River as successful and promising. The manoeuvres of Monday resulted in turning the rebel fortifications; and when our forces pushed forward the ...
lead_paragraph: The latest intelligence from GRANT'S army represents the development of the new movement on the north bank of the James River as successful and promising. The manoeuvres of Monday resulted in turning the rebel fortifications; and when our forces pushed forward the next day they found that the enemy had fallen back during the night to a stronger position than the one they had been driven from. The position occupied by our forces is only six miles from Richmond. It enables GRANT to threaten both the rebel capital and Petersburgh, while LEE cannot mass his troops for the protection of either place without leaving the other exposed to great danger.

abstract: Rear, Rebel Efforts to Cut Off
snippet: Rear, Rebel Efforts to Cut Off
lead_paragraph: For a long time the rebel press has been crying lustily for some dashing horseman from among their cavalry force to precipitate himself upon SHERMAN's rear, cut his railroad, destroy his supply depots, and thus, as they fancy, compel him to fall back, when HOOD's army would have nothing to do but follow, and gobble up SHERMAN's army as it fell to pieces on the retreat, which they were sure it would do. As yet they have had no rider bold enough to attempt it with any prospect ofsuccess. The redoubtable PILLOW, with two brigades, tried it, but was bloodily repulsed at Lafayette, Ga., by two regiments of our cavalry, under a plucky Kentuckian. But the dispatches this morning announce that WHEELER, who has gained some notoriety as a rebel cavalry leader, appeared before Dalton, a hundred miles in SHERMAN's rear, on the 14th inst., with seventeen hundred men, and demanded its surrender. The result is not known, but as Dalton is but twenty-three miles from Chattanooga, and as Gen. STEDMAN, who commands the latter post, was hurrying forward reinforcements, it may be safely assumed that the 800 veteran troops in the fortifications of Dalton were able to resist the attack of 1,700 rebel cavalry until the assistance arrived.

abstract: FATALLY STABBED AT A WEDDING. An inquest was held yesterday at Bellevue Hospital, on the body of JOHN COLLINS, who was stabbed with a dirk knife in the hands of JOHN McGRATH, on the morning of the 15th inst., an account of which was published in the TIMES of Tuesday last.
lead_paragraph: FATALLY STABBED AT A WEDDING. -- An inquest was held yesterday at Bellevue Hospital, on the body of JOHN COLLINS, who was stabbed with a dirk knife in the hands of JOHN McGRATH, on the morning of the 15th inst., an account of which was published in the TIMES of Tuesday last. FATALLY STABBED AT A WEDDING. -- An inquest was held yesterday at Bellevue Hospital, on the body of JOHN COLLINS, who was stabbed with a dirk knife in the hands of JOHN MCGRATH, on the morning of the 15th inst., an account of which was published in the TIMES of Tuesday last. The testimony given before the jury showed that there was a wedding on Sunday night, at No. 92 Henry-street, which was attended by deceased, MCGRATH, and a large number of their friends. As the party was about to break up at 2 1/2 o'clock in the morning, a quarrel occurred between deceased and MCGRATH, in regard to the singing of a song, whereupon deceased left the house and started toward his home. He had gone but a short distance when MCGRATH overtook him, and, without any previous warning, plunged a dirk knife into his abdomen. The wound inflicted was such as to cause death soon after. He was a native of Ireland, aged 27 years. MCGRATH, who was arrested at the time, was yesterday committed to the Tombs to await an indictment by the Grand Jury.

abstract: Pressed for Gov of N Y.
snippet: Pressed for Gov of N Y.
lead_paragraph: -- Quite an active canvass is going on among the Democratic politicians for the nomination for Governor, although the Presidential contest rather overrides and overshadows it. In this part of the State, Judge BARNARD is pressed with a good deal of pertinacity and determination. He certainly is among the most prominent and influential of the Democratic leaders here, and has claims upon his party which his past history proves he knows how to press and forclose. He is much more of a representative man, moreover, than the Democrats have been in the habit of nominating. He is now Judge of the Supreme Court -- quite as honorable and responsible a post as that for which he is urged by his friends. The nomination belongs this time to this section of the State, and we should not be surprised to see it conceded to this City.

abstract: The "Military News"
lead_paragraph: The additional reports received from the James River do not materially change the aspect of the engagements of Sunday near Deep Bottom. On Sunday night our forces held all the ground that had been gained during the day, and on Monday our lines -- what portion of them is not stated -- were advanced at one point to a position within six miles of Richmond. The work of Sunday, however, was not achieved without sacrifices; the Tenth and the Second Corps having lost, between them, over five hundred in killed and wounded. One brigade of the Second Division of HANCOCK's corps, under Col. MACY, in its fearless pursuit of the rebels, attempted to charge through a ravine which was intersected by a stream and an almost impassable swamp. The ravine was commanded by rebel artillery from the opposite heights, and Col. MACY was at last compelled to shelter his men from the enemy's fire as best he could, and to retire under cover of night. The action of Monday, the details of which are yet wanting, shows at least thatour forces were in a position to follow up the advantages gained on the previous day.

abstract: It is stated that EDWARD A. POLLARD, formerly one of the editors of the Richmond Examiner, who was some months since taken prisoner on the blockade-runner Grayhound, and subsequently committed to Fort Warren, was discharged from the fort last Friday.
lead_paragraph: It is stated that EDWARD A. POLLARD, formerly one of the editors of the Richmond Examiner, who was some months since taken prisoner on the blockade-runner Grayhound, and subsequently committed to Fort Warren, was discharged from the fort last Friday. It is said that be has been exchanged for some Federal prisoner in Richmond, and that he is on his parole to come to Brooklyn, where he is to report regularly to the Provost-Marshal. Previous to leaving the fort, POLLARD took the oath, swearing not to make any revelations, either verbal or written, and to keep his parole strictly and truly, &c, POLLARD reached Boston last Friday afternoon, and left in the early train Saturday morning.

abstract: Actors' Protective Union; Address to Dramatic Profession; Meeting of in New-York
snippet: Actors' Protective Union; Address to Dramatic Profession; Meeting of in New-York
lead_paragraph: A Meeting of the Actors' Protective Union was held yesterday afternoon at Cooper Institute, Mr. WILLIAM DAVIDGE presiding. The theatres were nearly all represented. The great object of the meeting was to take such action as would increase the small salaries now received by the profession, and to ask the cooperation of all actors throughout the country.

abstract: Maine Democratic Convention on Peace
lead_paragraph: "An honorable peace" is becoming a pet phrase of the Copperheads. It figures constantly in their party organs, and is finding a place in all their party platforms. The Copperhead State Convention of Maine just held, took pains to inlay it in three successive resolutions. They resolved that "the only hope of securing an honorable peace is by expelling the present corrupt, imbecile and revolutionary Administration;" that "the Administration is manifestly incapable of negotiating an honorable peace," and that they "are in favor of an honorable peace at the earliest practicable moment." It is high time to understand what this qualifying term honorable means.

abstract: SEMMES played no braggart's part when he promised his friends in England to have a new ship at his disposal before the lapse of many weeks. The Tallahassee, after having destroyed between sixty and seventy merchant ships and fishing smacks, in four or five days' time,...
lead_paragraph: SEMMES played no braggart's part when he promised his friends in England to have a new ship at his disposal before the lapse of many weeks. The Tallahassee, after having destroyed between sixty and seventy merchant ships and fishing smacks, in four or five days' time, yesterday reached the port of Halifax in safety. There she will coal, and, if necessary, refit. There her officers and crew, who have the fortune -- many of them -- to hail from the Province of Nova Scotia, will be feasted and coddled with proverbial Blue-nose hospitality. And thence she will steam out in due course -- probably making a short cruise along the neutral maritime fishing-grounds off the Newfound-land and Labrador coast, and thereafter steering as directly as may be for the main North Atlantic highway to the English Channel.

abstract: The
lead_paragraph: The "Printers' Union," as it calls itself, held a meeting in the Park last evening, to sustain the demands they have recently made upon those by whom they expect to be employed. The speeches and resolutions represent these demands as being simply for an increase in the price of their labor. This is not so. If they had simply asked for an advance in wages, they would doubtless have received it now, as they have done hitherto. Every employer, in this as in every other department of business, understands the necessity of paying more for labor in consequence of the increased price of living, and no class of employers has more uniformly or more promptly recognized this necessity, or more liberally responded to it than Publishers.

abstract: Tallahassee; Depredations of the; Gen, Movement a Failure
snippet: Tallahassee; Depredations of the; Gen, Movement a Failure
lead_paragraph: An official dispatch from Secretary STANTON, this morning, puts us in possession of the details of Gen. GRANT's movements north of the James, on Monday and Tuesday last. Gen. GRANT announces in an official dispatch, which has been delayed in transmission, that the result of the lighting was favorable, and that the enemy were driven back with the loss of about 400 prisoners, leaving their killed and wounded on the field. Among the former were two Brigadier-Generals. Our total loss from the crossing of the river up to Tuesday, was about 1,000 in killed and wounded.

abstract: Eleventh Regiment Officers Placed Under Arrest
snippet: Eleventh Regiment Officers Placed Under Arrest
lead_paragraph: It seems now quite certain that the draft will be commenced on the 5th of September, as ordered. The enrollment is complete, and the clerks are arranging the books and preparing the name-slips as rapidly as possible; they will be all ready before the day for the draft. Recruiting progresses very slowly, averaging about twenty-five men per day, and the majority of these enter the service as substitutes. It is impossible for us to raise by volunteering the number of men wanted before the 5th; to do so we should have to furnish over one thousand men per day for the next two weeks, and that we cannot do.

abstract: About 8 o'clock this morning a collision occurred in the tunnel of the Erie Railroad Company, between a passenger train of the Morris and Essex Railroad and an Erie freight train. The train on the Morris and Essex Railroad left Hoboken for Newark at fifteen minutes before 8 o'clock, consisting of a baggage car and three or four passenger cars. When about two-thirds of the distance through the tunnel the locomotive ran into a freight car on the Erie road, moving quite slowly in the same direction, smashing the rear car, which happened to be empty, and breaking the trucks and several platforms of other freight cars. The Morris and Essex locomotive was quite seriously broken, as was also the truck under the tender, both platforms of the baggage-car, and one or two platforms on the passenger-cars. HENRY PANKHURST, baggage-master, was slightly injured in one of his hips, and HENRY BONNELL, a brakeman, was injured in the shoulder. A peddler in the baggage-car was slightly cut about the face by broken glass, but no other person was injured as we could learn, On the Erie train the conductor and a brakeman, who were upon the near car, heard the bell of the approaching locomotive and saved themselves from injury by leaving from the train.

abstract: A young man named KINNEY, formerly a Trojan, but recently belonging to a Western regiment, reached this city yesterday, and is now stopping at No. 53 Franklin-street. He served for a long time under Gen. SHERMAN, and was wounded at the battle of Altoona. The circumstances attending his injuries are such as we do not recollect to have seen recorded during the war. Young KINNEY was shot in the lower part of the leg by bullet -- apparently an ordinary rifle bail. It lodged in the limb, but did not prevent his walking to the rear. He had just seated himself in an ambulance, half an hour after being hit, when the bullet exploded in his leg -- shattering the limb terribly, making four instinct openings, and carrying away a quality of bone. Despite the severe shock, the young hero traveled to his home in Troy, and is now under the care of one of our surgeons, with a chance of recovery. -- Troy Times, Aug. 11.

abstract: On Sunday next, at 10  A.M., at St. Patrick's Cathedral, in Mott-street, will be performed, the ceremony of installing the new Archbiship. The Most Rev. Dr. McCLOSKY. The most extensive and perfect arrangements have been made, and the ceremonies will be of the most grand and impressive character.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday next, at 10 A.M., at St. Patrick's Cathedral, in Mott-street, will be performed, the ceremony of installing the new Archbiship. The Most Rev. Dr. McCLOSKY. The most extensive and perfect arrangements have been made, and the ceremonies will be of the most grand and impressive character. The music will be of the highest order,and will be under the direction of Prof. G.A. SMITZ the organist of the cathedral. Right Rev. Dr. TIMON, Bishop of Buffalo, will officiate as Celebrant at the Pontifical High Mass. The Master of Ceremonies will be Rev. FRANCIS MCMIRNEY. Most Rev. Archbishop MCCLOSKEY will deliver his inaugural address on the occasion. Admission will be by ticket, and no person will be permitted to enter on the occasion by the door on Mulberry-street except the clergy. This regulation will bestrictly carried out. Those who have tickets for the chairs in the middle aisle, will be accommodated with their seats immediately after the procession enters the sanctuary. The pew-holders of the cathedral will be entitled to their seats on that day, and, after accommodating them, everything will be done to provide for others who may be present.

abstract: -- That an answer might be made to the suggestions lately made through the various journals by a number of correspondents, to whom the idea seems to have simultaneously occurred, that the Sanitary Commission should set apart a portion of its funds for the purchase of sugar, to be handed over to such persons as are willing to use it in the manufacture of blackberry syrup, or other preparations of that fruit, the officers of the commission have been applied to for information and they say: 1. That, upon the "cash in hand" at their immediate disposal, there are so many urgent and more pressing drafts, which must be instantly met, that they feel that they cannot consistently divert any portion of the ready money at their disposal into this new channel. 2. Even were there in the treasury any surplus funds which might properly be applied in the manner indicated by these correspondents, the Commissioners would hesitate about the expenditure of monies in that direction, for the reason that the berries may be so preserved without sugar, as to be fully as useful to the surgeon as a curative agent, and as grateful to the soldier as a delicious confection, as though conserved with their equal weight of the finest and purest loaf sugar. The manner of putting up blackberries the commission recommend is this: Carefully clean the fruit from leaves, bugs, dirt, &c., and spread it on clean boards, or on the bottom of tin pans or trays, and place them in the sun. There let them remain (taking them into the house every night to preserve them from the dew) until they are thoroughly dry. Then put them up in cloth bags, and send them to the nearest branch of the Sanitary Commission. Should the weather be unfavorable, and sunshine be scarce, the berries may be dried by the broad country home fire-place, or in a moderately-heated brick oven.

abstract: Recruiting; Progress of
lead_paragraph: The practical evidence accumulating daily in the hands of Mr. BLUNT at his recruiting quarters forms a painful commentary on the repeal of the commutation clause of the Conscription Act. The offers made for recruits by wealthy persons who wish to anticipate the draft are in many cases so extravagantly large that in comparison with these offers, the bounty which the Volunteer Committee are in a position to offer, becomes contemptibly mean. The committee, in fact, are driven out of the substitute market altogether by reason solely of the absence of a commutation limit. The men are there. Recruits -- healthy, willing recruits -- can be had; but they must have their little game of speculation before enlisting. Thus a healthy recruit had just concluded, yesterday, to take the regular bounty offered by the committee, when an independent offer of three times the amount he had agreed to take was made to him by a private gentleman, who had conceived the expediency of providing against the Fifth of September.
headline: {'main': 'The Progress of Recruiting.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Progress of Recruiting.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Gridley, Philo
lead_paragraph: The Utica Herald announces the death of PHILO GRIDLEY, former Justice of the Supreme Court of this State. He had been in low health for a long time. Judge GRIDLEY was a native of Connecticut, and was born in 1797. He selected the law for a profession, and made his residence at Hamilton, Madison County, where he resided for over thirty years, highly respected. In 1838 he was appointed Vice-chancellor of the Fifth Circuit by Gov. MARCY, and continued in office till the adoption of the Constitution of 1846, after which he was elected to the Bench of the Supreme Court, and held that position six years.

abstract: It is pretty generally understood that FREMONT is to be withdrawn as a candidate for the Presidency, and somebody else nominated in his place at Buffalo. His name does not prove to be the tower of strength it was expected to prove. He fails to rally to his support all the patriotism, all the virtue, all the public spirit of the country. Even the Germans do not come up to the work as it was supposed they would. On the whole, FREMONT is a dead failure, and must be taken out of the way. WILKES' Spirit discovered over a month ago that the movement was merely a tender on MCCLELLAN, and refused to be a party to it any longer. Its example has been very extensively followed since.

The late lessee was a prudent man in times of storm and theatrical  hauger, but it was a little wearisome that when the ...
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. -- This well-known and popular establishment was reopened for the season last night, under the management of Mr. W. STUART. There was a large attendance, and among the habitu s a very hearty degree of satisfaction was expressed at the change of direction. The late lessee was a prudent man in times of storm and theatrical hauger, but it was a little wearisome that when the weather had cleared he still persisted in running his vessel under bare poles, with the hatches all battened down, the grog stopped, and the entire crew on half allowance. We have in the olden time more than once complained of this. If, therefore, we now feel profoundly overcome with the fact of another captain having stepped upon deck, it is certainly not with mad agony or wild regret at the loss of the old one. Mr. STUART's antecedents afford us the best promise of the future of the Winter Garden. In association with Mr. BOUCICAULT, and alone, he has produced more new (original) plays than any other manager, and in a style that has long since ceased to be common, so rapidly has the theatre degenerated during the period of his retirement. It should be remembered, too, that some of the best known artists now on the stage were first introduced to a New-York public by Mr. STUART -- notably Miss KATE BATEMAN, Mr. EDWIN BOOTH, Mr. J.S. CLARKE. &c., &c.

abstract: Receipt Stamps; Who Should Pay for
snippet: Receipt Stamps; Who Should Pay for
lead_paragraph: -- Commissioner LEWIS in a recent decision says: "Ordinarily at law no person is bound to give a receipt for money paid. The receipt is in instrument of evidence useful only to the person to whom it is given. If he needs a receipt, it is necessary for him to furnish the stamp, or to stamp the receipt, if required, before it is signed, The person who receives the money is not obliged to give a receipt unless the other party furnishes the proper stamp. If a person gives a receipt without requiring that the party to whom it is given shall furnish the stamp, the maker of the receipt must himself stamp the paper before he delivers it. If he fails to stamp it before he delivers it, he is liable to the penalty provided by law for the omission; but the other party may stamp it immediately upon its being received."
headline: {'main': 'WHO SHOULD PAY FOR STAMPS ON RECEIPTS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'WHO SHOULD PAY FOR STAMPS ON RECEIPTS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Gen. BURNSIDE arrived in this city Tuesday morning, in good health and spirits. It is not correct, as stated by the telegraph, that he has been relieved. The Court of Inquiry in relation to the assault on Petersburgh has not reported, and has not examined any witnesses except Gens. BURNSIDE and MEADE. We judge that one of those unfortunate military difficulties which seem inseparable from the service, has arisen between Gen. MEADE and Gen. BURNSIDE, and the latter, being the subordinate, preferred, as he always does, to sacrifice himself rather than to embarrass the army in the field by any controversy. He tendered his resignation, which Gen. GRANT refused, and also refused to relieve him. The Court of Inquiry was temporarily adjourned on account of the necessary absence of some of its members. Gen. GRANT then offered him twenty days leave of absence, by virtue of which he is at home. We have no doubt that his testimony before the Court of Inquiry will acquit him of all blame, and that he will soon be called to his old or to some new command. -- Providence Journal, Aug. 17.

abstract: Metropolitan Co, Double their Price
lead_paragraph: The annual convocation of the Independent Order of Good Samaritans, a temperance organization, and one which not only allows ladies the right of membership, but also a voice in all the proceedings of its meetings, commenced at No. 195 Bowery, on Wednesday morning. The Order is now in excellent condition and has received some three hundred new members during the past year. Delegates of hove sexes, representing delegates from the five Grand Lodges, and the forty minor ones into which the Order is divided -- were present. Mr. CHARLESA. GUINARD presided, and the proceedings were conducted in private -- none being admitted except members in possession of the "degree." The convocation will continue in session until Saturday.

abstract: -- In a letter from one of our Fall River boys on board U.S.S. Richmond, dated Mobile Bay, Aug. 5th, the details of the battle between our fleet and the forts and rebel rams, are given. They are very nearly the same as we have already published. The writer says the fight lasted a little over one hour. The battle ha[???] only just began when the monitor Tecumech was seen to rise out of the water and the next moment she went down. He thinks but three or four of the crew were saved, as but one boat was seen to reach the spot. The solid shot fired at the rebel ram bounded from her iron sides like peas thrown against a wall. Not so with the 15-inch shot of our monitor, which, in about 45 minutes, caused the rebels to show the white flag. He save, also, we took one of their gunboats named the Selma. We feel that we have come out ahead, if we did lose our monitor. The rebel officers say we fought them fairly, but they did not think it possible for any of our vessels to get through the numerous torpedoes they had planted in the channel. -- Fall River News.

abstract: A private letter from St. Johns, N.F., dated 10th inst., states that a frost in that section, a few nights previous to that date, is reported to have injured the potatoe crop. The weather had been unusually cold. There had been scarcely any warm weather. The fisheries had proved almost a total failure, and fears were entertained that the poorer classes would suffer greatly the coming Winter.

abstract: Execution of Chiefs of Revolutionary Committee
snippet: Execution of Chiefs of Revolutionary Committee
lead_paragraph: -- The Czar of Russia, having crushed out the Polish rebellion and the Revolutionary Government about a year ago, is now engaged in the work of hanging the leaders of the revolt. It will be remembered that while that great rebellion was in actual progress, it maintained profound secrecy as to who were its leaders, and as to its means and agencies of operation. The "Revolutionary Committee," or "National Government," was a secret affair; secret as to its members and as to its plans, while its edicts were issued in secret and executed secretly by mysterious agents. It issued orders for the assassination of obnoxious persons, and vast numbers were suddenly and unexpectedly slain by they knew not whom. Some of its active military chiefs were of course known; but both in field and cabinet, it tried to wrap itself in mystery. It assumed for a time very formidable proportions, and had it got the assistance that was promised from England and France, it might have achieved success. But the immense armies of Russia, when fairly set in motion, soon broke it down, and reduced it to a mere guerrilla war, which also in turn was crushed out; and all the notice we now find of the late Polish "Revolution" is such as is conveyed in the following telegram from "Warsaw, under date of the 5th inst.:

abstract: Abuse of by Copperheads
lead_paragraph: MONTAIGNE has a very pleasant chapter upon the silly propensity of human nature to discharge its passions upon false objects, where the true are wanting. abstract: Tha military situation on the James River has undergone no material change since the recent successful movement on the north bank. The Second Corps on Tuesday charged the enemy in their front, and with better success than attended ...
lead_paragraph: Tha military situation on the James River has undergone no material change since the recent successful movement on the north bank. The Second Corps on Tuesday charged the enemy in their front, and with better success than attended the attack made on the Sunday previous, inflicted heavy loss upon the rebels in killed, wounded and prisoners, drove them from their works, and succeeded in holding the position thus gained. Thursday morning was signalized by more vigorous firing from the rebel lines, along their whole extent, than has been witnessed since the explosion of the mine. But nothing came of it, and no damage of any amount was suffered on our side. Later advices indicate that our forces occupy an improved position. A strong reconnoissance, sent out by Gen. HANCOCK, had been pushed beyond Fair Oaks.

abstract: Mr. JOHN H. TALLMAN, for a long series of years a dry goods jobber and cotton factor in Pearl-street, died Friday, Aug. 12, at his residence in West Nineteenth-street. Mr. TALLMAN was in the eighty-eighth year of his age at the time of his decease, and up to his last illness had enjoyed almost uninterrupted health during his whole life. He was a native of Dutchess County, and came to New-York nearly seventy years ago, when there were less than 50,000 inhabitants. There was but one banker and an insurance company at that time in this City. Many years since he retired from business, but his large wealth and extensive real estate possessions kept him active as a man and diligent in financial circles. Mr. TALLMAN was well known in Wall street for his energy of character and the integrity of all his dealings. His rigid habits of temperance and constant daily exercise kept him vigorous, and nothing but an exhausted nature, from a most painful malady (dry gangrene in the foot) removed him from his family circle and the duties of life. Mr. TALLMAN's memory was remarkable, relating events of sixty years' standing with great accuracy, and repeating readily any verse or chapter in the Bible with ease. He was a genial old gentleman, a kind neighbor and an affectionate husband and father, dying in full communion with the Episcopal (Trinity) Church. Mr. TALLMAN leaves a venerable wife and three daughters, two in this City, and one in Poughkeepsie, on the Hudson.
