abstract: The Indian war on the Plains is still waged with unabated ferocity on the part of the savages, amongst whom there is said to exist a compact for the extermination of white settlers. The trains and mail coaches on the overland route have stopped, and communication with the States is almost entirely suspended.
lead_paragraph: The Indian war on the Plains is still waged with unabated ferocity on the part of the savages, amongst whom there is said to exist a compact for the extermination of white settlers. The trains and mail coaches on the overland route have stopped, and communication with the States is almost entirely suspended. The fact that the telegraph wires are unmolested leads to the belief that no white men are engaged with the Indians in their work of devastation. Several ranches near the Blue River have been burned, the inhabitants massacred and the stock run off. Measures are in progress to raise a sufficient number of men to punish the savages and afford protection to the whites.

abstract: The mission of Col. JACQUES proved of extreme service, not simply because it established that JEFF. DAVIS will listen to no proposals of peace that do not embrace disunion. That, undoubtedly, was the most important point.
lead_paragraph: The mission of Col. JACQUES proved of extreme service, not simply because it established that JEFF. DAVIS will listen to no proposals of peace that do not embrace disunion. That, undoubtedly, was the most important point. It was only what had been publicly said a thousand times before by the rebel leaders, and by JEFF. DAVIS himself; yet, in view of the efforts now being made by the Peace party of the North to delude our people into a belief that peace is now practicable without disunion, this fresh and deliberate declaration by the man who, of all others, has the best knowledge and the most power in the premises, was peculiarly timely and valuable. His parting declaration, solemn and emphatic -- "Say to Mr. LINCOLN from me, that I shall at any time be pleased to receive proposals for peace on the basis of our independence; it will be useless to approach me with any other" -- made rubbish, on the instant, of all the electioneering peace mockeries.
headline: {'main': 'The Testimony of Jeff. Davis.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Testimony of Jeff. Davis.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Bay, Operations in
lead_paragraph: There is much in the Southern accounts of Admiral FARRAGUT'S operations, to sustain the view that the rebels placed great reliance on the ability of the forts at the entrance of the bay; that the surrender of Fort Gaines was a most unlooked-for event; that garrisons of sufficient strength were left both in that fort and in Fort Powell, to make a stubborn resistance to any attacking force; and that Fort Morgan will now be defended with all the energy possible. The surrender of Fort Gaines is attributed by the Richmond press to treachery or cowardice on the part of the commanding officer, ANDERSON.

abstract: Waste and Prices
lead_paragraph: The evening journals of the City are well employed in laying bare the extortions daily practiced upon housekeepers. The strictures, it is true, will fall ineffectual upon the ears of the extortioners. But the housekeeper will listen and will listen most attentively. And this is probably, after all, what is most needed, if we are to reach the prime source of the evil. The farmer and the middleman may be, lectured till doomsday. We may appeal to the dairyman, who asks forty-five and fifty cents a pound for his butter by wholesale, that there is nothing to warrant his demanding such a price. He may be told that he pays barely 25 per cent, more for his labor than he paid two years ago, when he was content with twenty cents a pound for his butter. He may be reminded that he grows his own wool and wears it in flannels and in clothes; that sugar, tea and coffee are almost the only necessaries of household consumption he is taxed for at the Customs; and that the price of exchange only affects him as compared with others in an infinitesimal degree. What is all this to him? He finds a market for his stuff, and he sells it naturally enough at the highest it will bring. He finds a combination of minor tradesmen ready to gouge the consuming public in his interest. And if he has to share his profits on a liberal scale with these tradesmen, still he finds the prices are kept up in the public market, and the plunder is ample enough to bear division.
headline: {'main': 'Our Habits of Waste.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Our Habits of Waste.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: on Mission of Democracy to Stop the War; Democratic Hostility to the War
snippet: on Mission of Democracy to Stop the War; Democratic Hostility to the War
lead_paragraph: -- FERNANDO WOOD wrote to the Peoria Convention: "The great body of the Eastern Democracy now speak in but one voice and hold out but one sentiment on this question, and that is in hostility to the war, and the determination to accept the proffered offer of a restoration of the Union and Constitution." THOS. H. SKYMOUR, of Connecticut, wrote to the same body: "The first grand step in this work of reform should be to stop the war. An armistice would be worth more to the entire, country than a thousand battle-fields. This I take to be the splendid mission of the Democracy at the present time to secure an armistice and make peace! If this is not its mission, then I have mistaken the character of the Democracy, and you may strike my name from the roll."

abstract: The situation before Petersburgh a new and deeper interest this morning. The official dispatch from Secretary STANTON, giving the brief but clear dispatches of Gen. GRANT up to Friday evening at 9 o'clock, invest the operations before Petersburgh with great magnitude.
lead_paragraph: The situation before Petersburgh a new and deeper interest this morning. The official dispatch from Secretary STANTON, giving the brief but clear dispatches of Gen. GRANT up to Friday evening at 9 o'clock, invest the operations before Petersburgh with great magnitude. Two more serious engagements have been fought. On Thursday evening, the 18th, the rebels came out from their works on the north side of the James and attacked the Tenth Corps, under Gen. BIRNEY, which was in a fortified position. The attack was furious, but was repulsed with very severe loss to the enemy. Gen. BIRNEY says that the loss was not less than one thousand, and adds that the colored troops behaved handsomely. In front of one of the colored regiments eighty-one dead rebels were found. On the morning of the 18th Gen. WARREN's corps moved out of its position to the left, and soon [???]lanted itself across the Weldon Railroad, about one mile south of their works. From that point he advanced toward Petersburgh, meeting the enemy as he moved forward. He had considerable fighting during the day, but the loss was light. On Friday evening the rebels came out and made an attack on WARREN's right, with the evident intention of cutting off his connection with the old line in front of Petersburgh. He drove in our pickets and pressed back two of WARREN's divisions, when a severe battle ensued, in which the rebels were driven back and our lines reestablished. This is the latest news received at the War Department from Gen. GRANT. It is estimated that the rebel loss in the various engagements of last week amount to fully four thousand men.
headline: {'main': 'THE REBELLION.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE REBELLION.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- In the Nisi Prime Court at the Manchester Summer Assize[???] a few days age, Mr. H.E. NICHOLSON, under twenty years of age, a traveler for a firm of silk manufacturers, brought an action against the Lancashire and Yorkshire Railway Company, to recover compensation for injuries sustained in a collision between two trains on the line of the defendants at the Victoria Railway [???], and in consequence of their servants' negligence. The collision took place on Oct. 29, last year, and the effects of it on the plaintiff were to render him a cripple for life, and a mere wreck of his former self. The defendants did not deny the negligence of their servants, of the severe injury that had been inflicted on the plaintiff. They merely pleaded mitigation of damages. The jury found a verdict for the plaintiff-- damages, £3,000, being £1,000 more than the plaintiff asked for.

abstract: Lying stretched under our campaign-fly, last night, in the courtyard of Winchester, endeavoring to woo a little sleep, we were surprised by a serenade, and while listening to the voices delightfully mingling in sweet sounds, our pleasant dream was harsely broken by sudden and unexpected orders for the corps to move at 4 o'clock the next morning for Berryville, and had the additional information volunteered that the Sixth and Eighth Corps were on the road also, en route for Winchester.

abstract: Corone[???] NAUMANN held an inquest on Friday on the body of MARY A. MCGREEVY, aged about six years, living with her parents at No. 365 Tenth-street, who died from the effects of drinking six cents worth of a liquid which was termed brandy. Her parents had been in the habit of sending her to the corner store for the purpose of obtaining small quantities of liquor. A day or two since the child took six cents, went to the store, bought a cup of brandy, and, without her parents knowledge, drank the whole of it. The result was, death in a short time after.

abstract: The steamship Peruvian, from Liverpool August 11, and Londonderry Augugt 12, passed Farther Point en route for Quebec at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Her news is five days later, though not specially important. Three men had been tried in Liverpool for enlisting men for the Confederate steamer Rappahannock. They were found guilty, fined £150 sterling, warned not to repeat the offence, and then liberated on their own recognizances. The little brig Vision, bound from New-York to London, was spoken on the 20th of July in lat. 48° 10′, lon. 33° W., and supplied with provisions and water, when she continued on her voyage. The Dano-German question continued to excite considerable discussion.

abstract: Secession against Secession
lead_paragraph: The position in which North Carolina is placed just now by the Secessionist interpreters of the Confederate Constitution, furnishes a very good illustration of the nature and value of the doctrine, that every State may secede when it pleases. It appears that she has a perfect right to secede from the Confederacy -- a better one, because more solemnly secured, than she had to secede from the United States; but should she attempt to exercise it, the Confederacy will instantly make war upon her. This act of aggression would of course not be committed because she seceded, but because, having seceded, the United States would probably not acknowledge her neutrality, and would still use her territory as a base of operations against the remainder of the rebels. The duty of self-preservation would therefore impose upon the Confederacy an obligation to treat her as an enemy, to march armies into her, seize her strongholds, gather her crops, levy contributions on her towns, drive out her inhabitants, carry off her negroes, and do all other things, if any others there be, which would be necessary to prevent the enemy's deriving any aid or succor from her. So that, secede or not secede, it would be impossible for her to escape sharing in the perils and losses of the war.

abstract: Royal Sovereign; Turret-ship
lead_paragraph: The iron-cased turret ship Royal Sovereign, Capt. SHERARD OSBORN, C.B., arrived in Portsmouth harbor, on Saturday, from her short cruise outside the Isle of Wight, on which she started from off Osborne immediately after the visit of Her Majesty to the ship on Thursday evening. The return of the ship to Portsmouth harbor is solely owing to orders given some time since by the Admiralty to place her in dock at the earliest opportunity, in order to remove the band of zinc which is now fixed round the ship below the water line, and between the armor plating and the Muntz metal sheathing on the ship's bottom, and substitute in lieu of it a wooden band, on a plan which has been approved by the Admiralty. It is also understood that a peculiar kind of cement, simple in application and not expensive, which has been brought under the notice of the Admiralty by Capt. COLES, will be applied experimentally to that portion of the ship's armor plating below the water line. If successful, the experiment may probably help materially in the solution of the problem lately referred to by Lord CLARENCE PAGET in the House of Commons -- how to preserve and keep clean the bottoms of iron ships on service in tropical waters. The Royal Sovereign's necessarily short cruise, from which, she returned on Saturday, only extended to about 20 miles south of St. Catherine's, in a parallel line with the Isle of Wight, quite far enough from the land to test her rolling properties had the wished-for breeze been met with; but, although a nice Summer channel-breeze -- southwesterly -- was found, it was accompanied with no great swell, and a greater roll could not be got out of the ship than five degrees each way. Enough, however, was seen to give the officers every confidence in their ship under ordinary circumstances at sea, and it is evidently unnecessary to wish for any further confidence to be placed in the sea-behavior of a craft which, after all, is only a conversion, and is merely being used as a floating means of testing Capt. COWPER COLES' principle of working monster ordnance on board ship by means of revolving platforms, protected by cylindrical armor.

abstract: In the engagement near Deep Bottom, on the 16th instant, a very gallant action was performed by H.M. HARDENBURGH, a young private belonging to Company G, Thirty-ninth Illinois Regiment. He charged upon the color-sergeant of the Tenth Alabama Regiment, and, after a hand-to-hand fight, he captured the colors, and brought them off, leaving the rebel sergeant mortally wounded.
lead_paragraph: In the engagement near Deep Bottom, on the 16th instant, a very gallant action was performed by H.M. HARDENBURGH, a young private belonging to Company G, Thirty-ninth Illinois Regiment. He charged upon the color-sergeant of the Tenth Alabama Regiment, and, after a hand-to-hand fight, he captured the colors, and brought them off, leaving the rebel sergeant mortally wounded. He presented the colors to Gen. BIRNEY, who complimented him highly for his bravery. Four flags and over four hundred prisoners were captured.

abstract: The bark Daniel, Capt. SPEARWATER, arrived this morning from Matamoras, bringing data to July 16. The news is unimportant. CORTIA, with a force variously estimated, was somewhere near Vitorla; report said he had met the French and beaten them. Col. CORTINA, brother to the Governor, was in command of the city of Matamores, and everything was quiet. Business was very dull and the market over-stocked with goods of every kind. Cotton was scarce and high. It was rumored that Brownsville would be evacuated in a few days.

abstract: Morgue, Paris, Statistics of
lead_paragraph: A correspondent of the Athenoeum supply the following curious statistics: Of the 2,[???]51 bodies of men and women received at the old Morgue of Paris during the past ten years, 1,[???]6[???] are set down as the result of suicide, and concerning these some curious information is given. It appears that self-destruction is at its maximum between the ages of 30 and 40; that it commences between 10 and 15, and dwindles to almost nothing after 70, which is not surprising, the suicides between 10 and 20 being three times more numerous than those committed after the age of 70 years. As regards the supposed causes -- for, in his case, there must be a margin left for imperfection if judgment -- it appears that insanity and suicidal monomania account for more than one-quarter of the whole; drunkenness and disgust of life, each, about one-tenth; absolute poverty for nearly the same proportion; misfortune and incurable, diseases, each, for nearly as many; [???], and close upon these, come disappointed love, domestic misery and misconduct of the suicide himself; accusation of theft stands for about one in in 26; fever and delirium for one in 33; and vexation caused by the remonstrances of others about one in 57. This, however, applies only to the made sex; in the case of women insanity stands fast, disappointed affection second, disgust of life third, drunkenness fourth, starvation fifth, domestic misery sixth, and incurable disease seventh. As regards the mode adopted out of the 1,766 cases recorded at the Morgue, 1,414 had recourse to drowning, 114 to hanging, 38 to firearms, 56 to the fumes of charcoal, 46 precipitated themselves from buildings or other elevated places, 16 made use of cutting weapons and instruments, 11 only had recourse to poison, 7 threw themselves beneath railway or other carriages, and 4 killed themselves by swallowing alcohol. Another table informs us that more than one-third of the whole of these suicides were committed between the hours of six in the morning and mid-day; while the first two hours of the afternoon exhibit by far the smallest number -- not one-tenth, as compared with the six preceding hours of the day. The number of females who committed suicide is scarcely more than a fifth of that of the male sex. It is a striking proof of the influence of misery on suicide -- unless, indeed, it be an evidence of a superstitious dread -- that only about one in six of the suicides was buried at the expense of his family or friends.
headline: {'main': 'THE MORGUE OF PARIS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE MORGUE OF PARIS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Political Criticism in
lead_paragraph: The practice which Gen. McCLELLAN commenced, by his extraordinary letter to the President from Harrison's Landing, in 1862, and into which other officers have since fallen, of criticising the policy of the Government while in the army, and of resigning and publishing the reasons for their resignations, when any portions of that policy chance to be distateful to them, is one which is thoroughly shocking to soldiers bred in the traditions of old military States. In any European army such epistles as those either of Gen. MCCLELLAN or of Gen. BUELL, would, by the charitable, be considered evidences of lunacy, though most men would set down the penning of them as an act of the grossest insubordination -- so gross that hardly any punishment would be too heavy for it. And the reason is very simple.

abstract: Achievements of
lead_paragraph: The Vienna Conference has achieved a triumph -- it has effected a compromise between the Danes and their antagonists -- it has induced the belligerents to make peace -- it has closed the war -- it has solved the SchleswigHolstein difficulty. Europe has reason to rejoice, as she has escaped for the present from the horrors of a general conflict; but whether either King CHRISTIAN or the Germanic Confederation ought to be equally exultant, seems somewhat doubtful.

abstract: Bremen Wine Cellar, the
lead_paragraph: The following account is now running the round of the German press: "The municipal wine-vault of Bremen is the most celebrated in all Germany." One section, called the Rose, from the bronze has-relief of roses over it contains the famous Rossenwein, which is now two centuries and a half old. There, six large casks of Rhine wine. Johannisherg, and as many of Hocheimer, were placed in 1624. In the adjacent p[???] of the same division of the collar are twelve large casks, bearing the names of the Apostles, and containing wines not less precious, but not so aged by a few years; the wine bearing the name of Judas is considered the best. The other parts of the cellar are occupied with wines of a subsequent growth. By degrees, as a few bottles of Rosenwein are drawn off, the casks are filled up with Apostle wine, and that with some sort still younger, and so on, in such a manner that the different casks are always kept very nearly full. A single bottle of Rosenwein now represents an immense value. A cask of wine containing 1,000 bottles cost, in 1624, 1,200f. Calculating that sum at compound interest with the expense of cellarage, a bottle would positively cost 10,895,232f; and a glass or eighth part of a bottle, about 1,361,90[???]. The Rosewein and Apostle wines are never sold but to citizens of Bremen. The burgomasters have, alone permission to draw a few bottles, and to send them as presents to Sovereigns. A citizen of Bremen may, in case of serious illness, procure a bottle of 20f. on his obtaining the certificate of his doctor and the cons[???] of the municipal council. A poor inhabit of B[???] may obtain a bottle grat[???]s, after having [???] certain formalities. A citizen has also the [???] of demanding a bottle when he receives [???] celebrated personage at his house as guest. A bottle of Rosenwein was always seat by the City of Bremen to GOETHE on his [???]-day.

abstract: Vallandigham's Views
lead_paragraph: The highest testimony that has lately been given touching the qualifications of Mr. LINCOLN for the Presidential office in the present crisis, has been given by VALLANDIGHAM in the course of his recent address to the Copperheads of Dayton, Ohio. After showing the imperative necessity of nominating a peace candidate at the Chicago Convention, and portraying the evils which would result from the election of a War Democrat, the Copperhead chief frankly declared "that if they wanted a War President, they had as good a one as they could get in the person of LINCOLN." "I would as soon," said Mr. V., "be drafted under him as under a War Democrat; and I would agree with ABRAHAM, that it is no time to swop horses while swimming a river." It would be going rather far to infer from this that VALLANDIGHAM and the Copperheads will vote for the reelection of Mr. LINCOLN, if they cannot effect the nomination of a disunion peace candidate at Chicago; but it is nevertheless a frank admission by the coryphaeus of that party, that, in his opinion, Mr. LINCOLN is the best candidate for the Presidential Chair, if the people would have the rebellion crushed, and the integrity of the Union restored. Nay, he virtually avows his belief that the public interests would suffer were a President to be elected who, with none of the advantages derived from experience and acquaintance with affairs, should yet have to tread in the footsteps and pursue the policy of the present Chief Magistrate. He wants a President who would stop the war, withdraw our armies from the South, and proclaim in effect to the Governments of Europe that the North had been defeated in the conflict, and that the time for their recognition of the Confederacy was arrived. He probably thinks, too, that C.L. VALLANDIGHAM would be just the beau ideal of a President to carry out this programme; but, lest the delegates to the Chicago Convention should prove so obtuse as not to be able to discover the beauty of his policy, or his superior fitness for the Presidential office, he magnanimously acknowledges beforehand that he esteems his rival, "Old ABE," to be in the second degree most worthy of the honor, -- following, in this case, the example of the Grecian admirals, who, after the Persian war, assigned to themselves respectively the first rank in merit, but unanimously assigned the next to THEMISTOCLES.

abstract: At the Thames Police Court, on Saturday, HOWLAND, one of the summoning officers of the court reported to Mr. PAGET the result of his inquiries relating to a seaman named GEORGE LA PIERRE. It will be recollected that LA PIERRE'S statement was that he went to America as a seaman ...
lead_paragraph: At the Thames Police Court, on Saturday, HOWLAND, one of the summoning officers of the court reported to Mr. PAGET the result of his inquiries relating to a seaman named GEORGE LA PIERRE. It will be recollected that LA PIERRE'S statement was that he went to America as a seaman in the English ship Universe, was kidnapped in New-York by crimps, and taken on board the American ship, the Caroline Nasmith, in which he was obliged to work as a seaman on the voyage to London without wages and with not any change of clothes. He is a native of Quebec and a British subject. HOWLAND believed that the representations of LA PIERRE were in the main correct. The chief mate of the [???] Nasmith admitted that he had been "Shangh[???]d' at New-York -- meaning that he was [???] on board drunk, after being kidnapped. He added [???] this practice was common there. The seaman complained that he had been taken on board after the vessel got to sea and that he [???] [???] to much work, as he was afflicted with a bad leg. The mate added that he thought there would be a piece of work in England about the way in which the man was taken on board in New-York. HOLAND afterward saw Capt. COTTER, the master of the Caroline Nasmith, who said that he paid $80 to an agent in New-York to bring him a man on board, and that LA PIERRE was a deserter from the ship, and owed him $50. The Captain admitted that it was very probable the seaman had not received any [???]ey, but he had nothing to do with that. He asked Capt. COTTER if the seaman had signed any articles of agreement, to which the Captain replied in the affirmative. He asked to see the articles, and the Captain said they were "up town," and he could not see them. HOWLAND, in conclusion, said the seaman was in a wretched plight, and had no change of clothes or linen, and that he had, by direction of the magistrate, provided him with board and lodging at a coffee-house in Stepney. The seaman wanted to teach Liverpool, where his ship, the Universe, in which he sailed from England, was lying. His wife was also living there. A society for the protection of sailors, with which the Marquis TOWNSHEND was connected, had sent for the particulars of LA PIERRE's case, and meant to interfere on his behalf Mr. PAGET said the sailor's case appeared to be a very hard one. He directed HOWLAND to continue his care of the sailor for the present, and he would decide in a few days what was to be done with him.

abstract: New-York; White-street; Railroad Depot
lead_paragraph: FIRE IN THE RAILROAD DEPOT BUILDINGS IN WHITE-STREET. -- At 8 o'clock, last night, a fire broke out, from some cause at present unknown, on the top floor of the Railroad Depot buildings in Whitestreet. These buildings are very extensive, occupying one entire square, and are bounded by Centre, Franklin, Elm and White streets. Flames were first discovered issuing from the upper story of building No. 4, situated on the White-street side, and occupied by Mr. J. DEVOE, glass-cutter and dealer. His damage to stock is estimated at about $3,000. He is fully insured in City companies. The third floor is occupied by Mr. BARNES, manufacturer of steel wire, and Mr. BROOKS, machinist. Both of these men were extensively damaged both by fire and water on their stock, machinery and fixtures. They are said to be fully insured, but in what companies could not be ascertained. Building No. 5 in the same block on White-street, Was occupied on the third floor by H. THAYER, blacking-box manufacturer. The fourth floor of the same building was occupied, by CHAS. ALT, spectacle-maker. Both of the last-named gentlemen have suffered a serious loss on stock, machinery and fixtures, the amount of which could not be learned, owing to the lateness of the hour. Mr. STERN, coffee-grinder, occupying the floor immediately over the depot of that building known as No. 4, was badly damaged on stock by water. The origin of the fire is at present unknown;. It is understood that the buildings are owned by the Harlem Railroad Company. They are damaged to the extent of $2,000, and are fully insured.

abstract: In the long list of heroes who have freely offered up their lives amid the shock and smoke of battle, that the wicked rebellion of the South might be subdued and the Union maintained. Connecticut has many sons whose names will shine brightly on historic pages and live long in the hearts of her people. None truer or braver, none governed by loftier motives of patriotism, and none more willing to make sacrifices for their country, have shed their blood in the present war, than those who have gone from homes in our own State. Connecticut has nobly responded to the calls upon her in this national crisis. Her loss in general officers alone has been very severe. LYON at Wilson's Greek, MANSFIELD at Antietam, and SEDGWICK in the Wilderness, after rendering faithful and invaluable service to their country, died in the face of the enemy -- on the fields of their renown -- and a nation mourns their loss. The memory of their heroic deeds shall not fade through generations, nor shall the valor of any soldier, however humble his position, be forgotten, as men in the future read of the battles of to-day, and wish they could have lived to have taken part in the great struggle for liberty.

abstract: Nothing of any great importance has occurred as yet in this department, and the army remains in almost the same position my last letter left it. One brigade of the Nineteenth Army Corps started for Winchester, in charge of the empty wagon train, yesterday. The Sixth Corps returned from a brief reconnoissance out in front yesterday also, and report the enemy strongly posted on Tumberland River, just beyond the town of Strasburgh.

abstract: Streight, Col A D; Winslow, Capt, Obituary
snippet: Streight, Col A D; Winslow, Capt, Obituary
lead_paragraph: Rev. Dr. HUBBARD WINSLOW, the author and clergyman, whose death we have lately announced, was born in Vermont near the commencement of this century, and came by direct line of descent from the Mayflower WINSLOWS. Both of Mr. WINSLOW'S brothers, Rev. MYRON WINSLOW, D.D., LL.D., of India, and the late Dr. WINSLOW, of the Sanitary Commission, have made themselves eminent in their callings. HUBBARD WINSLOW graduated with promise at Yale College, and entered the ministry of the Congregational Church. He soon rose to a high degree of eminence as a preacher. In 1831-2 his first volume, entitled "Doctrine of the Trinity," was published. It was at a time when the public mind was deeply engrossed by the contests in New England between the Unitarian and Trinitarian parties. This work found its way over the ocean and was read by Dr. CHALMERS, who called it the ablest treatises on that topic that had then appeared. Mr. WINSLOW was then settled in Dover, N.H.; but when old Dr. LYMAN BEECHER left Boston in 1832, his mantle unanimously fell upon the young and rising minister. A successful pastorate of twelve years in Boston gave Mr. WINSLOW a wide reputation, both as a preacher and writer. The church numbered several of the most influential citizens of Boston, and its growing strength repeatedly colonized sister churches. A large part of Dr. WINSLOW's time and labor was given to the welfare of young men. and his Young Men's Aid, has been read by hundreds of thousands of young men. Reprinted in England, it found a ready and an immense sale, Mr. WINSLOW's partiality for philosophy led him to devote much time to that department of study. He published several philosophical tracts, and wrote largely for the reviews.

abstract: Mahopac, Monitor, Trial Trip of
lead_paragraph: The iron-clad monitor Mahopac made a trial trip yesterday up the Hudson, for the purpose of testing her engines and sailing qualities, but more particularly for experimenting with her guns. The Palisades was just the spot for such kind of practice, as there was no danger of the shot and shell going into the country, and killing or frightening honest Jerseymen; besides, a fine opportunity was afforded for seeing the balls and shells strike the cliff, and the terrible crashing and tearing effect produced among the rocks and cedar shrubbery.

abstract: The Poona Observer, of June 21, contains an account of a visit paid on the preceding day to the Free Church Institution in Poona by Dr. LIVINGSTONE, who was at the time the guest of his Excellency the Governor of Bombay, at Daporee. We take the following from its columns: "Dr. LIVINGSTONE arrived about 11 o'clock, accompanied by Capt. LEITH, and was received by Mr. GARDINER, the missionaries, Maj. CANDY, Mr. Ross, Presbyterian Chaplain, several officers, and other gentlemen. Mrs. MITCHELL, Mrs. GARDINER and several ladies were also present. In reply to a request from Mr. MITCHEEL that he would give his opinion as to the prospects of South Africa in regard to its future civilization and trade, Dr. LIVINGSTONE stated that those prospects were not nearly so bright now as they had been when he arrived with the expedition at the mouth of the Zambesi River in 1858. They had procured the assistance and countenance of the Portuguese Government, and an order to its subordinates to give them every aid and support. The harbor was a remarkably fine one, and everything promised well when they made their first expedition up the river. They found the neighboring country thickly peopled, and some caution was required to avoid any demonstration, lest they should be attacked from the banks with the arrows of the natives, who knew no Europeans but the Portuguese, and were not disposed from what they knew of them to give strangers a very friendly reception. When they came dowa, however, they found that these hostile feelings had disappeared, and that they were well received. The expedition was sent out by the English universities, and accompanied by the excellent and devoted Bishop MACKENZIE, who was so regardless of his own comfort, that there is little doubt he lost his life thereby. The Portuguese had long carefully excluded all other Europeans from the country; he himself had obtained access to it on a former occasion by entering it from the south and coming down the river, when they could not for very shame compel him to go back. This was in 1856,and on his return two years later the expedition was allowed without difficulty to enter the country, as just stated. On ascending the river several cataracts were encountered, which Dr. LIVINGSTONE had not seen when he came down. On this account they took the direction of the Shire River, and ascended the beautiful valley of that name. It contained a thick population, flourishing villages, and fine cultivation. Above was an elevated plateau some thousand feet above the sea, which strongly resembled the Deccan, except that it was covered with trees and grass, and which, like the valley, contained a large populalation. But about that time the Portuguese sold a quantity of firearms and ammunition to one of the tribes, to be paid for in slaves. The tribe, thus armed, swept the whole neighboring country like a scourge, killing the men in the villages, and carrying off women and children into slavery. This produced a terrible famine, in which large numbers of the survivors perished; and the fine valley of the Shire was transformed literally into a valley of bones. Whole villages were found without people. On another expedition they ascended the main stream of the Zambesi, passing thirty-five miles of rapids, and reached Lake Nyassa, which was 270 miles long and 60 or 70 wide. Above it was a range of hills, which proved when they had amended it to be another plateau or table land nearly 4,000 feet high, extending for many miles, and filled with villages and cultivation." The Government was of the patriarchal form each village being entirely independent under its own head man or chief. In one respect there was a great contrast to this country, for there were slaves in every village chained up and working for their masters. They were inhabitants of other villages, who had been kidnapped and brought into captivity. They were held by a collar round the neck, to which a long stick was attached, and they were thus secured for the night, or when made to travel, pushed along by the proprietor, who held the other end of the stick and followed. Many of the slaves were quite little children, whose parents probably had been killed, for Dr. LIVINGSTONE did not believe their mothers had sold them. In reply to various questions. Dr. LIVINGSTONE, who seemed good-naturedly desirous to satisfy the curiosity of those present, stated that the cultivation by the African natives was very good, though it was entirely carried on with [???]. They were very industrious, and while whole families worked in their gardens, which were often very large, men, women and children altogether, an infant in addition being sometimes seen deposited under a hedge. They grew beans of all kinds, pumpkins, maize and rice, but not wheat nor grain. Cotton they grew, span and wove themselves. They had no trade.

abstract: By far the most important and far-reaching success achieved by the Army of the Potomac since it assumed its present position on the Appomattox, is that set forth in the three dispatches from City Point, incorporated by Secretary STANTON in his bulletin.
lead_paragraph: By far the most important and far-reaching success achieved by the Army of the Potomac since it assumed its present position on the Appomattox, is that set forth in the three dispatches from City Point, incorporated by Secretary STANTON in his bulletin. We refer to the march upon and seizure of the Weldon Railroad by Gen. WARREN on Thursday last, from which position the enemy made an attempt in force to drive us on the evening of Friday, but failed.

abstract: Hon. S.B. GARVIN, Hon. ALBERT CARDOZO, DANIEL DEVLIN, Esq., JAMES M. MCLEAN, Esq., President of the Board of Education, and S.G. RANDALL, Esq., City Superintendent of Schools, will act as judges to select a nominee for the West Point Academy, to be appointed by Hon. ANSON HERRICK, of the Ninth Congressional District. Competition will be open for all public school and free academy boys in the Twelfth, Nineteenth and Twenty-second Wards. The examination will take place at the Hall of the Board of Education, at 2 o'clock P.M. on Monday; the appointee to report at West Point on Saturday.

abstract: Position at Atlanta; Mischievous Delusions
lead_paragraph: If there be one thing more than another which tends to plunge the public into doubt and despondency, it is the exaggerated accounts of the military prospects which come from Washington. Not that we have any fault to find with anybody's honest endeavors to set the best side of our affairs before the people, and to encourage them to look at it, if not constantly, at least as often as the other side.

abstract: Terence Smith Fined for Watering
lead_paragraph: CHARGED WITH ADULTERATING MILK. -- TERARNCE SMITH, a milkman, was arraigned yesterday before Justice MANSFIELD, at the Essex Market Police Court, charged, on the complaint of Officer ELY, of the Sanitary Squad, with violating the recent act of the Legislature of this State, prohibiting milkmen, under a severe penalty, from watering or in any way adulterating their milk. The officer saw SMITH come cut of the distillery of Messrs. LOWBER & OSTEIN, in North Fifth-street, Williamsburgh, early on the morning of the 17th inst., with his milk cans. He proceeded to a pump in Second-street, Williamsburgh, where he filled up his cans to the brim, pouring in large quantities of water. SMITH thence proceeded to New-York, followed by the officer. At Nos. 120 and 122 East Fourth-street the delinquent milkman delivered a portion of the milk and water, and afterwards delivered a whole can of the same diluted milk to WM. GLASS, a milk dealer, on the corner of First-avenue and Tenth-street. Justice MANSFIELD held the accused for trial in the sum of $500 bail.

abstract: -- An unknown man, in attempting to get on board the Staten Island boat last evening, missed his footing, and fell into the water, when Mr. JEREMIAH REARDON, better known as "Bally Cotton," plunged in after him, and succeeded in keeping him above water until other assistance was rendered; they were both taken on board the boat in an almost exhausted condition.

abstract: You may expect to hear shortly of the offensive being taken again in this department. Before this reaches you, GORDON GRANGER will be thundering at the gates of Mobile. I understand that our base of operations is to be Pascagoula. I presume that the importance of a demonstration upon this City of Mobile at this time is fully appreciated by Gen. CANBY, and that it is being pushed forward with all dispatch.
lead_paragraph: NEW-ORLEANS, Friday, Aug. 5, 1864.

abstract: Gen SHERIDAN changed his position in order the better to watch the passes of the mountains. The great number of points which he is compelled by orders to cover, imposes upon him a more conservative military policy than he would otherwise adopt. The rebel force at Martinsburgh is but an inconsiderable raiding party, and will not interfere with Gen. SHERIDAN'S programme of operations, which will be something more than defensive.

abstract: Reply to Johnston Cooke's Letter; Reply to His Letter to Everett
snippet: Reply to Johnston Cooke's Letter; Reply to His Letter to Everett
lead_paragraph: SIR: In a recent number of the Richmond Examiner, I find a letter over the signature of "A Virginian," addressed to Hon. EDWARD EVERETT, of Massachusetts. I think I cannot be mistaken in believing that you are the author of that letter. Before the war I knew the style and manner of every Virginian writer of note or promise; and no small part of their writings which they wished the world to see, or from which they hoped to gain either fame or moneycame before me while in manuscript. From noone of these have I read more, and with more pleasure, than from JOHN ESTEN COOKE. NO one seemed to me to possess so delicate a fancy or tobe master of so graceful a style. There were always paragraphs in his communications which THACKERAY might have written. I find these characteristics in this letter to Mr. EVERETT. I do not think the last three years likely to have developed them in any other Virginian; and so I conclude that the "Virginian" who wrote the letter is yourself. That letter was copied into the NEW-YORK TIMES, and I avail myself of that medium far a reply.

abstract: Commodore BUCHANAN, who commanded the rebel fleet in Mobile Bay, and who is now a prisoner, is likely to close his career with the fight in which he has just been defeated. His wound is reported dangerous, and his age will tell against his recovery. He entered the service in 1815, from Maryland, and belongs to one of those "first families' that think they have a claim on the Government to take care of them. In 1861 he was the commandant of the Navyyard at Washington, and after the inauguration of LINCOLN, was loud in his professions of loyalty and his denunciations of the men who had worn the uniform of their country, and had betrayed it in the hour of its danger. The President, in compliment to the spirit manifested by the Commodore, attended the marriage of his daughter, which took place at the Navy-yard, with much patriotic display, the bridal party standing under the American flag; and altogether Mars and Neptune seemed to have quite as much to do with the affair as Cupid, and the other "dear delightful little creature," as Mrs. Skewton used to call Hymen. We do not remember how many days after this it was that the rebels first threatened Washington from the neighborhood of Arlington Heights, and the officers of the navy-yard of rebel sympathies threw up their commissions and invited the attack which they expected. Commodore BUCHANAN went with them, whether leading or following, in the ignoble race, we do not know. It was thought that with the abandonment of so many of the officers, and the corrupt influences that had been employed upon the workmen and others in the yard, an insurrection would take place there spontaneously, without waiting for the approach of external treason. But Admiral DAHLGREN, then a Commander, was in charge of the Ordnance department of the yard, and all his superior officers having deserted, he at once assumed the command of the entire yard, and adopted such vigorous measures that the incipient treason was stopped.

abstract: Our troops are getting short of rations, and the cavalry have had very little forage, except such as they were enabled to gather in the country through which they passed. Today a number of beef and milch cattle were seized for the immediate use of the troops. Several of the owners of these cattle have claimed their property, but have to prove their loyalty before they are able to save the animals from slaughter.

abstract: The steamship Peruvian, of the Montreal line, arrived at Father Point on Saturday afternoon. Her latest dates are to the 12th instant. Her news is not of special interest. Three persons had been tried at Liverpool for enlisting seamen for the rebel vessel Rappahannock.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Peruvian, of the Montreal line, arrived at Father Point on Saturday afternoon. Her latest dates are to the 12th instant. Her news is not of special interest. Three persons had been tried at Liverpool for enlisting seamen for the rebel vessel Rappahannock. They were found guilty and fined #163;150 sterling each. The little craft Vision, from this port, had been spoken at sea and supplied with water and provisions. BATEMAN, the theatrical speculator, had been before a Police Court for assaulting a lady.

abstract: FIRE IN A FOUNDRY. -- At 10:30 o'clock on Saturday night, a fire broke out in the large foundry in Ste[???]en-street, near Greene-street, Jersey City, owned by Mr. CULVER, and owing to the fact that there was a large amount of combustible material in the building, the flames spread with great rapidity. The Fire Department was soon at work, and eventually subdued the flames, not, however, until the interior of the building and contents was burned out. For a while the adjoining buildings were in great jeopardy but escaped without damage through the exertion of the firemen. In consequence of the absence of Mr. CULVER the loss could not be ascertained, but it is thought to be not less than $3,000. The origin of the fire is not known, but was undoubtedly accidental.

abstract: Sheridan's, Gen Philip H, Operations in the Valley
snippet: Sheridan's, Gen Philip H, Operations in the Valley
lead_paragraph: It is two weeks to-day since Gen. SHERIDAN took command of the Middle Military Division, which embraces, besides the Department of Washington, the command of all the separate armies of WALLACE, COUCH, HUNTER, technically designated the Middle, the Susquehanna and Western Virginia Departments. The force thus concentrated under one head consists mainly of the Sixth, Eighth and Nineteenth Corps, and the Kanawha army, the latter including, beside the forces of CROOK and AVERILL, those under KELLY at and around Cumberland.

abstract: New-York--O'Brien, Policeman, Shot by J Riley
snippet: New-York--O'Brien, Policeman, Shot by J Riley
lead_paragraph: THE CORNER NOTIFIED TO HOLD AN ANTE-MORTEM EXAMINATION. -- About 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, Officer O'BRIEN of the Nineteenth Precinct, while patroling his beat, saw a man named JOHN RILEY, who is a fugitive from justice, he having escaped some months since from the officials, after having been indicted as one of the rinfileaders in the riots of July last. O'BRIEN followed RILEY into a liquor store at the corner of Eighth-avenue and Forty-first-street. There the policeman undertook to arrest him, when the latter suddenly drew a pistol and shot O'BRIEN in the forehead, inflicting a serious, and, it is feared, fatal wound. He was conveyed to St. Luke's Hospital, and the Coroner notified to hold an ante-mortem examination. RILEY made his escape immediately after firing the pistol, and at a late hour last night he had not been arrested. Capt. WALLING, of the Twentieth, the Precinct in which the shooting took place, was immediately notified, and that official dispatched men in pursuit of RILEY.

abstract: The German papers publish the preliminaries of peace between Denmark and Germany, of which the following are the most important points: The King of Denmark relinquishes his rights over Schleswig-Holstein and Lauenburg in favor of the Emperor of Austria and the King of Prussia, and agrees to recognize all arrangements made by the two latter Sovereigns with respect to the Duchies.
lead_paragraph: The German papers publish the preliminaries of peace between Denmark and Germany, of which the following are the most important points: The King of Denmark relinquishes his rights over Schleswig-Holstein and Lauenburg in favor of the Emperor of Austria and the King of Prussia, and agrees to recognize all arrangements made by the two latter Sovereigns with respect to the Duchies. The German papers publish the preliminaries of peace between Denmark and Germany, of which the following are the most important points: The King of Denmark relinquishes his rights over Schleswig-Holstein and Lauenburg in favor of the Emperor of Austria and the King of Prussia, and agrees to recognize all arrangements made by the two latter Sovereigns with respect to the Duchies. The surrender of Schleswig includes all the islands belonging to that Duchy. Denmark also cedes the Jutland possessions to the south of the southern frontier line of the District of Ribe.

abstract: Installation of
lead_paragraph: The installation of the Right Rev. JOHN MCCLOSKEY, late Bishop of Albany, as Archbishop of the Metropolitan See of New-York, took place yesterday, at St. Patrick's Cathedral, on Mott-street. It was attended with imposing ceremonies, and exceeded, in the grandeur of the pageant, any similar occasion in the United States. Since the installatton of the late Archbishop HUGHES, who was the first Prelate elevated to the Archiepiscopate office in New-York, the Catholic community have largely increased in numbers and position, and the public mind was excited in just expectation of unprecedented splendor in the ceremony.

lead_paragraph: The latest intelligence from the Army of the Potomac represents the situation as materially unchanged since the successful attempt to gain possession of the Weldon Railroad. The Fifth Army Corps still maintain their position on the railroad, every effort of the enemy to dislodge them proving unsuccessful. Last Friday was very quiet in front of Petersburgh, scarcely a gun being fired during the entire day. On the North side of the James River our lines, up to the latest intelligence received, continued unchanged, notwithstanding the repeated efforts of the enemy to dislodge our forces. The canal was progressing favorably.

abstract: There are no changes to note at any of the theatres, with the exception of Wallack's. At this establishment a new play is produced to-night, called "Eveleen," in which a young artiste, Miss OLIVE LOGAN, makes her debut as the heroine. The lady has previously served an apprenticeship to the stage, and according to the German fashion, has since traveled, and so matured her knowledge of art. Without intending to forestall public opinion, we may say that few artists on the stage have better qualifications for success than Miss LOGAN. Nature has been kindly to her in all the physical requirements of the profession, and much cultivation has, we hope, rendered her capable of using these advantages in the proper way. For particulars of the other places of amusement we refer to our advertising columns.

abstract: The trial trip of this vessel, which was launched about two months since, took place last Saturday, on the Hudson, for the purpose of testing her engines and experimenting with her guns. The vessel was built by Mr. ZENO SECOR, of Jersey City. She belongs to the second batch of monitors, most of which are now in active service. The occasion was anspicious and the weather was clear, with a strong breeze down the river.
lead_paragraph: The trial trip of this vessel, which was launched about two months since, took place last Saturday, on the Hudson, for the purpose of testing her engines and experimenting with her guns. The vessel was built by Mr. ZENO SECOR, of Jersey City. She belongs to the second batch of monitors, most of which are now in active service. The occasion was anspicious and the weather was clear, with a strong breeze down the river. The number of invited guests was large. Including several Europeans of high rank, who were anxious, to investigate the practical worth of the Iron-clads. Among the rest were the officers of the vessel, Capt. WM. A. PARKER, Chief Engineer CHENVER and others. Also, Admiral Gregory, Capt. Rogers, Capt. Boggs, Messrs. colwell and Broadnax, Capt. Worden, Messrs. Secor, and Mr. Birkbeck, superintendent, who had general supervision of the vessel. At 10 o'clock, when the vessel started under the guidance of two tugs, she was the object of curiosity from a large number of spectators on the different plers and vessels in the vicinity. But, swinging around against a heavy breeze, the splendid craft steamed up the Hudson, without any incumbrance, in fine style, and in half an hour was lost to view. The river was rather rough, and the larger waves frequently dashed up on the bomb-proof deck, making a clean sweep, to the discomfort of the "land-lubbers." Under the disadvantages of heading against a strong breeze and the working of new machinery, the vessel made six knots an hour by the log; under favorable circumstances she will make about nine knots. She has all the gracefulness which appertains to her peculiar class, and is certainly one of the finest specimens of the monitors. Her length is 235 feet; extreme beam over armor, 46 feet; breadth of beam of boat proper, 37 feet; depth of hold, 13 feet; sheet of deck, 12 inches. The general characteristics of the vessel are as well known as "household words," and need no description. The engines worked admirably; no accident occurred, and the trip to the engineers was entirely successful. The armament consisted of two 15-inch Dalghren smooth bore guns, both long-range, and sixteen inches longer than any gun yet put in a turret. The weight of one was 43,110 pounds, and the weight of the other 42,970 pounds. When the vessel hove to off the palisades, a little above Fort Lee, these guns were tested. There were three discharges from each gun, composed respectively of one shell, one solid and one cased shot, the latter only a little lighter than a solid shot,) which weighed about 440 pounds. The charge for the shell was thirty-five pounds of powder, and for others it was fifty pounds. Upon each discharge the recoil of about 4 1/2 feet was about the same, the concussion being mostly outside of the turret, as the gun projected through the ports. The result was quite satisfactory, the length of time consumed in loading the pieces, perhaps, being the only objection. As the last gun was fired, a signal was given for the guests to proceed to lunch. An excellent collation was served up in the messroom, to which ample justice was done. A fast tug, which had been laying near by, then took off as many as wished to land in New-York, leaving those who wished to proceed in the Mahopec to the Brooklyn Navy-yard. At about five o'clock the iron-clad was safely moored at the navy-yard, where she will be fitted out immediately for active service.

abstract: Denmark vows one month she'll never yield an inch. The next month she yields everything. One moon she is all defiance, the next moon all submission. And yet where is there stiffer stuff than in that old Scandinavian race? Who will say that there is tougher grit in our Southern rebels? It has always been a received fact that mobility and fickleness are Southern, and not Northern qualities.

abstract: Brooklyn--Newton, Murdered by his Son
lead_paragraph: An old man, named FREDERICK NEWTON, residing in Madison-st., near Franklin-av., Brooklyn, was beaten so seriously by his son RICHARD NEWTON, on Saturday night, that he died from the effects of his wounds at the City Hospital yesterday afternoon. There were a number of conflicting stories in regard to the melancholy affair, and it was almost impossible to obtain a correct account yesterday. It was well known that the father and son had been upon rather bad terms, and It is reported that while under the influence of liquor on Saturday evening, he went to the apartments of his son and smashed his door down; in fact, this is the statement which the accused made after his arrest by Officer WILLMARTH, of the Forty-ninth Precinct, yesterday afternoon. He contends that the old man created the affray, and struck him on the head after breaking in his door. He then seized a laborer's shovel and dealt the old man a blow on the top of his head, knocking him down in the half-way. He then went out and made a charge to the police against the old man, of drunkenness and disorderly conduct; and an officer took him in a senseless condition to the Forty-ninth Precinct Station, under the impression that he was stupid from the effects of liquor. The accused of course went off rejoicing at, as he thought, getting rid of the deceased so easily. Capt. WADDY, as is his habit, examined the old man, and found that he was bleeding from the wound on his head. He sent for Dr. WOODSUFF, who was near at hand, and had the wounds dressed. During the night, however, the deceased grew worse, and the Captain again sent for the Doctor. A further examination revealed the fact that his skull was fractured, and that he had a congestion of the brain. He was then sent to the City Hospital, where be. was examined by Dr. COCHRANE and the Hospital physicians, who stated that it was impossible for him to survive more than a few hours. The deceased died in four hours after. Officers were immediately sent in search of the accused, and he was arrested and lucked up to await the result of the investigation to be held by Coronet Norris this afternoon.

abstract: A correspondent writing from Admiral FARRAGUT's fleet, says the ram Tennessee surrendered because her Admiral was wounded. She could have made a long fight had the men not been so dispirited by his loss. Her stern post was so jammed by the same shot that wounded BUCHANAN that the gun could not be run out, but she still had five heavy Brookes' rifles, to use. Her stern and sides were very much battered by our shot. But one had penetrate her -- this was a 15-inch solid shot from the Manhattan, the was shot of that size that struck her. The battle was finished three hours and a quarter from its commencement.

abstract: The Copperhead wing of our "Constitutional Unionists" seems now practically identical with our "Peace Democrats," and well represented by GARRET DAVIS and Lieut.-Gov. JACOB. Neither can say too much against the Administration, and both call the President a tyrant deserving the fate of CHARLES the First. Mr. JACOB predicts 80,000 majority in Kentucky for McCLELLAN, though he might not get even a fourth of that, if any at all.

abstract: Yale College Mutual Insurance Against Draft
snippet: Yale College Mutual Insurance Against Draft
lead_paragraph: An advertisement appears requesting the Alumni of Yale College, in this City, to meet "to devise and adopt a method of mutual insurance against the draft." Et tu, Brute! Educated men, too, plotting evasion and desertion. The Republic calls upon her sons to defend her. destruction is inevitable. And yet every-where there is a disposition to get clear of the duty. How to escape the draft, is the leading question of the day. All devices are resorted to. The gutters are dragged for substitutes. Traps are set in Europe. Negro slaves, who owe to the Republic nothing but curses, are driven to the rescue. Anything, anything but a straightforward, personal response to patriotic obligations. The scathing words of Maj.-Gen. SHERMAN, from the front the other day, against the prevailing shifts, were deserved. This shirking is a disgrace to the cause, or rather it is a disgrace to the men who profess to support the cause. The war for the salvation of the Republic is as sacred as ever; no conduct of ours can make it a whit the less righteous or glorious. But such a way of sustaining it as is fast becoming general throughout the North, is a shame to Northern manhood. It is particularly a shame in Northern educated men.

abstract: Exchange South, and Rebel Anxiety for
snippet: Exchange South, and Rebel Anxiety for
lead_paragraph: The anxiety of the rebels for an exchange of prisoners at this time takes a singularly contradictory way of manifesting itself. At Charleston, as will be seen by our correspondent's letter from the Department of the South, there is a threatened recurrence to the barbarism of putting a large number of Union prisoners under fire. Six hundred of our officers are now retained in Charleston jail for the purpose of being thus exposed, provided the rebel terms of exchange are not acceded to. JONES, the rebel General in command at Charleston, has, meanwhile, been notified by Gen. FOSTER, commanding the Union forces before the city, that he will place six hundred rebel officers in an exposed position on Morris Island the moment the threat of putting the Unionists under fire is carried out. We should hope that whatever may be the temporary loss we suffer in the exchange, this business will be arrested before it goes further. Gen. FOSTER, it is understood, has sent to Washington for instructions; let us hope that these instructions will embrace other considerations beside those of strict military expediency. That, of course, would be not only the prime, but the only consideration were we reduced to the necessity of fighting the rebels, man for man. But with the vast preponderance of the national force in numbers, we can afford to have regard in our exchange, as well to the long endurance of our poor, suffering, half-famished soldiers now prisoners at the South, as to the mere etiquette on which a strictly equitable mutual release should take place. The patient endurance, the noble resignation, the unconquerable fidelity of the Union prisoners at the South demand sacrifices by the War Department, but they are sacrifices which we feel assured our people would make good by extra efforts at volunteer recruiting, rather than have a general exchange delayed.

abstract: Later intelligence from the front represents our losses in the fight at the Weldon Railroad as heavier than heretofore reported. It appears that the attack was a surprise to our forces, many of them being in their shelter-tents at the  time, to escape the heavy rain that was falling.
lead_paragraph: Later intelligence from the front represents our losses in the fight at the Weldon Railroad as heavier than heretofore reported. It appears that the attack was a surprise to our forces, many of them being in their shelter-tents at the time, to escape the heavy rain that was falling. After a feint about noon, in front of the Third Division of the Fifth Corps, the rebels, at 3 o'clock, charged in heavy force between the Fifth and Sixth Corps, and succeeded in turning the flank, of the former, and capturing a number of prisoners. The advance of the enemy was checked by the arrival of the Ninth Corps. At the same time a heavy column of the rebels obtained a temporary advantage on our extreme left, where they took several hundred prisoners. Our whole line was forced back for a time, with considerable loss -- the enemy also suffering severely -- but our men were reformed before dark, and being strengthened by reinforcements, a desperate charge was made to recover the lost ground. This effort was successful, so that at night our forces occupied the same line from which they had been forced in the afternoon. Our loss is estimated at over three thousand.

abstract: WALLACK'S THEATRE. Miss. OLIVE LOGAN made her first appearance at this establishment last evening in a new drama called "Eveleen." The place is strongly sensational, and in that point of view, is better written, and contains more felicitous language than we expect or find in similar productions. Miss. LOGAN comes of a recognized dramatic family, and her infuitions give promise of a brilliant career.
lead_paragraph: WALLACK's THEATRE. -- Miss. OLIVE LOGAN made her first appearance at this establishment last evening in a new drama called "Eveleen." The place is strongly sensational, and in that point of view, is better written, and contains more felicitous language than we expect or find in similar productions. Miss. LOGAN comes of a recognized dramatic family, and her infuitions give promise of a brilliant career. She has had a slight experience of the stage, but being yet young, it was at a time when routine had no acceptable significance. An interval of six years has enabled her to educate her mind in the best school of Europe, and a susceptible temperament gives her the power of thinking action, and rendering it, too, passionately and earnestly. But in art it is always necessary to measure space between the artist and the public. A painter places his picture in such a position that the stronger colors are merged in their weaker neighbors, and so the design becomes distinct yet soft; powerful but unobtrusive. Miss. LOGAN's inspirations are all good; they indicate a rare intelligence, but they lack the exact balance of art. A new actress of promise should be received with glad welcome, and we desire to hall Miss LOGAN cordially. She has every natural and acquired qualification for the profession she graces. Her voice is melodious, her presence charming, and her talent very distinct and discernable. She needs nothing, in fact, but practice. Not to be impetuous, not to act "too close," not to sway the figure in sudden gusts of grief and tribulation -these are the mechanical restraints that she has to impose upon herself; restraints which it is obvious an intelligent mind will accept as necessities of the distance that separates the actress from the audience. For the rest, Miss LOGAN may safely be left to herself. Her abilities will speedily place her in the front rank of artists.

abstract: and Blockade Running
lead_paragraph: Some four months ago, we published a speech, delivered to the Bahama Legislature by Mr. C.J. BAYLEY, who happens to be Governor of the islands for the time being. Possibly many of our readers have forgotten that in that speech Mr. BAYLEY dwelt -- almost to the exclusion of other topics -- upon the satisfactory condition of the trade in blockade-running. His congratulations of the islanders were uttered with as much cordiality as if they had been preparing to furnish a supply of raw cotton for the whole of Europe. And the speech, with all its felicitations, was transmitted to the Colonial Office in London, for the approval of the Secretary of State.
headline: {'main': 'The Bahamas and Blockade-Running.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Bahamas and Blockade-Running.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We are informed by an officer of FARRAGUT's fleet, that the action had hardly ceased before boats loaded with vegetables and fruit, which the owners were anxious to sell, came off to the vessels. They would not receive Confederate money, but clutched greenbacks and postage currency eagerly. An officer offered one of them a silver quarter for a large melon; the poor fellow fell overboard in his frantic efforts to grasp the desired coin.

abstract: This war, like all wars has abounded with personal disgraces, but it would be hard to name one more painful or scandalous than that now fastened upon Surgeon-General HAMMOND.
lead_paragraph: This war, like all wars has abounded with personal disgraces, but it would be hard to name one more painful or scandalous than that now fastened upon Surgeon-General HAMMOND. When raised to his high position, two years ago, he had high repute in his profession and a stainless name. There was universal confidence alike in his character and his abilities. His first stage of official duty was marked by what seemed to be great faithfulness and efficiency. In time, whispers began to be heard about irregularities and abuses in his administration. They were imputed to jealousy and other sinister motives, and were not heeded. Even when these whispers had gradually grown into loud and strong accusations, the public continued incredulous. It finally became the duty of the Government to investigate them, and for that purpose the President ordered a court-martial, last Winter, consisting of nine officers of high rank and character. A trial was had, lasting nearly four months, conducted with remarkable patience and thoroughness. This trial was private, but so unwilling was the public mind to think such a man guilty, that it hardly imagined any other result than an honorable acquittal. The press almost universally, without distinction of party, abstained from all comment, and even surmise. The court weighed all the testimony, heard the defence of his able counsel, adjudged him guilty, and sentenced him to be dismissed the service, and to be forever disqualified from holding any office of honor, profit or trust under the Government of the United States. This decision underwent review by the Judge-Advocate-General, was sanctioned by the President, and is now promulgated.
headline: {'main': 'The Fall of Surgeon-General Hammond.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Fall of Surgeon-General Hammond.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The assets of this company now reach $708,502. Its semi-annual dividend of five per cent, has recently been declared, and $341,946 has been reserved for reinsurance. It is both a Fire and Marine Company, and the assured receive seventy-five per cent, of the net profits without incurring any liability, or a liberal discount is made on the premium. The losses are liquidated in gold if the premiums are similarly paid. -- Journal of Commerce.

abstract: It seems to be nearly certain that a proposal will soon be made to us from some quarter -- either from LINCOLN or from the Chicago Democratic Convention, to assent to an armistice, or simple cessation of hostilities, to allow of negotiations "for peace and reunion," and for that alone. A New-York paper most urgently advises LINCOLN himself to take the initiative in this, in order "to disarm and silence the demoralizing peace faction at the North," because it shrewdly guesses that such armistice and negotiations would be refused. This is merely a move to take the wind out of the Democratic sail. Whether LINCOLN is to make such a proposal now, or whether the Democrats are to carry in their candidate expressly that he may make it -- from whencesoever it may oucur, it is wholly inadmissible. If the North desires to have negotiations for reunion entered upon at all, let all troops and blockading fleets be withdrawn and the right of secession formally acknowledged, and then negotiation would be at least possible. If they invite us to negotiate on any other footing our only rational answer would be another blow at the heart of Pennsylvania. We are not likely to consider the question of reunion with a sword hanging by a hair over our heads; and if such a proposal be made we shall only conclude that it means war, and endless war, until one nation or the other shall be subjugated or extirpated.
lead_paragraph: It seems to be nearly certain that a proposal will soon be made to us from some quarter -- either from LINCOLN or from the Chicago Democratic Convention, to assent to an armistice, or simple cessation of hostilities, to allow of negotiations "for peace and reunion," and for that alone. If the North desires to have negotiations for reunion entered upon at all, let all troops and blockading fleets be withdrawn and the right of secession formally acknowledged, and then negotiation would be at least possible. If they invite us to negotiate on any other footing our only rational answer would be another blow at the heart of Pennsylvania. We are not likely to consider the question of reunion with a sword hanging by a hair over our heads; and if such a proposal be made we shall only conclude that it means war, and endless war, until one nation or the other shall be subjugated or extirpated.

abstract: -- An exhilarating dispatch from Washington has already announced that the "fall of Fort Morgan is only a question of time." We think we have seen the same statement before about several other places, including Richmond, Atlanta and the entire Southern Confederacy. In each and all of these cases, the remark is doubtless true, in a general sense; but the dispatch about Fort Morgan is correct in a strictly military view. Had the dispatch-writer been aware that Fort Morgan was invested, and had he kept in mind the very trite military anxiom that a "place besieged is a place taken" he would have seen that it was not necessary to [???]o[???]ster up the public faith with a stereotyped formula which has been so often misapplied during the war, and which is now so often laughed at.

abstract: By the arrival, yesterday, of the Cunard steamer China we have dates from Liverpool to the 13th and from Queenstown to the 14th inst. American news was anxiously awaited in England, where intelligence of GRANT'S renewed activity before Richmond had been received.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival, yesterday, of the Cunard steamer China we have dates from Liverpool to the 13th and from Queenstown to the 14th inst. American news was anxiously awaited in England, where intelligence of GRANT'S renewed activity before Richmond had been received. The Confederate loan was flat and drooping. The father-in-law of Prince METTERNICH has written a letter to President LINCOLN, expressing his conversion to the cause of the North. The London Times reviews the recently published journals of Capt. SEMMES and other officers of the Alabama, which it characterizes as rather dull reading. The question of removing the British troops from Canada is agitated in England. The Dano-German question is still discussed, but the people of the Duchies, it appears, are to have as little voice in the settlement of their affairs as they had under the Danish Crown.

abstract: The Board of Supervisors met yesterday. Supervisor PURDY introduced a preamole and resolutions, which were adopted, setting forth that Supervisor BLUNT has gleaned information from the naval enlistment depots, of naval enlistments to the number of over 24,000, which shall be claimed upon the quota of the City, and directing the Volunteer Committee to act in conjunction with Gov. SEYMOUR and his associate Commis- ...
lead_paragraph: The Board of Supervisors met yesterday. Supervisor PURDY introduced a preamole and resolutions, which were adopted, setting forth that Supervisor BLUNT has gleaned information from the naval enlistment depots, of naval enlistments to the number of over 24,000, which shall be claimed upon the quota of the City, and directing the Volunteer Committee to act in conjunction with Gov. SEYMOUR and his associate Commissioner in the matter of such enlistments, to make such a claim, and to ask a postponement of the draft, the exemption of firemen, uniformed militia and the police, and also to represent the "hardship of taking heads of families upon whom devolves the duty of providing means for their support." The resolution, which is of a remarkable character in many respects, and appears as if framed to pre-announce the results of some special labor of the Volunteer Committee, may be found entire in another column. Communications were received from the Harlem Bridge Commission, proposing to divide the cost of building the bridge according to the lineal feet of the structure, within the jurisdiction of Westchester and, this county, and from the Tax Commissioners, stating that the assessment rolls will be ready for delivery to the Board on next Friday. A report was presented against giving the Department for the Survey and Inspection of Buildings a contingent fund. The Mayor vetoed the resolutions to pay substitutes for citizens, on the ground of want of a specific appropriation, and that the present fund is for the purpose of obtaining "acceptable volunteers." The board adjourned to noon on Friday, to receive the assessment rolls.

abstract: The belligerent forces in the valley keep active. On Sunday a considerable engagement oc  curred two miles cast of Charlestown, on the Summit Point road. The attack was made by the enemy, and the Sixth Corps bore the brunt of the engagement, sustaining the chief loss, which was 370 in killed, wounded and missing.
lead_paragraph: The belligerent forces in the valley keep active. On Sunday a considerable engagement oc curred two miles cast of Charlestown, on the Summit Point road. The attack was made by the enemy, and the Sixth Corps bore the brunt of the engagement, sustaining the chief loss, which was 370 in killed, wounded and missing. WILSON's division of cavalry were also engaged, and suffered considerably, but the rebel loss in all cases was fully as great as our own. Gen. SHERIDAN's army now occupies a strong position near Halltown, four miles west of Harper's Ferry, and between that point and Charlestown. The rebels have been reported in possession of Martinsburgh; but a late dispatch from Hagerstown says the place is now occupied by a part of Gen. AVERILL's command. Telegrams from Gen. SHERIDAN's lines up to yesterday P.M. report no new movements.

abstract: Andersonville; Petition from
lead_paragraph: A delegation, consisting of four Union prisoners just released from Andersonville, Ga., will have an early interview with the President, for the purpose of presenting the case of the thirty-five thousand Union soldiers now penned up at that place as prisoners of war. The statement which these men are prepared to lay before the President is horrifying to a degree far beyond what the experience of this war has brought hitherto. In an inclosed field of thirty acres of ground, exposed to the heat of an all but tropical sun, fed upon a daily ration for each man of three-quarters of a pound of dirty corn bread and two ounces of rancid swine flesh, and supplied with water from a stagnant ditch, which forms the receptacle of the excrement of the camp, are thirty-five thousand of our bravest soldiers -- the men who were the foremost in the hard-fought field, and the most daring in the final grapple and crisis of battle. There they swelter and rot, or go raving mad, or find an end to it by crossing the "dead line," where the friendly rifle of the sentinel brings them final release without the aid of cartel or Commissioner. A seething, reeking pen, surcharged with horrors unimaginable. Pestilence in every form of deadly fever, scurvy and nameless disease raging with undisputed sway; and death making its daily harvest of half a hundred.
headline: {'main': 'The Union Prisoners at Andersonville.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Union Prisoners at Andersonville.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
