abstract: On Monday the County Volunteer Committee forwarded to Gov. SEYMOUR and Maj. TOWNSEND, the Commission appointed by the Secretary of War to ascertain the number of naval enlistments in this State since the commencement of this war, a voluminous report containing the names, ages and residences, of over twenty-six thousand naval recruits. This report will be forwarded immediately to the War Department by the Commissioners, and every possible exertion will be made to have this County credited with these 26,000 men. If they are successful in their efforts, and many who are in positions to be able to judge, think they will be, this City will have a surplus of some 6,000 men, and there will be no necessity for a draft.

abstract: It has now been ascertained, since the rebels recrossed the Potomac, that about seven miles of the track has been torn up above Martinsburgh, and between that point and Opequan Bridge, the rails bent in all imaginary shapes and the cross-ties turned. All the bridges between the point named have also been more or less, damaged. It is supposed that it will require fully two weeks to make the necessary repairs for running trains, at the end of which time, should there be no more visits from the rebels, the road with be in full operation to Wheeling. -- Wheeling Intelligencer, Aug. 13.

abstract: and Peace; National Intelligencer on
lead_paragraph: The National Intelligencer persists in maintaining that President LINCOLN stands pledged, not only by the letter "to whom it may concern," but also by his Emancipation Proclamation, not to receive or consider any proposition for peace with the rebels which does not embrace the abandonment of Slavery as well as the restoration of the Union. It holds that he is bound to prosecute the war for the abolition of Slavery, even after its prosecution ceases to be necessary for the restoration of the Union. We have already given our reasons for not concurring in this opinion. We do not believe that Mr. LINCOLN is so pledged by his antecedents or by his declarations, -- nor do we believe that his practical conduct of the Government will be guided by such a theory. If JEFFERSON DAVIS should offer, on behalf of the men in arms under him against the Union, to return to his allegiance to the Constitution and Government of the United States, we believe that President LINCOLN would thereupon stop the war. We do not believe that he would continue it for an hour longer, for the abolition of Slavery or for any other purpose. The Union saved, all other questions at issue would be at once remanded to the decision of the proper tribunals, -- and, if desired by the proper authorities, the Constitution itself would be submitted to the revision of a Convention.

abstract: There were two battles of considerable magnitude on Sunday last one on the Weldon Railroad and the other on the Upper Potomac, near Charlestown. In both instances the rebels were the attacking party. On the railroad, where the rebel assault upon Gen. WARREN was made, with two divisions, they were repulsed with heavy loss.
lead_paragraph: There were two battles of considerable magnitude on Sunday last one on the Weldon Railroad and the other on the Upper Potomac, near Charlestown. In both instances the rebels were the attacking party. On the railroad, where the rebel assault upon Gen. WARREN was made, with two divisions, they were repulsed with heavy loss. At Charlestown the rebels effected nothing, though the subsequent movements of our troops, and the object of their movements, are not sufficiently definite for us, at this writing, to set forth the precise situation of affairs.

abstract: Discussion with J. E. McDonald
lead_paragraph: The political campaign now in progress in the State of Indiana is one of the most remark- able that has taken place for many years in the West, and is exciting great attention and in terest, not only throughout that State, but in the adjoining States of Illinois and Ohio. The two candidates for the office of Governor (OLIVER P. MORTON, the present incumbent, and JOSEPH E. MCDONALD, the opposition nominee,) are traveling together over the State, and discussing before immense audiences the all-important national questions of the day. Ample notification is given beforehand as to the time and place for the debate, and the people flock in from all the country around. A letter from Laporte, describing the recent discussion there, says: "There were delegations from all the towns and villages in this region. Large wagons decorated with evergreens and poles, pendant with rational emblems, and filled with sturdy farmers from the prairies, with their wives, daughters and sweethearts, came into town at an early hour, and at the time appointed wended their way to the grove, and arranged themselves around the speakers' stand." While there has always been displayed on both sides an earnestness befitting the great theme, the discussions have been characterized by the highest personal courtesy on the part of the disputants. The arrangement between the parties on several, if not all of the occasions, has been that Gov. MORTON should open the debate with a speech of an hour's length, followed by a speech of an hour and a half from his opponent, who, in turn, is succeeded by the first speaker in a half hour's closing speech. In this campaign, Gov. MORTON has shown himself to be a masterly debater, with a grand, bold, comprehensive, Western sweep of mind, with a keen and incisive force of logic, with great popular power, and with an all-sacrificing patriotism, that glistens through all his thoughts and sentences, as it has shone forth splendidly in all his deeds during the last four years.
headline: {'main': "The Political Campaign In Indiana--Gov. abstract: HENRY BURKE, an errand boy, aged 14 years, residing at No. 63 Thompson-street, was brought before Justice LEDWITH Tuesday at the Jefferson Market Police Court, charged on the complaint of Mr. JOHN GREEN, of No. 160 Thompson-street, with having robbed him (complainant) of his watch, valued at $15. It appears that young BURKE accosted GREEN, while passing through Spring-street the evening previous, and while the latter was endeavoring to answer BURKE's question, he snatched GREEN's watch from his pocket and ran rapidly away. GREEN pursued him several blocks, and finally lost sight of him in Mercer-street. Yesterday, however, he saw him again in Spring-street, and delivered him into the custody of Officer MCCAUL, of the Eight Precint. He was committed to answer in default of $500 bail.

abstract: The ship Victoria, Capt. CHAMPION, from London, arrived at this port last evening, having on board the man MULLER, who murdered a Mr. BRIGGS in a London railway carriage about two months ago, and for whose arrest the London authorities sent out several detectives. One of the London officers and Officer TIEMAN, of the New-York detective force, boarded her at Quarantine, and will probably bring MULLER to the City this morning.

abstract: the Defence of
lead_paragraph: There is nothing new in the spirit in which the London press approaches the question of maintaining an imperial military force in the neighboring provinces. And the lecture ad dressed to the Canadian people by the leading English journal, which we publish in another column, will not be likely to alarm any large section of the province. As a specimen of drivel, it can probably bear comparison with anything lately published on that or any similar topic. The whole question is reduced to the problem of what might follow if a whole regiment of red-coats were captured on the Canadian frontier by a given number of United States soldiers. War, of course, between the United States and Great Britain would be the result. Therefore the regiment of redcoats must not be exposed to any such mischance. That is the argument in the vulgate. But it is not the argument in superfine English, thus: "We post fragments of our army in positions where they may be at any moment surprised, much as King Alfred suspended golden bracelets in lonely woods, and challenged anybody to offend justice by appropriating them."

lead_paragraph: -- Marshal MURRAY on Monday last seized thirty-two cases, containing from fifty to eighty revolvers each, of the Savage Arms Company patent. abstract: Crediting Enlisted Men; Gen Shepley's Decision
snippet: Crediting Enlisted Men; Gen Shepley's Decision
lead_paragraph: It would be wise not to be in haste to look for too much from the uncredited naval en listments, as affording promise of relief from the draft. It is doubtless true that a large body of naval recruits enlisted in New-York have not been credited to the City, and it may be equally true that were the uncredited num bers assigned to the districts from which they enlisted, our quota under the President's last call might possibly be found to be filled. But Gen. SHEPLEY, who is in command at Norfolk, Va., has just given a decision in the case of three soldiers enlisted in New-York, which, if it is sustained by the military authorities, would upset all the calculations that have been founded on the excess of naval recruits which New-York can show.

abstract: Elsewhere we print a communication, from a source entitling its statements to credit, setting forth the embarrassments and annoy ances in the way of putting recruits in the naval service, as the system is now managed.
lead_paragraph: Elsewhere we print a communication, from a source entitling its statements to credit, setting forth the embarrassments and annoy ances in the way of putting recruits in the naval service, as the system is now managed. This is not the first complaint we have received. We have heard so much grumbling at the manner in which loyal and earnest citizens have been treated by some of the naval authorities, that the matter deserves public notice. Surely there should be no obstacles in the way of dispatching this business with thoroughness, safety and rapidity. Yet that such obstacles exist is indisputable. Facts have come to our knowledge which convince us that there is serious dereliction somewhere. The statements of our correspondent are quite lenient, and when he says that no respectable gentleman will submit to the annoyances and indignities to which the present system necessarily subjects him, he states what is quite true. What do the authorities mean? Can they not see the daily result of the present condition of things? Does it not inevitably tend to discourage enlistments and disgust men with the service, when the recruit is subjected to so much delay and expense? Are men imbued with a spirit of loyalty and respect for the Government which they propose to serve, when traitorous workmen in the Navy-yard are allowed to blackguard and ridicule recruits as they pass along the avenue -- to call them "victims" --"abolitionists," etc. -- to approach them and advise them not to enlist, as they have done? Are gentlemen who seek necessary and proper information to be rudely rebuffed by the officials, because they ask a civil question -- as was done but yesterday? Can no system be devised by which parties visiting the rendezvous or the yard with recruits may know what to do and how to do it? Cannot the routine which a recruit must pass through be made so plain that he can get into the service without unnecessary loss of time, patience or money?

abstract: Yesterday a match between the Manhattan Club of New-York and the Union Club of Newark, N.J., came off on the ground of the latter club. There was a large and highly respectable attendance to witness it, and a great deal of interest was manifested in the game, which was very closely contested. The Manhattan Club were short two of their strongest players, but they succeed in obtaining the victory by 12 runs -- the scores standing: Manhattan 41 and 53; Newark, 29 and 53.

abstract: -- The competitive examination for a West Point cadetship, in ANSON HERRICK's Congressional District, took place Monday, at the Hall of the Board of Education. There were twenty-two competitors. The examination was conducted by City Superintendent RANDALL, under the supervision of Judges CARDOZO and GARVIN, City Chamberlain DEVLIN, the President of the Board of Education and a large number of the friends of the competing pupils. The examination embraced arithmetic, writing from dictation, geography, history, politics, philosophy, &c. The successful candidate was ROBERT FLETCHER, of No. 222 West Forty-eighth-street.

abstract: It is not generally known that the numerous light-draft iron-clads building at this port are to undergo a radical change in their original design. What that change is experiment and time will alone develop. The first one of this class of monitors was launched some time since at Boston; the vessel was launched successfully, but part of the deck remained submerged, and it was found her draft of water far exceeded that which was specified. The Government was at once made acquainted with the facts, and, as a consequence, Capt. ERICSSON is now at work upon her to make her an available craft. All the builders of the light-draft monitors were ordered to suspend operations, and the vessels of this class have remained in statu quo for about two months. The following are the vessels of this class building at this port: The Coho[???]s, building at the Continental Works; the Modoc, building by Mr. UNDERHILL, and one building, by Capt. PERINE, all in Greenpoint. Their general dimensions are: 225 feet long, 45 feet beam, 7 feet 10 inches depth of hold, and draft of water 6 feet 6 inches. They have a single turret and two guns, and are in some points radically different from the seagoing iron-clads. The Modoc was ready to launch when the information was received; her machinery is in, and she is almost finished. The others could be finished shortly if requisite. Nothing will be done, however, until definite orders are received from the Government.

abstract: Maj.-Gen. CURTIS arrived here to-day to straighten up the Indian affairs. The Overland Stage Company have removed all the agents, stock, and coaches to this post for protection. There are no white inhabitants between here and Denver. All have fled to the forts for protection. The road around Denver is reported as swarming with hostile Indians.
lead_paragraph: FORT KEARNEY, Tuesday, Aug. 23.

abstract: The news from Gen. GRANT'S army in front of Petersburgh is to the effect that he still main tains his firm hold upon the Weldon Railroad, and that on Tuesday the rebels were discovered to have withdrawn from Gen. WARREN'S front. Our forces have advanced on the Weldon Railroad to within two miles of Petersburgh without opposition. The rebels have retired within their earthworks, and no longer dispute the possession of the Weldon line.
lead_paragraph: The news from Gen. The rebels have retired within their earthworks, and no longer dispute the possession of the Weldon line.

abstract: -- The recent influx of emigration to this country has been the occasion of stimulating bounty brokers to a renewal of their efforts to swindle unsuspecting foreigners. Instances are occurring daily of attempts to perpetrate outrages on emigrants, which, were it not for the untiring vigilance of Mr. CASSERLY, the General Agent of the Commissioners of Emigration, would result in kidnapping and robbery. Through the admir-table system carried out under the management of that official, the vagabonds who infest Castle Garden are completely precluded from carrying out their nafarious designs. Officers, specially deputized, are stationed at every entrance to the building, and no person not known to have business about the premises is permitted to enter the gates. Loafers and hangers on meet with but little sympathy, and if they attempt to force themselves in are in the most summary manner ejected. Officer BURNS acts as crier, and on the arrival of emigrants, takes pains to proclaim to them their rights, and instructs all concerning their privileges. Cards, printed in large type, are conspicuously posted about the building, on which are stated the amount of bounties every man may expect who wishes to join the army or navy. In every legitimate way the General Agent is disposed to do all that lies in his power to further enlistments; in fact he has been accused of being over zealous in his efforts to sustain the Government. Be this as it may, the public may be assured that affairs at Castle Garden are in good hands.
lead_paragraph: -- The recent influx of emigration to this country has been the occasion of stimulating bounty brokers to a renewal of their efforts to swindle unsuspecting foreigners. abstract: -- The district embraced within the Archiepiscopal authority of Right Reverend Archbishop MCCLOSKEY bears the title of the "Province of New-York," and comprises the dioceses of New-York, Brooklyn, Hartford, Portland, Burlington, Albany, Buffalo and Newark -- New-York, New-England and New-Jersey. The dioceses are constituted as follows: New-York -- the City of New-York and the counties on Hudson River south or 42° north latitude; Brooklyn -- the counties on Loug Island; Hartford -- the States of Connecticut and Rhode Island; Boston -- the State of Massachusetts; Portland -- the States of Maine and New-Hampshire; Burlington -- The State of Vermont; Albany -- the northern and eastern counties of New-York north of 42° north latitude, and east of the counties of Cayuga, Tompkins and Tioga; Buffalo -- all the residue of the State; Newark -- the State of New-Jersey.

lead_paragraph: The President stands firm against every so- licitation to postpone the draft. To the pro crastinators who have asked it, that they may fill their quota by volunteers, his reply is, that for this end, his proclamation gave ample time, and that the army is not to be punished if that time has been wasted. To the alarmist who are concerned lest the draft cannot be enforced without resistance and insurrection, his reply is that, if it has come to this, the quicker the Government proves its power to maintain its laws, the better. To the little calculators of his party who are exercised lest the enforcement of this draft will defeat his election, his reply is that, whatever his fate, he shall do his duty. We rejoice in this spirit. It is precisely what the crisis demands.
headline: {'main': 'President Lincoln and the Draft.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'President Lincoln and the Draft.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Memphis, the Attack on
lead_paragraph: -- The so-called attack on Memphis by FORREST, in the early morning of Sunday last, was a very curious affair. It seems that his men rode into the very heart of the city, assailing the Irving Block, where rebel prisoners are confined, visiting the Gayoso House, (the principal hotel,) plundering the stores, dashing into the headquarters of Gen. WASHBURN, the Commander of the department, rushing into Gen. BUCKLAND's headquarters, and making an effort to capture Gen. HURLBUT, formerly commanding the Department of West Tennessee. It is curious that FORREST, "with three brigades of rebels," should have been able to get near the city without anybody finding it out. Though after he did get near it, it is not curious that he should have been able to enter it. The great work defending Memphis -- Fort Pickering -- is located a mile or two south of the city, and we can hardly suppose that the rebels advanced or were allowed to retreat by the main highway running east from the place, as that is commanded by the guns of Fort Pickering. The garrison must either have been all sound asleep on that early Sunday morning, or the rebels must have struck down from the northeast.
headline: {'main': 'THE ATTACK ON MEMPHIS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE ATTACK ON MEMPHIS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Blakeman, Adj't John P.; Sinclair, Catharine, Authoress
snippet: Blakeman, Adj't John P.; Sinclair, Catharine, Authoress
lead_paragraph: The death of Mr. ROBSON, the lessee of the Olym pic Theatre, London, is announced by the China. The melancholy event took place on Thursday, night, (Aug. 11,) at 12 o'clock. This popular come- dian (says the Men of the Time) was born at Margate, in the year 1821, and was apprenticed at an early age to a copper-plate engraver in the metropolis. Not relishing the occupation, he was tempted to essay the stage, and while yet a young man, made his debut at a private theatre in Catharine-street, in the part of Simm Mealbag, in the drama of " Grace Huntley." Had Mr. ROBSON been wanting in perseverance, the result of his first essay would have deterred him from any further prosecution of his new designs, as several professional critics strongly advised him to abandon all idea of adopting theatrical pursuits; but, fortunately for his future prospects, a conviction of latent power more than counterbalanced the depressing influence of their advice. And after two short provincial engagements at Whitstable and Uxbridge, he again appeared on the London boards, playing at the Grecian Saloon from 1844 to 1849. By this time he had so far acquired a reputation as an original delineator of character, that his services were eagerly sought by several provincial managers, one of whom secured him for the Queen's Theatre, Dublin. At the termination of this engagement, in 1853. Mr. ROBSON returned to London, having accepted an offer from Mr. FARREN, the lessee of the Olympic Theatre. His success was now placed beyond doubt, and so high an appreciation did metropolitan audiences evince of his peculiar talent that the pieces played at the little theatre in Wych-street were mainly selected with the view of affording a vehicle for their exhibition.

lead_paragraph: A most respectable number of wealthy citizens, exempted from the draft by age or from other causes, have responded to the appeal of the Provost Marshal-General, and are now represented in the National army by sound, strong, fighting men. The success of the appeal, indeed, is described by a Washington authority as "astonishing." To give emphasis to the high satisfaction and approval with which the military authorities regard this most grateful mode of recruiting the forces in the field, the Provost-Marshal has provided a diploma in appropriate form which certifies to the patriotic conduct of the citizen who furnishes a representative recruit. abstract: Printing Rebel Lies
lead_paragraph: One of our readers has clipped from Tuesday's TIMES, and inclosed to us, an article which we copied from a Georgia paper, making preposterous statements about the capture of Gen. STONEMAN'S troops, and accusing the gallant General of cowardice; and he indignantly asks us, "Why do you continually copy such things from rebel papers without comment? Many a person reads them and supposes they are true, because the TIMES gives no denial of them."

abstract: - Col. T.C. DEVIN, of the Sixth New-York Cavalry, (Acting Brigadier-General of the Second Brigade. MERRITT'S division,) under orders from Gen. MERRITT, presented on Monday to the Secretary of War two battle flags captured by this brigade at the battle of Front Royal, on the 16th inst., in which the Colonel was wounded. The flags belonged to KERSHAW's division and WICKAM's cavalry brigade, of FITZHUGH LEE's division. The Secretary expressed his gratification in acknowledging the numerous gallant and meritorious services of Col. DEVIN,of which he gave earnest by an appointment of Brevet Brigadier-General for gallantry in the field. The sergeant and privates whose prowess personally secured the colors were present to Mr. STANTON, who courteously thanked them for their gallantry and directed, a medal to be presented to each with his name engraven thereon. There have been but few actions on the cavalry of the Army of the Potomac wherein Col. DEVIN has not appeared conspicuous for courage, and we are gratified to learn that the merits of an officer who has participated in more than forty battles are appreciated by the Secretary of War. -- National Intelligencer.
lead_paragraph: - Col. T.C. DEVIN, of the Sixth New-York Cavalry, (Acting Brigadier-General of the Second Brigade. MERRITT'S division,) under orders from Gen. abstract: In our yesterday's issue we had occasion to notice the arrival of the Swedish steamer Ernest Merck, from Stockholm, with 478 passengers. Certain facts have since come to our knowledge which clearly prove the complicity of the Federal Government in an attempt to kidnap a considerable number of these emigrants, as its agents have already kidnapped thousands of others in order to recruit the armies of the model republic.
lead_paragraph: In our yesterday's issue we had occasion to notice the arrival of the Swedish steamer Ernest Merck, from Stockholm, with 478 passengers. Certain facts have since come to our knowledge which clearly prove the complicity of the Federal Government in an attempt to kidnap a considerable number of these emigrants, as its agents have already kidnapped thousands of others in order to recruit the armies of the model republic. Out of the to tal number of emigrants on board the Ernest Merck, about 250 appear to have been legitimately engaged to work in the Lake Superior mines, and these, we believe, have proceeded westward to their destination. The remainder, some 220, are, however, not to be landed at Quebec, but at Portland, Me. -- having been forwarded, free of charge, by a person named TEFT, who occupies the post of United States Consul at Stockholm. The victims, however, had first to sign an agreement with TEFT, by which they bound themselves to reimburse the "passage money and incidental expenses" -- work being provided for them according to their respective trades and occupations. The men were to receive as remuneration $125 per annum, and the women $40 per annum, "in current money of the United States," together with boarding and lodging. The agreement was signed by the emigrants on the one part, and by Mr. TEFT on behalf of the "Foreign Emigration Association," on the other. No mention appears, however, to have been made of any agent at Portland to whom these poor people could apply for a fulfillment of the contract. This fact alone discloses the nature of the scheme. Every feature of the case, however, shows that the object of this traffic in human flesh is to crowd the Atlantic ports with thousands of destitute foreigners, whose wretched condition must at once force them into the ranks of the army, in order to avoid at least a lingering death. The agency of the United States Consul establishes the official nature of the speculation. A rush of starving emigrants might afford sufficient war material to render another conscription unnecessary, and thus "stave eft" the disturbance another draft is sure to create. And again -- at the terms of remuneration, in Federal currency, set forth in the contract, these unfortunate white slaves would find themselves obliged to work for years in order to repay their passage money and "incidental expenses." It appears that the Swedish authorities did everything in their power to counteract the efforts of the agent of the Foreign Emigration Society; but could not, of course, prevent the embarkation of the emigrants.

abstract: Yesterday was made memorable in the lives of the little orphan cadets at Col. YOUNG's Institute, at Suspension Bridge, by a visit from Gen. HOOKER, The General, who is spending a few days at the Falls, very gladly accepted an invitation to inspect the institute, and was evidently much pleased with it. He reviewed the boys in their military exercises very thoroughly and precisely, and complimented them in the highest terms upon their proficiency. He then addressed them in a very pleasant and touching speech, upon the proud heritage of honor which their fathers have left them and their duty to preserve it untarnished.

headline: {'main': 'SOUTHERN NEWS.; Rebel Accounts of the Late Battles. Names of Federal Officers Captured. HIGH EXPECTATIONS OF WHEELER\'S RAID The Peace Question Vigorously Discussed. What is Expected From the Chicago Convention. What the Rebels Hang Their Hopes Upon. PROSPECTS OF AN EXCHANGE OF PRISONERS. abstract: -- The agents employed by the Aldermen and Supervisors of the various wards to revise the enrollment lists, with a view of finding out the actual amount of excess, are hard at work, and the result thus far promises to show an excess of about one-sixth on the whole enrollment, which, if allowed, would make the, entire quota of the county a little over 6,000, instead of 7,800, as it is now. The revision of the Twentieth Ward lists has been completed, and shows 200 names enrolled of persons who, from over age and manifest physical disability, should not have been enrolled.

lead_paragraph: Whereas the act of Congress of the 28th of September, 1850, entitled "an act to create additional districts in the State of California, and to change the existing districts therein, and to modify the existing collection districts in the United States," extends to merchandise warehoused under bond the privilege of being exported to the British North American Provinces adjoining the United States, in the manner prescribed in the act of Congress of the 3d of March, 1845,which designates certain frontier ports through which merchandize may be exported, and further provides "that such other ports situated on the frontiers of the United States adjoining the British North American Provinces, as may hereafter be found expedient, may have extended to them the like privileges on the recommendation of the Secretary of the Treasury, and proclamation duly made by the President of the United States, specially designating the ports to which the aforesaid privileges are to be extended:"

abstract: Bounty Brokerage and Recruiting
lead_paragraph: Comptroller BRENNAN opened proposals for a county loan, yesterday, of $946,700, to extend to 1880 and 1881, at 6 per cent., for the redemption, on Sept. 1, of the "Soldiers' Substitute Relief Fund Bonds," issued in August of 1863, the new bonds to be entitled "Soldiers' Substitute and Relief Redemption Bonds." Nineteen bids were given by thirteen different parties, and the united sum of their bids was only $227,200. Of this amount $134,000 were offered at par, and the remainder at premium rates of from 1-20th of 1 per cent. to 5 per cent. The Comptroller deferred stating action on the bids till to-day. It is probable that nearly the whole loan will be readvertised. The many calls for money from New-York on county and town bounty bonds now being made, at 7 per cent. interest, for counties and towns in the vicinity of New-York, is supposed to be the cause of our loan failing to be taken yesterday. The savings banks, (of which only one bid yesterday) are also supposed to be prevented from bidding for it, by the withdrawal of deposits for investment in the new National seven-thirties.

abstract: "Carl Benson" of course comprehends that when our learned correspondent "F.L." in the article on Military Honor, which we published last Saturday, spoke of EPAMINONDAS "shouldering his musket," the phrase was used, as the context showed, only in a soldierly and somewhat grim humor. In the same sense, the same paragraph spoke of EPAMINONDAS as a "common grenadier," as a soldier who was denied the "three-starred shoulder-strap" and the "Marshal's baton," and also as a "Field Marshal," when, in fact, in his day there were neither "shoulder-straps," "Marshal's batons," nor "grenadiers." And no one in the wide world knew all this better than the erudite writer who used the phrases and figures.
lead_paragraph: "Carl Benson" of course comprehends that when our learned correspondent "F.L." in the article on Military Honor, which we published last Saturday, spoke of EPAMINONDAS "shouldering his musket," the phrase was used, as the context showed, only in a soldierly and somewhat grim humor. abstract: On Tuesday night last, United States Detective WM. JENKINS arrested in this City a soldier named ERNST BRAUER, on the charge of having been guilty of deserting from the Fifty-seventh Regiment New-York Volunteers. The officer proceeded [???]th his prisoner toward the Provost-Marshal's office, and when they came opposite No. 157 Chatham-street, BRAUER suddenly darted away, and, as is alleged, was on the point of escaping through a back door, when the detective ordered him to halt. No attention being paid to the order on the part of BRAUER, the official fired two shots from his revolver, neither of which took effect. The chase continued until they reached a kitchen in the rear of Mr. MULLER's, and there JENKINS fired a third shot. The ball entered the back part of BRAUER's head, inflicting a wound so serious that he died soon after being conveyed to the New-York Hospital. An inquest will be held on the body this morning by Coroner RANNEY. Detective JENKINS was arrested, and handed over to Officer HUNTERFIELD, of the Fourth Police Precinct. He will be hold to await the result of the inquisition.

abstract: Perversions of Grant's Campaign
lead_paragraph: It has been said that the wolf when learning to read could make nothing out of the letters but lamb, whatever other words they might form. Copperheads have a similar inaptitude. Whatever the military situation, they can never make anything of it but failure. It would seem as if failure were their very meat and drink, and as if their whole heart were constantly set upon it.

abstract: Policy in Withdrawing from European Politics
snippet: Policy in Withdrawing from European Politics
lead_paragraph: The formal withdrawal of England from all active share in the management of European politics, and the formal declaration of the Government, with the approval we will not say of the people, but of the "governing class" -- that is, the middle class -- that she will henceforward, in no case employ force except in self-defence, have a greater significance than most people accord to them, and seem to be the beginning of very extensive changes in the distribution of power among the commonwealth of nations. We in America have for the last four years been so busily engaged in singing the praises of national debt, that we have almost forgotten that the question has two sides, and that there is a good deal to be said on both. A moderate national debt is unquestionably of great value in consolidating a nation with a strong tendency to disintegration, such as Great Britain was a century and a half ago; but there is a point at which the burden may become so great as to partially paralyze the national energies, and lower that mysterious something which for want of a better name we call vitality, and bring on gradual decay. Of this effect of a large debt there could not be a better illustration than Holland, and England seems very likely to furnish another. Holland incurred enormous liabilities, both in the struggle with Spain, afterward with England and Louis XIV., and came out of the ordeal victorious and glorious indeed, but owing so much that she had the cruel alternative presented to her of either surrendering the proud place among nations, which she had won by her valor, or else of breaking faith with her creditors. To her eternal honor she chose the former, shouldered her debt manfully, put on all the taxes the population could possibly bear, and sunk at once to the rank of a third-class Power. She owes now ninety millions sterling, with a population of about two millions, and a soil which has long ago reached the limit of its productiveness -- in other words, forty -- five pounds a head -- while Great Britain does not owe over twenty pounds a head. The Dutch meet the interest on this sum by untiring industry and frugality, and by diligent use of the enormous capital accumulated in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries; but they can do nothing more. They have lost all weight in European councils, and preserve their independence mainly by a vigorous and careful neutrality.
headline: {'main': 'The New Policy of England Philosophy of National Power.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The New Policy of England Philosophy of National Power.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Comptroller BRENNAN yesterday opened proposals for a loan of $946,700 on "Soldiers' Substitute and Relief Redemption Bonds," to redeem the "Substitute and Relief Fund Bonds" of last year. The new loan is to bear 6 per cent. interest, and be paid in 1880 and 1881. The bids for it fell far short of the sum called for, amounting in all to $227,200. The Comptroller will decide to-day which of them he will accept, and what course he will take to dispose of the remainder of the loan. The numerous calls for county loans on county and town bonds, at 7 per cent. interest, just now being made upon the New-York money market, it is believed is the cause of the New-York County loan not being taken yesterday. The following are the bids given for it:
lead_paragraph: Comptroller BRENNAN yesterday opened proposals for a loan of $946,700 on "Soldiers' Substitute and Relief Redemption Bonds," to redeem the "Substitute and Relief Fund Bonds" of last year. The new loan is to bear 6 per cent. interest, and be paid in 1880 and 1881. The bids for it fell far short of the sum called for, amounting in all to $227,200. The Comptroller will decide to-day which of them he will accept, and what course he will take to dispose of the remainder of the loan. The numerous calls for county loans on county and town bonds, at 7 per cent. interest, just now being made upon the New-York money market, it is believed is the cause of the New-York County loan not being taken yesterday. The following are the bids given for it:

abstract: The Eighteenth Regiment Massachusetts Volunteers passed through this City yesterday afternoon, en route for Boston. This regiment entered the service three years ago with full ranks it has been filled by recruiting twice since, so that their muster-roll contains over 1,500 names. They have served their entire time, and now return home but 130 strong, under command of Lieut.-Col. WHITE. They left 141 men in the field who had reenlisted. They have participated in many hard-fought battles, and their decimated ranks show that they have done their duty well.

abstract: Our forces still maintain their position on the Weldon Railroad, a large portion of which has been effectually destroyed. No engagement, up to latest advices, had taken place since Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Our forces still maintain their position on the Weldon Railroad, a large portion of which has been effectually destroyed. No engagement, up to latest advices, had taken place since Sunday. The enemy, as if in despair of recovering possession of the road, have fallen back to their lines, which they are busily engaged in strengthening. Richmond papers acknowledg a heavy loss in the engagement of Sunday, but claim to have taken a large number of prisoners. Gen. WARREN has advanced his line a mile in the direction of Petersburgh.

abstract: Operations on Upper Potomac
lead_paragraph: There is a correspondence as to time between the operations of the army under Gen. GRANT's immediate direction, and the backward march of SHERIDAN form Strasburgh to Charlestown, which would seem to indicate that there were other reasons for the retrograde movement than those that have appeared upon the surface. It will be noticed that it was before the divisions sent from LONGSTREET's corps to the support of EARLY appeared at Thoroughfare Gap, that SHERIDAN's train was ordered back to Winchester.

abstract: The Olympic Theatre will reopen for the season on Monday evening, the 5th of September. We give below a complete list of the company. It will be seen that it includes many well known names, and many that are strange to our public -- probably none the worse for that reason. There will be a warm welcome for the old favorites, and a kindly reception for the new aspirants. The prices of admission are advanced from 25 cents to 30 cents; from 50 cents to 75 cents; from 75 cents to $1, and from $1 to $1 50, No sensible person can object to this reasonable increase.

abstract: Yesterday morning a desperate attempt was made by some twelve or fifteen soldiers -- the most of them enlisted substitutes -- to escape from the guard at the barracks on the Battery. They started to run in a body, when we officers having them in charge ordered them to halt. To this order they gave no heed, when one of the guard leveled his musket and fired. The shot took effect in the brain of one of the would be deserters, named JOHN PETERSEN, killing him almost instantly. The others, seeing the fate of their companion, speedily returned to their [???] at the barracks. The Coroner was notified to hold an inquest on the body.

abstract: Mason's Semi-official Interviews with Lord Palmerston
snippet: Mason's Semi-official Interviews with Lord Palmerston
lead_paragraph: There is a natural curiosity, down South, which finds expression through the Richmond Examiner, to know how it comes about that Mr. MASON is main holding semi-official interviews with Lord PALMERSTON. When, recently, Mr. MASON abandoned his functions as rebel emissary in London, he did so by express order of his "Government." He did so, moreover, we are assured, with the entire approval of "the whole Confederacy." He was ordered to withdraw only after ample proof had been obtained that the English Government refused recognition, and after he had been repeatedly and ignominiously repelled at the doors of the British Foreign Office, by the "supercilious and insolent manner of Lord RUSSELL." To find Mr. MASON, then, "who is very much the superior of that small lord," again dangling in the ante-chamber, is found to be altogether "too much," and the Richmond journalist requests to know why it is so.

abstract: No material change is reported in the military situatlon around Petersburgh. On the right a severe cannonade is kept up in front of the Eighteenth Corps. On the left the line has been extended about six or seven miles, and our forces now hold the Weldon Railroad to Ream's Station. It is surmised that the rebel lines has been contracted on our left front.
lead_paragraph: No material change is reported in the military situatlon around Petersburgh. On the right a severe cannonade is kept up in front of the Eighteenth Corps. On the left the line has been extended about six or seven miles, and our forces now hold the Weldon Railroad to Ream's Station. It is surmised that the rebel lines has been contracted on our left front. The losses of the Fifth Corps in the battles of Friday and Sunday were quite severe. On Thursday morning, a sortie was made by the rebels in front of Gen. BUTLER's right wing. The enemy were repulsed with loss. This attack was probably intended to feel our strength in that quarter.

abstract: THREE DEATHS FROM FALLS. JOHN GEAR, resident at No. 15 Chrystie-street, accidentally fell from a third story window, and was so seriously injured that he died yesterday afternoon at Bellevue Hospital....JOANNA WHITTLE, a native of Ireland, aged 35 years, ...
lead_paragraph: THREE DEATHS FROM FALLS. JOHN GEAR, resident at No. 15 Chrystie-street, accidentally fell from a third story window, and was so seriously injured that he died yesterday afternoon at Bellevue Hospital....JOANNA WHITTLE, a native of Ireland, aged 35 years, residing at No. 140 Cherry-street, while leaning out of a second story window at a late hour on Thursday night, slipped and fell to the pavement. The injuries she received by the fall were so serious that she died soon after....JOSEPH FAHENTHACHER, while employed on the new building, No. 65 Suffolk-street, missed his footing and wan precipitated from the third story to the pavement. His skull was fractured by the fall, and he was otherwise to much injured that he died in a few hours after. Deceased was a native of Germany, aged 33 years, and resided at No. 63 Attorney-street.

abstract: The London railway murder case does not promise so much of interest in the development of what has been called the art of manslaughter, as the copious details of the investigation, since the commission of the crime, at first foreshadowed.
lead_paragraph: The London railway murder case does not promise so much of interest in the development of what has been called the art of manslaughter, as the copious details of the investigation, since the commission of the crime, at first foreshadowed. The brief but pointed inquiry and the evidence taken before the United States Commissioner, yesterday, reduces at once the crime and the criminal to a vulgar and despicable level. Within less than a week of the time when Mr. BRIGGS was found lying, bruised, bleeding and speechless on the railway track, between the Bow and Hackney railroad stations, MULLER had left in different parts of London -- as the testimony taken yesterday shows -- abundant evidence to convict him ten times over. All that remains, indeed, for investigation now, (and this will be done in London,) refers to the precise point at which MULLER got on to the train, and the instrument he used in making his victim so powerless that he was able to throw him out of the narrow window of a tightly-locked first-class English railway carriage.
headline: {'main': 'The Muller Extradition Case.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Muller Extradition Case.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Correspondence on Draft and Politics
lead_paragraph: One would imagine, to listen to much of the talk which is heard about the call for 500,000 and the draft which is likely to follow it, that the raising of men for the United States Army was the cruel freak of an Eastern tyrant; that the war was being carried on for the amusement or gratification of the President and the Cabinet; and that everybody owed it to his family and friends to defraud them of their prey by every conceivable means. The Albany Atlas & Argus contained a real or pretended letter, a few days ago, from a country reader, which represented a prodigious change as having come over the Republicans in his neighborhood; that they were so outraged by the determination of the Government to get more men for the army, that hundreds of them were going to vote against the tyrannical LINCOLN in November. They were raising men as fast as they could -- as fast as a proper attention to their farms and business would let them -- as fast, in short, as was convenient; and to think of drafting simply because they had not made up their quota, and were not likely to make it up, was more than they could endure. The story was told in a strong, bold, democratic way, and was probably half fiction and half exaggeration; but sentiments of this kind crop out in the conversation of a great many people who profess the most unbounded devotion to the war. Some people are furious with the Government for wanting more men; others think it quite natural they should want them, but think it brutal and inhuman that they should not make up their minds to go without them; but a still larger number -- and this class includes a great many "loyal" friends of the Union -- while acknowledging it to be the right and duty of the Government to get recruits, believe it to be the right of the public to prevent its getting them from amongst the native population in every way short of armed resistance; and they act up to their belief. They seem to consider their relations with the Executive something like those of a traveler with an armed highwayman; they surrender with a good grace what they cannot conceal, but nothing more.

abstract: Highway; New-York; McCullum, of $588
lead_paragraph: Two young men, who give their names as JOHN HALEY and THOMAS LAWLER, were arraigned yesterday afternoon before Justice LEDWITH, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, on the charge of having committed a felonlous assault and robbery. The complainant in the case is Mr. PETER CULLUM, of No. 123 West Nineteenth-street, who testified that about 2 o'clock yesterday morning he was passing through Canal-street, and when in the vicinity of Greenwich-street he was suddenly assaulted by three men, one of whom seized him by the throat and choked him until he was unable to stand. While CULLUM was lying partially insensible on the sidewalk, the prisoner, LAWLER, thrust his hand into his victim's pocket and stole therefrom the sum of $588 in bills, with which he made his escape. OfficerPAUL, of the Twenty-eighth Precinct, hearing shouts of "watch" and "murder," was promptly on the spot, and just in time to see three men running swiftly through Greenwich-street, He gave chase, and after about a dozen blocks, finally succeeded in taking HALEY and LAWLER into custody. The other thief, whose name is unknown, made his escape. The prisoners, when taken to the Ponce Court, were fully identified, both by COLLUM and the policeman. Upon examination, they plead innocence, as usual, and both stated they were painters by occupation, and resided in Brooklyn. Justice LEDWITH committed them for trial, in default of $1,500 bail each. No portion of the money bas been recovered.

abstract: Richmond Whig and Dispatch on
lead_paragraph: In addition to the political articles we yesterday quoted from the Richmond press, we copy several others this morning. The long discussion from the Richmond Whig upon the "Chicago Convention, its candidates and Platform," is very ably and shrewdly written, and the writer ostensibly puts it forth for the benefit of the Convention, saying that he "makes no apology for offering suggestions to the Northern Democracy as to their plan for the Presidential campaign." It is to be hoped that the delegates to the Convention, and those whom they represent, as well as the people of the country at large, may give due heed to this voice from Richmond. The Whig is evidently opposed to LINCOLN, and pretends to be opposed to MCCLELLAN; it thinks HORATIO SEYMOUR "might do," and FILLMORE "would be a good selection;" but the candidate of its soul, the hero of its love, the man for the crisis, is DON CARLOS BUELL. Why will not Chicago oblige Richmond by paying some heed to the advice which has been written out with great astuteness for its benefit?

abstract: Yesterday, says the Louisville Democrat of the 24th, Mrs. ALICE GORDON BENNETT was received in this city from the front to be tried as a rebel spy. It appears that a few days since she made her way through our lines near Atlanta, and under disguise had several communications with the officers in command, after which she endeavored to make her way back to the South.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, says the Louisville Democrat of the 24th, Mrs. ALICE GORDON BENNETT was received in this city from the front to be tried as a rebel spy. It appears that a few days since she made her way through our lines near Atlanta, and under disguise had several communications with the officers in command, after which she endeavored to make her way back to the South. While endeavoring to pass through the lines, she was arrested, and sent to this City under guard. She states that her husband is on the Winona, one of Commodore FARRAGUT's fleet, and, at her own request, she will be sent to New-Orleans for trial.

abstract: When the war first broke out, a young married man of Steubenville, Ohio, volunteered. lead_paragraph: -- When the war first broke out, a young married man of Steubenville, Ohio, volunteered. He was reported killed at Perryville, and subsequently his wife received a metallic coffin which purported to contain the body of her husband. She buried it with all due ceremony and affection, and after more than a year elapsed, she married again. A few days since, an exchanged prisoner passed through Steubenville, and left a message from the husband supposed to be dead that he would probably be soon exchanged, and would be home again. Her present husband is worthy man, and the case becomes somewhate barrassing.

abstract: Iron Trade; Memorial to Press on Municipal Reform
snippet: Iron Trade; Memorial to Press on Municipal Reform
lead_paragraph: Resolved, That a letter be prepared and addressed to the New-York Press, requesting their earnest and cordial cooperation with the "Iron Trade" of this City, in aiding in the great movement for reform in our Municipal Government inaugurated by he Citizens' Association of New-York, which has the hearty concurrence and active support of the great masses of workingmen of all the trades in this great metropolis; and that this letter be signed by the President, Vice-President and Secretaries of this meeting.

abstract: One hundred and twenty-five guerrillas entered this place this morning and compelled a negro blacksmith to look after their horses. Shortly afterward they commenced breaking in the doors of the Courthouse, when the same number of Home Guards and a company of the Henry Rifles fired upon them, killing four, including the negro blacksmith, and wounding four. The guerrillas were then driven out of the town without any loss on our side.
lead_paragraph: SHELBYVILLE, Ky., Saturday, Aug. 27.

abstract: A correspondent of a Georgia rebel newspaper gives an account of one of the means adopted by Gen. HOOD to increase the effective strength of his army in this crisis. He is putting a gun into the hands of every unarmed man connected with his force. All of the cooks have been armed and returned to their respective commands, and the negroes connected with the army have been employed in that capacity. Quartermasters and commissaries have been made to disgorge the many superfluous men in their departments; surgeons also. The result is that the army has received a considerable reinforcement. In CLAYTON's division alone the number of new men returned from the cooking detachments reached 800, which, at this time, is considered a good regiment. The increase from the cooks alone will reach 4,000 effective men. But the rebel General, we are told, does not stop here. He has ordered the arming of every artillerist, except from No. 1 to 6, who are absolutely necessary to handle a piece. From this source an increase will be obtained amounting to near 3,000 men.

abstract: The news from the army before Petersburgh, this morning, is again full of deep interest. The rebels do not seem to be willing to give up the contest for the possession of the Weldon Railroad. On Thursday afternoon a heavy force marched ground our left flank to the rear, and suddenly attacked HANCOCK'S corps which was divided ...
lead_paragraph: The news from the army before Petersburgh, this morning, is again full of deep interest. The rebels do not seem to be willing to give up the contest for the possession of the Weldon Railroad. On Thursday afternoon a heavy force marched ground our left flank to the rear, and suddenly attacked HANCOCK'S corps which was divided up into small commands and engaged in destroying the railroad some distance south of Ream's Station. Taken thus at a disadvantage, our troops were thrown into some confusion, and some artillery and a number of prisoners were captured before our men were concentrated.

abstract: There remains just a week more for the final adjustment of quotas in the various districts. As affects New-York, the question still remains to be settled, whether we shall have to fill a deficiency of twenty thousand by the draft, or find the quota more than filled already by uncredited naval enlistments.
lead_paragraph: There remains just a week more for the final adjustment of quotas in the various districts. As affects New-York, the question still remains to be settled, whether we shall have to fill a deficiency of twenty thousand by the draft, or find the quota more than filled already by uncredited naval enlistments. Leaving out of account, however, the temporary and altogether insufficient relief which a recognition of the naval recruits in the Provost-Marshal's summing up would bring us, we do well to consider several important facts in our estimate of the dirty which the emergency demands. The first of these is that the national armies want filling; that uncredited naval recruits do not fill the army; and that by so much as the present draft falls short of bringing the requisite number of men, by that much will the numbers required by a new conscription be increased. The relief we shall get by any system of counting heads in the navy can be but temporary, and whatever may be the issue of the pending decision, the crisis demands fore-thought, work, a national system of recruiting operations, and an expenditure of time as well as money by those who really desire to cooperate with the Government.

abstract: The French papers contain the following odd story: "Letters from Abyssinia state that THEODORE, Emperor of that country, has just crowned his imperial eccentricities by an act which exceeds them all in extravagance.
lead_paragraph: -- The French papers contain the following odd story: "Letters from Abyssinia state that THEODORE, Emperor of that country, has just crowned his imperial eccentricities by an act which exceeds them all in extravagance. Having learned of the widowhood of Queen VICTORIA, he has had a letter written to her offering her his hand. Mr. CAMERON, the English Consul, was charged to forward this missive to his sovereign. The reply to so unforseen an offer not being immediately forthcoming, the Emperor THEODORE got angry, and had Mr. CAMERON put in chains until his Majesty should have obtained satisfaction for such a want of attention toward him. On hearing of the imprisonment of Mr. CAMERON, her Britannic Majesty is said to have decided on replying by a polite refusal, the sending of which by post was more economic than a special mission to Abyssinia.

abstract: The Situation in
lead_paragraph: It must not be inferred from the rose colored accounts of the partisans Of MAXIMILIAN, or from the contemplated withdrawal of a portion of the French force, that the position of the Austrian in Mexico is by any means an enviable one. The partisans of MAXIMILIAN have an evident interest in misleading the outside world as to the real state of affairs; and the recall of a division of the French army may be indicative rather of the anxiety of NAPOLEON to be rid of the business than of his protege's ability to dispense with their services.

abstract: Madman in Railway Carriage
lead_paragraph: The Edinburgh Scotsman reports an alarming incident which occurred in one of the Edinburgh carriages on the Great Northern Railway, on Thursday night: "In one of the third-class compartments of the Express leaving King's Cross Station, at 9:15 P.M., a tall and strongly-built man, dressed as a sailor, and having a wild and haggard look, took his seat about three minutes before the train started. He was accompanied to the carriage by a woman, whom he afterwards referred to as his wife, and by a man, apparently a cab driver, with both of whom he took leave when the train was about to start. It had scarcely done so, when, on putting his hand to his pocket, he called out that he had been robbed of his purse, containing seventeen pounds, and at once began to shout and gesticulate in a manner which greatly alarmed his fellow-travellers, four in number, in the same compartment. He continued to roar and swear with increasing violence for some time, and then made an attempt to throw himself out of the window. He threw his arms and part of his body out of the window, and had just succeeded in placing one of his legs out when the other occupants of the carriage, who had been endeavoring to keep him back, succeeeed in dragging him from the window. Being foiled in this attempt, he turned round upon those who had been instrumental in keeping him back. After a long and severe struggle, which, notwithstanding the speed the train was running at, was heard in the adjoinining compartments, the sailor was overcome by the united exertions of the party, and was held down by two of their number. Though thus secured, he still continued to struggle and shout vehemently, and it was not till some time afterwards, when they managed to bind his hands and strap him to the seat, that the passengers in the compartment felt themselves secure. This train, it may be explained, makes the journey from London to Peterborough, a distance little short of eighty miles, without a single stoppage; and as the scene we have been describing began immediately after the train left London, the expectation of having to pass the time usually occupied between the two stations (one hour and fifty minutes) with such a companion must have been far from agreeable. While the struggle was going on, and even for some time afterwards, almost frantic attempts were made to get the train stopped. The attention of those in the adjoining compartment was readily gained by waving handkerchiefs out of the window, and by and by a full explanation of the circumstance was communicated through the aperture in which the lamp that lights both compartments is placed. A request to communicate with the guard was made from one carriage to another for a short distance, but it was found impossible to continue it, and, as the occupants of the compartments beyond the one nearest the scene of the disturbance could learn nothing as to its nature, a vague feeling of alarm seized them, and all the way along to Peterborough a succession of shows of "Stop the train," mixed with the frantic screams of female occupants, was kept up. On the arrival of the train at Peterborough, the man was released by his captors and placed on the platform. No sooner was he there, however, than he rushed with a renewed outburst of fury on those who had taken the chief part in restraining his violence; and as he kept vociferating that they had robbed him of his money, it was some time before the railway officials could be got to interfere -- indeed, it seemed likely for some time that he would be allowed to go on in the train. As remonstrances were made from all quarters to the station-master to take the fellow into custody, he at length agreed, after being furnished with the names and address of the other occupants of the carriage, to hand him over to the police. The general impression of those who witnessed the sailor's fury sems to be that he was laboring under a violent attack of delirium tremens, and he had every appearance of having been drinking hard for some days."

abstract: We have news from this Republic to the first part of the present month. The Panama Star says that an attempt to create a revolution was made at Monte Cristo, in the province of Manavi, on the 22d and 23d of last month, by a person named CASTRO, a native, and said to own some estates in the vicinity, but exiled on account of his opposition to the present Government. He had landed a short time before from a small vessel in which he had arrived from Peru, having with him several rifles and some ammunition. He appears to have enlisted several people at Manta and places adjacent, and marched into Monte Cristo at the head of some 80 followers, who were, however, soon overpowered by the Government troops, Some of them were taken prisoners, and the remainder escaped to the mountains.

abstract: Party; The North and South
lead_paragraph: There is a good deal of talk of peace just now, and there are large numbers of persons who flatter themselves that the Democratic Convention will in some way or other bring it about. As all such talk, however, has naturally the effect both of discouraging the army and of cheating people at home into indifference or languor as to the progress of the war, we would earnestly advise those who indulge in it, to enter a little into details before doing so any longer -- to turn aside for one moment from the vague declamations of Democratic newspapers about the "horrors of war," and the ambition and villainy of "Old Abe," and look into the plain, stern facts of the case. We hold that anybody who goes about preaching peace without having first asked himself and every authority within his reach whether the South is willing to accept any terms short of independence, and if so, what terms, is guilty of something worse than trifling.
headline: {'main': 'The Peace Party, North and South.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Peace Party, North and South.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: LIBERAL SANITARY CONTRIBUTIONS FROM THE SANDWICH ISLANDS. -- Capt. JAMES MAGEE a sugar planter of Honolulu, sent to this port by the bark Hector, which arrived last week, 100 barrels of molasses, consigned to MCRUER & MERRILL and to be sold for the benefit of the Sanitary Commission. No freight, duty, commission, dryage, wharfage or guaging charges were made. It came free for the sake of the cause. Capt. MAGER follows it up with another 100 barrels of molasses, which are now on the way hither by the bark Yankee. The first invoice was sold to-day at auction, in accordance with the wish of its benevolent donor. Sixteen barrels, containing 30'gallons each, were sold to various parties at the rate of $1 per gallon, bringing $430 in all; and the remaining 84 barrels were sold at the usual market rate of 30 cents a gallon, realizing $756, making the whole amount which was realized for the Sanitary Commission $1,236. -- San Francisco Bulletin, July 30.

abstract: The meeting of this body to-day will concentrate the attention of all parts of the country, rebel as well as loyal.
lead_paragraph: The meeting of this body to-day will concentrate the attention of all parts of the country, rebel as well as loyal. Its postponement from early July, the time first designated for it, was designed to settle its discords. A hope existed that within the eight weeks thus gained to non-committalism, some change would take place in the military situation that would lurch the mass of the party decisively over to the side of war, or of peace, and fix the policy of the convention beyond all controversy. Should such disaster overtake GRANT and SHERMAN as the rebels promised, it was calculated that the peace feeling would set in at the North like a flood, and make the Chicago path clear to a peace platform and candidate. Should GRANT and SHERMAN, on the other hand, consummate their campaigns by the capture of Richmond and Atlanta, it plainly would not answer to give up the old coercive policy which was so effectively crushing out the rebellion. But neither of these events have happened. GRANT has gained possession of one of the two keys of Richmond, but the city is not yet his. SHERMAN has successfully emerged from the dangerous defiles of Northern Georgia, and laid virtual siege to Atlanta; but that stronghold, though it would seem it must soon fall, still baffles him. Just so FARRAGUT has accomplished the first stage of the capture of Mobile with signal success, but the consummation of the work is yet a question. The military situation is no more favorable to the settlement of a definite war policy or peace policy at Chicago now, than it was in July. Every element of discord which was in motion then, has just as free play now. We may, therefore, count upon a scene of intense excitement and perturbation.

abstract: Operations in Shenandoah Valley
lead_paragraph: The terrible blow dealt the rebels on the Weldon line is telling quite as plainly on EARLY'S scouting and foraging expedition in the Shenandoah Valley as either at Petersburgh or Richmond. That terrific hit "by the left" at once sent provision up one hundred per cent. in Richmond, and to-day we read that it has brought EARLY down from his threatening elevation among the hills on the Upper Potomac. Gen. SHERIDAN reports to the War Department, under date of Saturday afternoon, that the enemy left his front on Friday night; that on the latter day he had inflicted on the rebels a severe, loss; and that the indications are that EARLY is making his way up the Valley, toward Richmond, with the utmost dispatch possible.

abstract: Bay; Fort Morgan Surrender
lead_paragraph: The surrender of Fort Morgan has followed so speedily on the capitulation of Fort Gaines, that it may be assumed the rebel garrison, after the latter event took place, contemplated little beyond a show of resistance to the attacking force. The particulars are altogether wanting; but an examination of the dates would seem to point to the conjecture that, whether Fort Morgan was blown up, destroyed by our heavy artillery, or surrendered, as Fort Gaines did, its abandonment was a foregone conclusion from the first successful operations of our forces.

abstract: THEFT OF HORSES AND WAGON. JOHN BOYLE was arraigned yesterday before Justice SHANDLEY, of the Essex Market Police Court, charged with having stolen from Mr. JACQUEE STILLWELL, of Gravesend, ...
lead_paragraph: THEFT OF HORSES AND WAGON. JOHN BOYLE was arraigned yesterday before Justice SHANDLEY, of the Essex Market Police Court, charged with having stolen from Mr. JACQUEE STILLWELL, of Gravesend, Long island, a pair of horses and a market wagon, valued at $750. It appears that on Saturday evening STILLWELL fastened his team to a post in Beekman street, near Front, and went into Fulton Market. When he returned he found his property gone. Some hours after, Boyle was found, trying to dispose of the horses and wagon at a price much below the actual value. The prisoner stated that his design was to take the team to Police Headquarters, but, being intoxicated, he was unable to find his way. The magistrate could not see the force of this defence, and committed him for trial, in default of bail. Boyle is a sailer, 26 years of age, and resides at No. 29 Lewis street.

abstract: Dispatches from Ohio and Kentucky make mention of a tremendous storm which prevailed there on Thursday last. At Columbus the storm raged with great fury.
lead_paragraph: Dispatches from Ohio and Kentucky make mention of a tremendous storm which prevailed there on Thursday last. At Columbus the storm raged with great fury. Trees were uprooted, and the streets of the city flooded with water. At Cincinnati the rain fell in perfect torrents, accompanied by heavy thunder and vivid lightning. The Indianapolis and Cincinnati train, which left at four o'clock, was blown from the track when within thirteen miles of Lawrenceburgh, and the cars were tumbled down an embankment of twelve feet. It is reported that from twenty to thirty persons were wounded. None are reported killed. The train contained a number of delegates en route to the Chicago Convention, but it is stated that none of them were injured. At Louisville, startling peals of thunder and most vivid lighting were its accompaniments. The steeple of Rev. Dr. DANBERTH's church was injured, and several other buildings damaged. A larger quantity of water has fallen than was ever known before to fall in a single day. The train from Nashville was delayed an hour and a half, coming part of the way through the water up to the car axles.

abstract: on Essential Differences Between North and South
snippet: on Essential Differences Between North and South
lead_paragraph: JEFFERSON DAVIS informed Col. JACQUES, in the late interview at Richmond, that there were "essential differences" between the North and South, that will, however this war may end, make them two nations. DE TOCQUEVILLE observed differences between them also, but gave it as his opinion that there was not one which could not be ascribed to Slavery, or which would not disappear if Slavery were removed. But, supposing them to be as DAVIS asserts, "essential," it is quite evident that they have not existed from the beginning, but are of comparatively recent origin, and have been growing. There is no reason to suppose, either, that if separation took place, they would cease to grow. On the contrary, they would, according to all rule, increase day by day, the longer we lived apart. And this fact would, of itself, furnish a reason of the strongest kind for continuing the war as long as may be necessary to render separation impossible, now and forever.

abstract: The Rebel Interest in
lead_paragraph: The rebels acknowledge the importance of the loss of the Weldon Railroad by their desperate efforts to regain possession of it. On Thursday afternoon a heavy force marched around our left flank to the rear, and suddenly fell upon HANCOCK's corps, which was divided into several small commands engaged in the work of destroying the railroad south of Ream's Station. Our troops were thrown at first into a slight confusion, in which some artillery and quite a number of prisoners were captured. Our line fell back, was re-formed, and, advancing to the attack with great spirit, drove back the enemy. After nightfall, perceiving that HANCOCK had been heavily reinforced, the rebels withdrew, leaving their dead and wounded on the field. Their losses were very severe. Our loss was principally in prisoners.

abstract: We learn that the extraordinary conduct of the captain of the gunboat Pontoosuc, in hanging around Eastport some 48 hours after he had positive intelligence that the pirate Tallahassee was coaling in Halifax, and some 24 hours after the receipt of a dispatch from our Cousul at Halifav, requesting him to proceed to intercept her, has excited the disgust and indignation of the citizens of Eastport, as well as that of the Congressional party who witnessed his apparent treachery. Hon. ALEXANDER H. RICR, Chairman of the House Committee on Naval Affairs, was of the party, and we understand that it will not be his fault if the Navy Department does not execute speedy justice upon the outrageous neglect to capture or destroy the pirate -- Bangor Whig.

abstract: The public submit quietly to the increase in stage fares from six to eight cents, because they deem it reasonable and substantially just. But they are not inclined to acquiesce in all the impositions which the omnibus drivers seem inclined to practice. They do not like to be forced to take tickets in change; nor to be treated with rudeness and insolence when they decline. The stage proprietors can very well afford now to provide their drivers with pennies enough for change. If passengers choose to take tickets it is all well enough -- but they have a right to legal change; and if they insist upon it, they should receive it without being badgered or bullied.

abstract: The brig Neva, Capt. TALBOT, from Lingau 17 days, with coal to SIMPSON & CLAPP, arrived here this morning. She left waiting, the bark Irma, COOTTS; brig Kenneb[???]c, BLAIR; schooners Keokuk, SMALL; Mary Sawyer, Ocean Bell, (new,) Rebecca C. Laur, (new,) and Kate Field, all for New-YorK. She reports that on Aug. 17, Cape Sable bearing N.N.W. 18 miles, was overhauled by the Confederate cruiser Tallahassee, and after about an hour's delay, was bonded on vessel and cargo for $17,000. The crew of the fishing-smack North America, of New-London, (she had been but a few hours destroyed,) were put on board the Neva, and were subsequently transferred to another vessel, and sent into New-London.

abstract: An official dispatch from Secretary STANTON states that the capture of Fort Morgan is fully confirmed by dispatches from Gens. GRANT and SHERMAN, who derive their information from Richmond and Mobile papers. It appears from the dispatch of Gen. GRANT that Fort Morgan was surrendered by the rebels, and not blown up.
lead_paragraph: An official dispatch from Secretary STANTON states that the capture of Fort Morgan is fully confirmed by dispatches from Gens. GRANT and SHERMAN, who derive their information from Richmond and Mobile papers. It appears from the dispatch of Gen. GRANT that Fort Morgan was surrendered by the rebels, and not blown up. A special dispatch from Washington indicates that want of supplies may have been one of the chief reasons of the speedy fall of this strong fortress.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing, Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents.
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing, Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European noire, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, givinig the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many or which are otherwise, inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: AN EMBARRASSING SITUATION -- Some three years ago a man living in the Nineteenth Ward entered a Philadelphia regiment, and left for the seat of war. After his departure he communicated frequently with his wife. In about six months his letters ceased, and he was reported dead. His company officers also reporter the fact of his death to the War Department, and in due course of time his wife drew his arrearages and pay. Time rolled around, and his widow received the addresses of another man. About six months ago, the two were married, and have been living happily together since. This week their happiness was considerably marred, and the wife found herself in a very embarrassing situation. One day her former husband walked into his former home, a strong, healthy man. The woman has now two loving husbands, and how the matter is to be settled we have not heard -- Philadelphia Ledger, Aug. 26.

abstract: Davis Manifesto and Congressional Election
lead_paragraph: Senator WADE was recently censured in a formal resolution by the Union Convention of his own county in Ohio, for his recent joint manifesto with WINTER DAVIS. His Congressional district now follows in a similar expression of sentiment its Union Convention resolving that "the recent attack upon the President by WADE and DAVIS is, in our opinion, ill-timed, ill-tempered and ill-advised, carrying great and undisguised joy to the rebel camps in the South and rebel sympathizers in the North, and productive of evil, and only evil, to the Union cause; and that we feel it a duty, no less imperative than disagreeable, to pronounce upon that disorganizing manifesto our unqualified disapproval and condemnation."
