abstract: The steamship New-York, from Southampton, Aug. 17, the Louisiana, from Liverpool, Aug. 16, and the Edinburgh, from Liverpool, Aug. 17, all arrived at this port yesterday. The news is interesting, though not specially important. The pirate Florida has again been heard from. During...
lead_paragraph: The steamship New-York, from Southampton, Aug. 17, the Louisiana, from Liverpool, Aug. 16, and the Edinburgh, from Liverpool, Aug. 17, all arrived at this port yesterday. The news is interesting, though not specially important. The pirate Florida has again been heard from. During the month of July, off the coast of Brazil, she is reported as having destroyed the American merchantman Imfican, DEILLS, master, from San Francisco, for New-York. After taking out seventy thousand dollars in treasure, which the ship had on board and a part of her cargo, the vessel was burnt. The same dispatch reports the steamer Electric Spark, captured in June off the coast of Delaware, as being in company with the Florida. The news was sent from Bahia, Brazil, to Lisbon, and thence telegraphed. The United States steamer Kearsarge was on her return to New-York the 10th inst., so she maybe expected here any day. The German demand for American securities continued unabated, despite the gloomy talk of the London Times. The new of Gen. GRANT's repulse before Peterburgh caused a rise of three per cent. in the rebel loan. Mr. LINDSAY, Anglo-rebel member of the British Parliament, had been making speeches to his constituents, prophesying the entire disruption of this country into several confederacies. The riots at Belfast had assumed a very serious magnitude. Business was entirely suspended, and great mobs of Roman Catholics and Protestants had fall possession of the city. Some sixty persons had been killed, and wounded and many houses sacked. Financial news unimportant.

abstract: SUICIDE OF A YOUNG WOMAN A SAD CASE.  Coroner WILDEY held an inquest on Monday on the body of a young woman named FANNY KIMBALL, a native of Boston, aged 23 years, who died from the effects of poison administered by her own hand, at a house in Wooster-street.
lead_paragraph: SUICIDE OF A YOUNG WOMAN -- A SAD CASE. -- Coroner WILDEY held an inquest on Monday on the body of a young woman named FANNY KIMBALL, a native of Boston, aged 23 years, who died from the effects of poison administered by her own hand, at a house in Wooster-street. From the testimony given before the Coroner, it appears that deceased was a woman of good education, and in her earlier life had moved in the society of the refined and virtuous. A few months since she had been led astray, and then abandoned. Feeling deeply the infumy and disgrace attaching to her condition, her spirits were thereby much depressed, and in the height of her despair she resolved to [???]end the ills she could not mend." On Sunday night she partook of her supper, appearing at the time more than usually cheerful. Soon after she had retired to her room, she was found writhing in the agonies of death. Medical assistance was immediately called, and everything possible war done to relieve her, but without success. She did in about half an hour after being discovered. The postmortem examination made by Dr. GEORGE B. BOUTON, revealed the fact that death was caused by a quantity of cyanide of potassium, a very deadly poison, and the jury rendered a verdict of death by suicide, caused by taking that drug. On the table in her room was found two letters, one of which was addressed to her sister, who is a cripple, and whom she had for a long time supported, requesting her to take charge of her effects. The other letter was addressed to the keeper of the house where she died, regretting that she should have given so much trouble as to commit suicide there, but she said she was tired of life, and could no longer endure the infamy which had attached to her conduct. She hoped, that in another world more leniency would be shown her than there had been in this.

abstract: There seems as yet to be no certainty as to whether or not the draft will be made in this City on Monday next as ordered in the President's Proclamation. The list of naval recruits prepared by Mr. BLUNT, is in the possession of the authorities at Washington, but no decision has been received from them.
lead_paragraph: There seems as yet to be no certainty as to whether or not the draft will be made in this City on Monday next as ordered in the President's Proclamation. The list of naval recruits prepared by Mr. BLUNT, is in the possession of the authorities at Washington, but no decision has been received from them. The County Volunteer Committee think the credit claimed will be allowed, and the people meanwhile are anxiously expecting the order from the War Department.

abstract: A SALOON KEEPER ARRESTED FOR AN ATTEMPT TO MURDER. -- GEORGE LEESE, proprietor of the saloon known as the "Smithsonian," situated at No. 122 Greene-street, was brought before Justice LEDWITH, of the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday, charged with having feloniously assaulted and brutally beaten Mr. JAMES BRENNAN, of No. 23 Fortyth-street, and Mr. PETER BRENNAN, of No. 153 Elizabeth-street. The injuries sustained by the BRENNANS are said to be of a very dangerous character, and they allege that an attempt was made by LEESE to take their lives. The Magistrate held the prisoner in the sum of $500 bail.

abstract: We had occasion to remark, a few days since, upon the difficulties attending the present system of naval recruiting, and some of our correspondents have commented, with righteous severity, upon the swindling practices prevalent in the vicinity of the several naval rendezvous.
lead_paragraph: We had occasion to remark, a few days since, upon the difficulties attending the present system of naval recruiting, and some of our correspondents have commented, with righteous severity, upon the swindling practices prevalent in the vicinity of the several naval rendezvous. We have investigated these matters still further, and have become satisfied that there is no real necessity for submitting to these outrages, so far as the shipment of men is concerned. This business is intended by law to be done, and can be done, without any expense whatever to the individual citizen Applications at the naval rendezvous it Cherry-street will be received in person by the faithful and honorable officer in charge, and the business can be done through his office without being swindled, or as was set forth in an advertisement recently published in our columns by Capt. BULLUS, "the premises are unconditionally open without charge, and any man can put in a substitute or volunteer in rotation." To parties unfamiliar with the routine we would say, keep aloof from offers of assistance from brokers and hangerson; present your men promptly, stand by them, and they will go through promptly, in regular rotation.

lead_paragraph: The Platform of the Peace and War Democracy, fabricated yesterday at Chicago, was promptly characterized by the Hon. ALEXANDER LONG (one of the delegates to the Convention) as one made up of resolutions which might mean anything. There is only a single defect in this description. It overlooks those portions of the party declaration which mean nothing at all, which were not designed to mean anything, and to which nobody will be expected to impute any meaning.

abstract: The report of United States Commissioner NEWTON, in the case of FRANZ MULLER, the alleged murderer, was sent to the President at Washington on Monday night. Accompanying the document was the Commissioner's certificate of criminality, upon which the, warrant of extradition will be issued, unlese the President should, on reading the report, decide that the warrant cannot issue -- which is considered highly improbable. The warrant will probably arrive here this week, and be placed by the Commissioner in the hands of the United States Marshal or other person authorized to execute it. If the legal forms are completed on Saturday, Inspector TANNER, with his prisoner, will start for England on that day.

abstract: The Chicago Convention performed onehalf their work yesterday in the erection of a platform; but they did not succeed in accomplishing the other half, of placing a candidate upon it.
lead_paragraph: The Chicago Convention performed onehalf their work yesterday in the erection of a platform; but they did not succeed in accomplishing the other half, of placing a candidate upon it. The platform of principles consists of six planks, and we suppose they are considered sufficiently indefinite to suit all factions of the Democratic party. The first professes adhesion to the "Union under the Constitution;" the second explicitly declares the failure of our arms, inexplicitly declares the crimes of the Administration, and calls for a cessation of hostilities, with a view to an "ultimate convention," (whatever that may mean;) the third condemns military interference in elections, and declares that its repetition will be "held as revolutionary and resisted with all the means and power under our control." The fourth sets forth the aim of the Democratic party in two lines, and declaims against the Administration in seven times as many The fifth reprobates the action of the Government with respect to our prisoners of war, not saying a word against the rebels for their slow murder of thousands of them; and the last expresses sympathy with the "soldiery of the army." The resolutions were adopted with but four dissenting voices, which would seem to show that as regards the platform, the peace faction are gratified.
headline: {'main': 'The Chicago Convention.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Chicago Convention.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Wilmington the Last Rebel Port
lead_paragraph: An intelligent Southern Union man, recently escaped from rebeldom, writes a communication to the TIMES, in which he says that he regards the holding of the Weldon road as by far the most important gain made by Gen. GRANT since he crossed the Rapidan; but that the effective blockading of the port of Wilmington would be of even greater importance to us and greater damage to the rebellion. This port is and has been of more importance to the rebels than 50,000 men would be to-day, and its value increases daily. He says that when he left the South, the rebel Commissary Department was importing heavily of provisions -- that not less than twenty large fast steamers were running regularly from Bermuda, Nassau, etc., to Wilmington, the tonnage of each of which is not less than an average of 2,000 barrels; and thus, he thinks, 40,000 barrels of flour and pork might be shipped from the United States to these West India Islands, and thence forwarded into Wilmington under one fleet at one shipment. Every article that can possibly be needed by the rebels, such as arms, ammunition, clothing, etc., are imported through Wilmington, while cotton, tobacco and naval stores are shipped in return as exchange.
headline: {'main': 'The Last Port Left to the Southern Confederacy.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Last Port Left to the Southern Confederacy.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: The speech, made by our Governor on taking the presiding chair of the Chicago Convention, hardly exhibits his ordinary plausibility. abstract: Mr. GLADSTONE, the indefatigable, who is not content to let his scholarship rust, has given a new proof of his devotion to classical literature by the publication of a translation of the First Book of the Iliad, attempted in a style at once more literal and more poetical than the customary versions.
lead_paragraph: -- Mr. GLADSTONE, the indefatigable, who is not content to let his scholarship rust, has given a new proof of his devotion to classical literature by the publication of a translation of the First Book of the Iliad, attempted in a style at once more literal and more poetical than the customary versions. The metre adopted is that of TENNYSON's Locksley Hall, and the statesman wields it with a facility equal to that of the Laureate himself -- who did not invent it -- as it was used previously to his time by Mr. FRERE in his translations from ARISTOPHANES, but to whom it owes its present currency. Its superiority to modern ears over the classical unrhymed hexameter is self-apparent, and no other verse seems so well adapted to render the "long resounding march" of HOMER's line. A collection in one volume of the different experimental versions recently made of this book by scholars, as ARNOLD, WORSLEY, Sir JOHN HERSCHEL, &c., with a sketch of the controversy on the best method of translating HOMER, would be an acceptable gift to general eaders, as well as to scholars.

Soldiers of fifteen years cannot be very dreadful chaps.

abstract: The Navy Department has recently conferred the office of General Inspector of Steam Machinery  for the navy, upon Chief Engineer WM. W.W. WOOD, in place of Chief Engineer STIMERS, who has been detached upon other service.
lead_paragraph: The Navy Department has recently conferred the office of General Inspector of Steam Machinery for the navy, upon Chief Engineer WM. W.W. WOOD, in place of Chief Engineer STIMERS, who has been detached upon other service. The new incumbent is everywhere greeted with the kindest wishes for success in the performance of the onerous duties of his office. His predecessor is well and favorably known, and was recently ordered from this port to Philadelphia, to see about the engines of the light-draft iron-clad Tunxis. Mr. WOOD is using all the dispatch possible, and employing all the mechanical resources of the country in hurrying forward our new iron-clad and wooden fleets, consisting of over a hundred vessels.

abstract: We understand that a number of mail-bags sent from this City Aug. 10 by the overland mail route to California, were received back at the Postoffice yesterday, (30th.) having reached St. Joseph, Mo. The mail agent at that place fearing their capture by the hostile Indians infesting the remainder of the route, returned them, together with one mail-bag received from San Francisco, from which city it was sent July 29. The returned mails will be forwarded to California by the next steamer, which sails Saturday next, Sept. 3.

abstract: -- The United States Mail steamer Carolina, which arrived at this port on Monday, from Beaufort, N.C., had a singular and perilous occurrence on board of her during the passage. The second, mate, named RYAN, while in the performance of his duties on Saturday night, had occasion to mount to the hurricane deck, but missing his foothold he fell through two hatchways to the lower hold, distance of 25 feet, alighting amidst the machinery, his arm falling between the two piston rods, but the engine being promptly stopped, he was extricated with only few slight bruises.

abstract: COUNTERFEIT THREE DOLLAR BILLS ON THE BULLS' HEAD BANK. -- THOMAS THOMPSON, a blacksmith, aged 29 years, living at No. 43 Hammond-street, was arraigned yesterday before Justice LEDWITH, of the Jefferson Market Police Court, on the charge of having passed three well-executed counterfeit $3 bills on the Bulls' Head Bank of this City. One of the spurious notes was passed on Mr. JAMES NORRIS, proprietor of a liquor saloon, at No. 647 Washington-street, one on a box in Hudson-street, and one on JOHN MURRAY. The latter made a complaint at Police Headquarters, and Office BENNETT, of the Detective Force, after some difficulty succeeded in taking THOMPSON into custody. The Magistrate committed him in default of $1,000 bail. The prisoner's defence was that he was intoxicated at the time.
lead_paragraph: COUNTERFEIT THREE DOLLAR BILLS ON THE BULLS' HEAD BANK. -- THOMAS THOMPSON, a blacksmith, aged 29 years, living at No. 43 Hammond-street, was arraigned yesterday before Justice LEDWITH, of the Jefferson Market Police Court, on the charge of having passed three well-executed counterfeit $3 bills on the Bulls' Head Bank of this City. One of the spurious notes was passed on Mr. JAMES NORRIS, proprietor of a liquor saloon, at No. 647 Washington-street, one on a box in Hudson-street, and one on JOHN MURRAY. The latter made a complaint at Police Headquarters, and Office BENNETT, of the Detective Force, after some difficulty succeeded in taking THOMPSON into custody. The Magistrate committed him in default of $1,000 bail. The prisoner's defence was that he was intoxicated at the time.

abstract: Aide, Hamilton, Rita, a Novel; Sabine, L; Loyalists of the Revolution
snippet: Aide, Hamilton, Rita, a Novel; Sabine, L; Loyalists of the Revolution
lead_paragraph: In addition to their importance as illustrations of American history, Mr. SABINE'S handsome volumes have a significance at the present time well worth remarking. It is within the memory of every one -- a fact that comes out strongly in youthful reminiscence, mingled with the earliest lights and shadows of the past -- that the dreaded name "Tory" was a true "word of fear," "the heaviest stone that misfortune could throw at a man" -- an imputation that comprised within itself whatever was most terrible in proportion as it was vague and undefined. This state of feeling, which all will recognize, succeeded to the more active and energetic opposition of two conflicting parties arrayed against each other with the peculiar bitterness of intestine strife. And now, such is the soothing influence of time -- it has already in one generation been succeeded by a temper of the public mind when laborious investigations are undertaken into the history of these very Tories that affrighted our youth, and minute explorations respecting their lives and fortunes occupy our Historical Societies, and are brought out, like the present volumes, with every advantage that the publisher can bestow. There is surely a lesson to be learnt from this of peculiar importance at the present moment. Looking at the violence, the passion and the deep-seated enmity with which different sections of the country are now arrayed against each other, the most sagacious men have often glanced doubtfully on the prospect, despairing to see the day when these elements of discord could be neutralized, and their fury allayed. Time, however, is wiser than our devices, and to its healing influences may be safely left the circumstances that defy immediate action; to our children the animosities of to-day will have softened down into the feeling with which we now regard the once dreaded "Tory" of the Revolutionary War.
